Description: VIRGINIA COOPERATIVE EXTENSION (VCE), A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN VIRGINIA STATE UNIVERSITY (VSU) AND VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY (VT), AND THE VIRGINIA STATE UNIVERSITY AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH STATION (VSUARS), ENABLES PEOPLE TO IMPROVE THEIR LIVES THROUGH RESEARCH AND EDUCATION USING SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE FOCUSED ON THE ISSUES AND NEEDS OF THE CITIZENS OF THE COMMONWEALTH OF VIRGINIA. AUDIENCES ARE INVOLVED IN DESIGNING, IMPLEMENTING, AND EVALUATING NEEDS-DRIVEN PROGRAMS. VCE AND VSUARS STIMULATE POSITIVE PERSONAL AND SOCIETAL CHANGE LEADING TO MORE PRODUCTIVE LIVES, FAMILIES, FARMS, AND FORESTS, AS WELL AS A BETTER ENVIRONMENT IN URBAN AND RURAL COMMUNITIES. VCE'S GOALS ARE TO: 1) DEVELOP AND TRANSFER NEW KNOWLEDGE IN APPLIED AND BASIC LIFE SCIENCES, 2) PERFORM RELEVANT, OBJECTIVE, AND TIMELY RESEARCH 3) IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR COMMUNITIES AND CITIZENS IN THE COMMONWEALTH, 4) USE A SYSTEMS APPROACH TO PROGRAMMING, WITH TASK- ORIENTED WORK TEAMS THAT RESPOND TO THE NEEDS OF INDIVIDUALS, GROUPS, AND ORGANIZATIONS, 5) WORK WITH AT-RISK, UNDERSERVED, AND UNDERREPRESENTED AUDIENCES WHO NEED FOCUSED AND SPECIALIZED ATTENTION, 6) FULLY INTEGRATE A CULTURALLY DIVERSE PAID AND VOLUNTEER STAFF IN PLANNING, IMPLEMENTING, AND EVALUATING PROGRAMS, AND 7) RECRUIT AND COLLABORATE WITH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE PARTNERS TO BETTER UTILIZE RESOURCES, HEIGHTEN IMPACT, AND REACH A MORE DIVERSE AUDIENCE.  THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) IS COOPERATIVE EXTENSION’S FIRST NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM FOR LOW-INCOME POPULATIONS AND CONTINUES TO BE AT THE FOREFRONT OF NUTRITION EDUCATION EFFORTS THROUGH A SERIES OF LESSONS TO REDUCE NUTRITION INSECURITY OF LOW-INCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH. AS PARTNERS IN THE COMMONWEALTH OF VIRGINIA, VSU AND VT COLLABORATE TO RECRUIT AND TRAIN EFNEP STAFF, WHICH USES EDUCATION TO SUPPORT PARTICIPANTS’ EFFORTS TOWARD SELF-SUFFICIENCY, NUTRITIONAL HEALTH, AND WELL-BEING.

NONCOMMUNICABLE DISEASES RELATED TO UNHEALTHY LIFESTYLES AND POOR DIETS ARE BECOMING INCREASINGLY PREVALENT IN AMERICAN SAMOA. DIETS, FOR THE MOST PART, ARE HIGH IN ENERGY AND FAT—ESPECIALLY SATURATED FAT, REFINED CARBOHYDRATES, AND SALT AND LOW IN DIETARY FIBER AND ANTIOXIDANTS WHICH ARE READILY AVAILABLE IN FRUITS, VEGETABLES, NUTS, AND SEEDS. AS MORE PEOPLE BECOME AWARE OF THE IMPORTANCE OF REGULAR PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND EXERCISE, WE ARE SLOWLY SEEING MORE HEALTH-CONSCIOUS INDIVIDUALS BECOMING MORE PHYSICALLY ACTIVE. THE PRICE OF CIGARETTES CONTINUES TO INCREASE AND TIME WILL TELL WHETHER THIS WILL AFFECT OVERALL SMOKING RATES. THESE AND OTHER RISK FACTORS, ARE HIGHLY ASSOCIATED WITH THE INCREASED PREVALENCE OF OBESITY, HYPERTENSION, CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASE, TYPE 2 DIABETES, AND CANCER. OUR GOAL WILL BE TO TARGET THE LOW-INCOME POPULATION TO INCREASE AWARENESS OF THE NEED FOR HEALTHY DIETS AND HEALTHY LIFESTYLES TO HOPEFULLY DECREASE THE AMOUNT OF OVERWEIGHT AND OBESITY IN OUR TERRITORY. INCREASE AT LEAST 50% OF THE PROPORTION OF EFNEP OUTREACH TO PARTICIPANTS OF LOW-INCOME FAMILIES WITH RESEARCH-BASED INFORMATION. SOME STRATEGIES WE INTEND TO IMPLEMENT IN THE HOMES WILL BE TO DEVELOP RECIPES USING LOCALLY GROWN PRODUCE AND TO TEST THEM IN THE HOMES. RECIPES HAVE BEEN DISTRIBUTED WITH THE RATIONALE  THAT IF MORE FRESH VEGETABLES ARE READILY AVAILABLE, MORE WILL BE USED IN HOME MEALS. IF MORE FAMILIES BEGIN TO COOK MORE VEGETABLES AT HOME, THIS WILL LEAD TO A HIGHER INTAKE, WHICH WILL HOPEFULLY IMPROVE THE HEALTH OF MORE FAMILIES. EXPAND NUTRITION EDUCATION TO THE LOW-INCOME, FINANCIALLY-RESOURCED SECTORS OF THE COMMUNITY. INCREASE BY 50% THE PROPORTION OF LOW-INCOME FAMILIES WHO PROVIDE MEALS WITH FRUITS AND VEGETABLES TO THEIR CHILDREN AT THE MAIN MEAL. CONDUCT WORKSHOPS, PRESENTATIONS, AND DEMONSTRATIONS IN VILLAGES, CHURCHES, AND GOVERNMENT AGENCIES WITH THE GOAL OF DEVELOPING AND TESTING RECIPES USING LOCALLY GROWN VEGETABLES. MOREOVER, EFNEP STAFF WILL CONTINUE TO ROUTINELY CONDUCT ONE-ON-ONE CONSULTATIONS WITH STAKEHOLDERS TO HELP IMPROVE AND EVALUATE WHAT WORKS BEST. EFNEP STAFF WILL ALSO USE THE INPUT OF ITS CLIENTS AND PARTICIPANTS TO HELP IMPROVE THE PROGRAM. SHORT-TERM OUTCOMES: EFNEP WILL ASSIST PARTICIPANTS TO LEARN, CHANGE THEIR BEHAVIORS, AND TO GROW AND EXPERIENCE A FEELING OF ACCOMPLISHMENT AND POSITIVE SELF-ESTEEM. INADEQUATE FOOD SAFETY KNOWLEDGE AND POOR SANITATION PRACTICES OF FOOD HANDLERS ARE SOME OF THE REASONS WHY THERE ARE MANY FOODBORNE ILLNESS CASES HERE EACH YEAR. PREGNANT WOMEN, CHILDREN, OLDER ADULTS, AND PEOPLE WITH DIABETES AND CANCER ARE MORE SUSCEPTIBLE TO FOODBORNE ILLNESSES. AS THE NUMBER OF SINGLE-PARENT AND DUAL-INCOME FAMILIES INCREASES IN AMERICAN SAMOA, MORE AND MORE CHILDREN ARE RECEIVING CARE OUTSIDE OF THEIR OWN HOMES AND THIS INCREASES THE NEED FOR HELPFUL INFORMATION SO THAT PARENTS AND FAMILIES CAN BETTER CARE FOR THEIR CHILDREN, ESPECIALLY WITH RESPECT TO DIET QUALITY AND FOOD SAFETY. GOALS INCLUDE INCREASING FOOD SAFETY KNOWLEDGE AND THE ADOPTION OF SAFE FOOD HANDLING PRACTICES, WHICH WILL HOPEFULLY DECREASE THE PROBABILITY OF LOW-INCOME RESOURCED FAMILIES OF BECOMING SICK FROM FOODBORNE ILLNESSES. THE STRATEGY IS TO EDUCATE AND CONDUCT FOOD SAFETY AND NUTRITION OUTREACH PROGRAMS IN THE C OMMUNITY. DUE TO THE CHANGES THAT HAVE OCCURRED AS A RESULT OF COVID-19, OUR STRATEGY WILL INCLUDE USING SOCIAL MEDIA BECAUSE IT IS AN INDISPENSABLE OUTREACH TOOL. THE PROGRAM WILL CONTINUE TO CONDUCT NUTRITION AND FOOD SAFETY WORKSHOPS FOR YOUTH AND FAMILIES THROUGH PARTNERSHIPS WITH SCHOOLS, YOUTH GROUPS, LOCAL GOVERNMENT, AND NON-PROFIT AGENCIES. OUR OUTCOMES WILL FOCUS ON INCREASING KNOWLEDGE AMONG PARTICIPANTS WITH THE GOAL OF CHANGING ACTIONS/BEHAVIORS WITHIN DAILY LIVES IN TERMS OF HEALTHY LIVING. THIS CAN LEAD TO CHANGE IN CONDITION, ENVIRONMENT, OR SURROUNDING. FOCUS GROUPS AND SURVEYS WILL BE USED TO COLLECT THE DATA. THE COLLECTED DATA WILL BE REVIEWED TO DETERMINE WHAT IS WORKING AND WHAT IS NOT WORKING IN THE PROGRAMS.

2022 EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM REPORT MAINTAINING HEALTHY CHOICES MAY BE DIFFICULT FOR LIMITED- RESOURCE INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES. MANY TIMES, LIMITED-RESOURCE FAMILIES LIVE IN AREAS WITH INADEQUATE ACCESS TO HEALTH CARE AND HEALTHY FOOD OPTIONS. BECAUSE OF UNHEALTHY EATING HABITS AND REDUCED ACCESS TO PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, LIMITED-RESOURCE FAMILIES RUN HIGHER RISKS FOR DIABETES, HEART DISEASE, STROKE, HYPERTENSION AND OTHER DISEASES. SINCE 1969, THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION HEALTH BEHAVIOR IMPROVEMENTS: ADULT OUTREACH PROGRAM HAS EDUCATED LIMITED-RESOURCE FAMILIES AND YOUTH IN LOUISIANA, TEACHING THEM TO DEVELOP SKILLS TO MAKE HEALTHY CHANGES THAT WILL LEAD TO IMPROVED DIETS AND NUTRITIONAL WELL-BEING. THROUGH EFNEP’S ”HANDS-ON” APPROACH, PARTICIPANTS LEARN TO MAKE BEHAVIORAL CHANGES AND IMPROVE THE NUTRITIONAL QUALITY OF MEALS FOR THEIR FAMILIES. THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) IS TAUGHT TO PARTICIPANTS WITH EMPHASIS ON MAKING HEALTH FOOD CHOICES AND EXERCISING MORE IS A TOP PRIORITY. AN EFNEP PARTICIPANT AT SMALL WORLD ACADEMY SHARED HER COMMENTS ABOUT WHAT SHE LEARNED DURING THE SERIES OF LESSONS PRESENTED BY THE ORLEANS PARISH NUTRITION EDUCATOR. THE EFNEP PROGRAM TAUGHT ME "HOW TO TRACK MY HEART RATE, EXERCISE RECOMMENDATIONS, SAFETY, EATING AND EXERCISINGAND WALKING." THE PARTICIPANT ALSO STATED, I LEARNED HOW TO BUILD HEALTHY MEALS AND USE IT ALONG WITH A CUSTOMIZED FOOD PLAN AND I LEARNED NEW RECIPES."  YOUTH J.S. CLARK MAGNET SCHOOL IN OUACHITA PARISH HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED AS HEALTHY COMMUNITIES PARTNER SCHOOL FOR THE 2021- 2022 SCHOOL YEAR. A FOCUS FORUM AND NEEDS ASSESSMENT HAVE BEEN COMPLETED FOR THE SCHOOL, AND HEALTHY COMMUNITIES WORK GROUPS HAVE BEEN ESTABLISHED. SCHOOL ADMINISTRATORS AND FACULTY ARE SUPPORTIVE OF PSE CHANGES AND DIRECT EDUCATION RELATED TO HEALTHY LIVING. FUNDING WAS SOUGHT TO IMPLEMENT CHANGES BY THE LSU AGCENTER FCS AGENTS. AS A RESULT, TO OUR COLLABORATED PROPOSAL, THE OUACHITA LSU AGCENTER WAS AWARDED $5,675 OF GRANT FUNDING BY THE HEALTHY COMMUNITIES PROJECT MINI GRANT TO ADDRESS THE NUTRITION AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY ENVIRONMENTS IN THE PARISH THROUGH A SYSTEMIC, COMMUNITY-DRIVEN APPROACH TO REDUCING OBESITY. THE FUNDS WILL BE USED TOWARDS THE GROWING HEALTHY SCHOOLS PROJECT THAT IS AIMING TO POSITIVELY IMPACT CHILDREN’S HEALTH BEHAVIORS WHILE ALSO PROVIDING SUPPORT FOR TEACHERS TO MAKE HEALTHFUL CHOICES. BASED ON NEEDS ASSESSMENTS, INPUT FROM SCHOOL REPRESENTATIVES, AND FEEDBACK FROM THE OUACHITA HEALTHY COMMUNITIES COALITION MEMBERS, FUNDING WAS SOUGHT TO IMPLEMENT POLICY, SYSTEMS, AND ENVIRONMENTAL (PSE) CHANGES AT J.S. CLARK MAGNET WITH THE GOAL OF INCREASING PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND SUPPORTING HEALTHY CHOICES. FUNDING WAS APPROVED FOR PSE CHANGES TO SUPPORT THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT: • INSTALLATION OF SENSORY PATHWAYS TO PROMOTE MOVEMENT AND HELP STUDENTS DEVELOP MOTOR SKILLS • ADDITION OF A MENU BOARD TO ENCOURAGE HEALTHY EATING IN THE SCHOOL CAFETERIA • INSTALLATION OF SIGNAGE AT THE SCHOOL WALKING TRACK TO CREATE A “SILLY WALKING TRACK” AND PROMPT PHYSICAL ACTIVITY • ADDITION OF GIANT BOARD GAMES THAT REQUIRE MOVEMENT TO PLAY IN ORDER TO ALLOW FOR ACTIVE RECESS TIME EVEN ON BAD WEATHER DAYS WHEN THE OUTDOOR PLAYGROUNDS ARE NOT ACCESSIBLE • ADDITION OF PLAYGROUND ENHANCEMENTS TO PROMOTE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY • PROVISION OF NEEDED EQUIPMENT TO SUPPORT PHYSICAL EDUCATION CLASSES AND ACTIVE RECESS PLAY PSE EFFORTS WILL BE SUPPORTED BY DIRECT EDUCATION THROUGH THE EFFORTS OF FAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCES (FCS) AGENTS AND EFNEP/SNAP-ED NUTRITION EDUCATORS. FCS AGENTS WILL PROVIDE MONTHLY EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS FOR FACULTY AND STAFF MEMBERS DURING AFTER-SCHOOL FACULTY MEETINGS. THESE PROGRAMS WILL PROVIDE NUTRITION AND FOOD SAFETY EDUCATION FOR THE ADULT MEMBERS OF THE SCHOOL COMMUNITY WHILE GIVING THEM THE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS TO CREATE HEALTHY MEALS FOR THEIR FAMILIES. DIRECT EDUCATION FOR YOUTH AT THE SCHOOL INCLUDED “LET’S EAT FOR THE HEALTH OF IT” SERIES OF CLASSES FOR 4TH AND 5TH GRADERS AND “SHOW ME NUTRITION” SERIES OF CLASSES FOR KINDERGARTEN AND 1ST GRADERS. THE YOUTH THAT PARTICIPATED IN THE SERIES OF CLASSES WERE EVALUATED FOLLOWING EFNEP AND SNAP-ED PROGRAM EVALUATION PROCEDURES. THE LSU AGCENTER WILL CONTINUE TO COLLABORATE WITH J.S. CLARK MAGNET SCHOOL TO PROVIDE RESOURCES, DIRECT EDUCATION, AND SOCIAL MARKETING. THE OUACHITA HEALTHY COMMUNITIES COALITION WILL CONTINUE TO LOOK FOR SOLUTIONS TO ENGAGE THE COMMUNITY IN EFFORTS TO PROMOTE HEALTHY EATING AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY.  IF YOU OR SOMEONE YOU KNOW IS INTERESTED IN PARTICIPATING IN THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP), CONTACT YOUR NEAREST LSU AGCENTER EXTENSION SERVICE OFFICE. SHARMAN J. THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) IS A PROGRAM THAT ADDRESSES THE CRITICAL ISSUES OF SOCIETY BY EMPLOYING PA RAPROFESSIONAL EDUCATORS TO ADMINISTER HEALTHY NUTRITION AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITIES TO LOW-INCOME YOUTH AND ADULTS. THE PROGRAM FOCUSES ON DIET QUALITY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, FOOD SAFETY AND FOOD SECURITY. EFNEP, PRESENTLY, SERVES LIMITED RESOURCE POPULATIONS WITHIN THE UPSTATE, MIDLANDS AND LOW COUNTRY REGIONS. PROGRAMMING PROVIDES NUTRITION EDUCATION AND MEAL PREPARATION SKILLS THAT ARE CONSISTENT WITH REGIONAL CULTURAL TRADITIONS AND RESOURCES. LOW INCOME, POOR DIET, OBESITY, AND A LACK OF EXERCISE ARE INTERRELATED FACTORS THAT CREATE MANY HEALTH RELATED ISSUES IN THE WORLD. TO HELP ALLEVIATE SOME OF THE ISSUES IDENTIFIED, THE SC STATE 1890 FOCUSES ON NUTRITION, OBESITY, FOOD SAFETY/INSECURITY, AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITIES, DURING THE PRESENT 5 YEAR PLAN CYCLE. GOOD NUTRITION IS IMPORTANT NOT ONLY BECAUSE IT PROMOTES A FEELING OF WELL-BEING, BUT ALSO BECAUSE IT HAS AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN DISEASE PREVENTION. ACCORDING TO VANDERBILT MEDICAL CENTER (2019), 5 OF 10 LEADING CAUSES OF DEATH IN THE UNITED STATES ARE DISEASES IN WHICH DIET PLAYS A PART. THE SUPPLEMENTAL NUTRITION ASSISTANCE PROGRAM. IN PREVIOUS YEARS, THE SOUTH CAROLINA STATE UNIVERSITY 1890 RESEARCH AND EXTENSION EFNEP HAS FOUND IT CHALLENGING TO OBTAIN ADULT PARTICIPANTS WHO MEET THE TARGET ADULT POPULATION. A PLAN WAS IMPLEMENTED TO DO A MORE CONSISTENT AND INTENTIONAL JOB OF IDENTIFYING PERSONS WHO MEET THE EFNEP CRITERIA AND THEN TARGETING THOSE PERSONS FOR INCLUSION INTO PROGRAMS BEING OFFERED. SOME CHANGES BEING IMPLEMENTED INCLUDE IDENTIFYING AND FORMING WORKING PARTNERSHIPS WITH ESTABLISHED GROUPS THAT CONSIST ONLY OF ACCEPTABLE PARTICIPANTS AND FINDING WAYS TO WORK WITH THEIR SCHEDULES AND OTHER NEEDS. FOR EXAMPLE, HOMES FOR PREGNANT TEENS, SHELTERS FOR WOMEN AND CHILDREN AND SCHOOLS FOR EXPECTANT MOTHERS AS WELL AS WORKING WITH THE COUNTY WIC OFFICES. THE FINANCIAL CIRCUMSTANCES FOR MANY SOUTH CAROLINIANS HAVE CHANGED WITHIN THE LAST FEW YEARS. PROGRAM OPPORTUNITIES AND PARTICIPATION IS CONSTANTLY EXPANDING TO MEET THE NEEDS OF THE PUBLIC. 1890 EFNEP WILL CONTRIBUTE TO NUTRITION, FOOD SAFETY/INSECURITY, AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITIES OF THE PARTICIPANTS THROUGH WORKSHOPS AND TRAININGS PROGRAMMING.

TENNESSEE HAS A POPULATION OF 6,829,174 WITH 15.3%, SOME 1,044,864 TENNESSEANS, FALLING AT OR BELOW THE POVERTY LINE. TSU'S EFNEP PROGRAM IS SITUATED WITHIN DAVIDSON, STEWART, AND TIPTON COUNTIES AND, IN 2023, SHELBY COUNTY HAS BEEN INCLUDED AS A POSSIBLE NEW PROGRAMMING COUNTY. SHELBY COUNTY'S POVERTY RATE IS 19.1%, OR ALMOST ONE OUT OF EVERY FIVE PEOPLE. STEWART COUNTY'S POVERTY RATE IS 13.2%. TIPTON COUNTY HAS A POVERTY RATE OF 12.7%. DAVIDSON COUNTY'S POVERTY RATE IS 12.8%.  THE POVERTY LEVEL OF CHILDREN ACROSS TENNESSEE IS DIRE WITH 18.4%, OR ONE OUT OF EVERY FIVE, OF TENNESSEE'S CHILDREN FALLING AT OR BELOW THE POVERTY LINE. IN DAVIDSON COUNTY 17.3%, OR ALMOST ONE OUT OF EVERY FIVE CHILDREN, FALLS AT OR BELOW THE POVERTY LINE. IN TIPTON COUNTY THE CHILD POVERTY RATE IS 20.1%. IN STEWART COUNTY, 21.1%, OR ONE OUT OF EVERY FIVE CHILDREN, FALLS AT OR BELOW THE POVERTY LINE. ONE OUT OF EVERY FOUR CHILDREN IN DAVIDSON, STEWART, AND TIPTON COUNTIES RECEIVED SNAP BENEFITS AND 40% OF CHILDREN IN SHELBY COUNTY RECEIVE SNAP BENEFITS. SHELBY COUNTY HAS 1 OUT OF 4 HOUSEHOLDS RECEIVING SNAP BENEFITS. TIPTON COUNTY HAS 1 OUT OF EVERY 5 HOUSEHOLDS RECEIVING SNAP BENEFITS.  FOURTEEN PERCENT OF TENNESSEANS ARE FOOD INSECURE, SOME 976,531 PEOPLE. FOOD INSECURITY IN THE COUNTIES SERVED BY TSU EFNEP RANGE FROM 14%-20. CHILD FOOD INSECURITY IS HIGHER WITH AN AVERAGE OF 19.8% OF ALL CHILDREN IN THE STATE EXPERIENCING HUNGER. IN SHELBY COUNTY, ALMOST 1 OUT OF EVERY 3 CHILDREN ARE FOOD INSECURE.  OBESITY IN TENNESSEE IMPACTS 33% OF ADULTS AND 39.5% OF CHILDREN. IN TIPTON COUNTY 37% OF ADULTS ARE OBESE AND IN SHELBY COUNTY 35% OF ADULTS ARE OBESE. IN STEWART AND SHELBY COUNTIES CHILD OBESITY RATES ARE 40.6% AND 39.3% RESPECTIVELY, AND IN TIPTON COUNTY, 37.9% OF CHILDREN ARE OBESE.  TENNESSEE STATE UNIVERSITY’S EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) WILL CONTINUE TO WORK IN DAVIDSON, STEWART, AND TIPTON COUNTIES, AND BEGIN TO DEVELOP A PROGRAM IN SHELBY COUNTY IN FEDERAL FISCAL YEAR 2023. THE PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE MULTI- SERIES CLASSES TO PARTICIPANTS THAT ARE 60-90 MINUTES IN DURATION FOR EACH LESSON, WITH PRE AND POST SURVEYS AND 24-HOUR DIETARY RECALLS. THE LESSONS WILL USE RESEARCH AND EVIDENCE BASED CURRICULA THAT FOCUSES ON FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, HEALTHY DIETARY CHOICES, FOOD SAFETY, AND INCREASING PHYSICAL ACTIVITY FOR ADULTS AND YOUTH. DATA COLLECTED BY THE PROGRAM WILL BE REPORTED TO USDA NIFA THROUGH THE WEBNEERS REPORTING SYSTEM TO INDICATE WHETHER OR NOT THE INTERVENTION OF THE LESSONS AND HANDS-ON ACTIVITIES AND COOKING DEMONSTRATIONS HELP PARTICIPANTS IMPROVE THEIR SHOPPING, COOKING, AND ACTIVE LIFESTYLE CHOICES AND BEHAVIORS TO HELP STRETCH FOOD DOLLARS AND REDUCE INSTANCES OF CHRONIC DISEASE.  INDIRECT EDUCATION WILL INCLUDE SOCIAL MARKETING AND BRANDING ACTIVITIES ON SOCIAL MEDIA PLATFORMS THAT ENCOURAGE PARTICIPANTS TO “SHOP. COOK. EAT. WITHIN YOUR BUDGET.” POLICY, SYSTEMS, AND ENVIRONMENTAL (PSE) CHANGE APPROACHES THAT HELP MAKETHE HEALTHY CHOICE THE EASY CHOICE FOR COMMUNITIES SERVED BY THE PROGRAM WILL CONTINUE TO BE SUPPORTED BY THE PROGRAM IN PARTNERSHIP AND COLLABORATION WITH LOCAL HEALTH COUNCILS, SCHOOL SYSTEMS, NONPROFITS, AND OTHER COMMUNITY OUTREACH ORGANIZATIONS WHOSE MISSIONS ARE TO BRING RESOURCES INTO THE COMMUNITY THAT PROMOTES EQUITY IN ACCESS TO HEALTHY FOOD AND HEALTHY LIFESTYLES.

DSU EXTENDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM  PER THE STATE OF CHILDHOOD OBESITY, DELAWARE HAS THE 1"' HIGHEST ADULT OBESITY RATE IN THE NATION AND THE16" HIGHEST YOUTH RATE FOR AGES 10 TO 17. DELAWARE'S ADULT OBESITY RATE IS CURRENTLY 33.5%, UP FROM 17 .1 % IN 2000. ADULTS BETWEEN THE AGES OF 45-64 HAVE THE HIGHEST PREVALENCE OF OBESITY AT 39%, FOLLOWED BY ADULTS BETWEEN THE AGES OF 25-44 AT 33.8%, AND ADULTS ABOVE 65 AT 32.5%. ADULT OBESITY RATES ARE LOWEST IN THOSE WHO ARE 18-24 YEARS OF AGE AT 18.4%. THE OBESITY RATE FOR 2-TO 4-YEAR-OLD WIC PARTICIPANTS IN DELAWARE IN 2014 WAS 17.2%. THE 2014 DELAWARE SURVEY OF CHILDREN'S HEALTH (DSCH), SPONSORED BY NEMOURS FOUND THAT 14.7% OF DELAWARE CHILDREN, AGES 2-17, ARE OVERWEIGHT AND THAT 20.9% ARE OBESE. ALIGNED WITH DSU PRIORITY FOR CARRYING OUT A PROGRAM OF EXTENSION ACTIVITIES DESIGNED TO EMPLOY AND TRAIN PROFESSIONAL AND PARAPROFESSIONAL AIDES TO ENGAGE IN DIRECT NUTRITION EDUCATION OF LOW-INCOME FAMILIES AND IN OTHER APPROPRIATE NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAMS. DSU-EFNEP PLAN WILL STRIVE TO USE EVIDENCE-BASED NUTRITION EDUCATION AND PSE INTERVENTIONS TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH BEHAVIORS OF LOW-INCOME DELAWAREANS THAT AFFECT PRIORITY ISSUES INCLUDING OBESITY, MENTAL HEALTH, AND CHRONIC DISEASE. APPROACHES FOR HEALTHY COMMUNITIES PSE LEARNING COLLABORATIVE HELPED EDUCATORS, SUPERVISORS, PLANNERS, LEADERS, AND DECISION MAKERS UNDERSTAND THE IMPORTANCE OF PSE WORK, CREATE A COMMON PSE LANGUAGE THROUGHOUT THE STATE, AND PROVIDE THE SKILL SET NECESSARY FOR THE INCORPORATION OF PSE APPROACHES INTO HEALTH PROMOTION WORK THROUGH DELAWARE. OUR TARGET AUDIENCE WILL CONSIST OF FAMILIES, I.E. MOTHERS, PREGNANT TEENS, ADULT CAREGIVERS OF YOUNG CHILDREN; IN ADDITION TO YOUTHS BETWEEN THE AGES OF 8-15 YEARS OF AGE. THE TARGET AUDIENCE WILL BE RECRUITED VIA COMMUNITY CENTERS, FAITH-BASED ORGANIZATIONS, SOCIAL SERVICE CENTERS, HEALTH CARE CENTERS, SHELTERS, ADULT EDUCATION CENTERS, STATE SERVICE CENTERS, REHAB FACILITIES, STATE AND LOCAL HOUSING FACILITIES, BOYS AND GIRLS CLUBS, AFTER SCHOOL PROGRAMS, ETC.

COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY (CSU) EXTENSION EMPOWERS COLORADANS TO ADDRESS IMPORTANT AND EMERGING COMMUNITY NEEDS USING DYNAMIC, SCIENCE-BASED EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES. FOR OVER 100 YEARS, CSU EXTENSION HAS HELPED PEOPLE IN COLORADO FIND THE ANSWERS THEY NEED FOR A HEALTHY HOME LIFE, SUCCESSFUL BUSINESS AND THRIVING COMMUNITY.  OBJECTIVES  FUNDS REQUESTED WILL BE USED TO DELIVER CSU’S EFNEP PROGRAMMING ACROSS THE STATE OF COLORADO AND BRING THE UNIVERSITY’S RESEARCH-BASED RESOURCES TO LOCAL COMMUNITIES. CSU EXTENSION’S EFNEP SPECIALISTS WILL CONNECT COLORADANS TO NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAMS AIMED AT REDUCING NUTRITION INSECURITY AMONG LOW-INCOME COLORADO FAMILIES AND YOUTH. THESE EDUCATION PROGRAMS WILL SUPPORT PARTICIPANTS IN GAINING GREATER SELF-SUFFICIENCY AND NUTRITIONAL HEALTH, AS WELL AS INCREASING PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AMONG UNDERSERVED COLORADO POPULATIONS.  METHODS EMPLOYED  CSU EXTENSION’S EFNEP PROGRAM WILL MEET THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT BY IMPARTING INFORMATION ON THESE SUBJECTS THROUGH DEMONSTRATIONS, PUBLICATIONS, AND DISSEMINATION OF INFORMATION IN CONNECTION WITH THESE SUBJECTS. CSU’S EFNEP PROGRAM COMBINES HANDS-ON LEARNING, APPLIED SCIENCE, AND PROGRAM DATA TO ENSURE PROGRAM EFFECTIVENESS, EFFICIENCY, AND ACCOUNTABILITY. EXTENSION SPECIALISTS DELIVER LOCAL PROGRAMMING IN 63 COLORADO COUNTIES, THAT ADDRESS IMPORTANT AND EMERGING COMMUNITY NEEDS. THIS EFFORT IS ACCOMPLISHED THRU HOME INSTRUCTION, IN-PERSON AND REMOTE SEMINARS, THE DISSEMINATION OF PRINT AND ELECTRONIC MEDIA, AND ON-DEMAND ACCESS TO SPECIALISTS. BY EMPLOYING THESE METHODS, CSU’S EFNEP PROGRAM SUPPORTS COLORADANS IN IMPROVING THEIR DIETS, IMPROVING THEIR NUTRITION PRACTICES, HANDLING FOOD SAFELY, AND INCREASING PHYSICAL ACTIVITY LEVELS.

FY 2023 PROGRAM ABSTRACT – EFNEP THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) IS A FEDERALLY FUNDED NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM FOR LIMITED-RESOURCES YOUTH AND FAMILIES DELIVERED THROUGH THE UVI SCHOOL OF AGRICULTURE COOPERATIVE EXTENSION SERVICE IN THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS. EFNEP PROVIDES HANDS-ON INTERACTIVE WORKSHOPS TO HELP PARTICIPANTS IMPROVE NUTRITION, DIET AND HEALTH LITERACY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY BEHAVIORS, FOOD RESOURCES MANAGEMENT, FOOD SAFETY AND FOOD SECURITY. PROGRAMS SERVE INCOME ELIGIBLE PARENTS AND YOUNG ADULTS, CAREGIVERS, AND EXPECTANT MOTHERS, AS WELL AS CHILDREN AND TEENS. THESE NUTRITION EDUCATION OUTREACH PROGRAMS ARE FACILITATED BY FRONTLINE EDUCATORS WHO, FOR THE MOST PART, COME FOR OR REPRESENT THE COMMUNITIES THEY SERVE. EFNEP IN THE VIRGIN ISLANDS ENGAGES ADULT PARTICIPANTS FROM PUBLIC HOUSING COMMUNITIES, ADULT EDUCATION, UVI STUDENTS, HEAD START PROGRAMS AND REFERRALS FROM THE WOMEN INFANTS AND CHILDREN (WIC) AND SUPPLEMENTAL NUTRITION ASSISTANCE (SNAP) PROGRAMS. THROUGH A SERIES OF 6-9 LESSONS USING EFNEP APPROVED CURRICULA, PARTICIPANTS LEARN HOW TO MAKE FOOD CHOICES THAT ARE ECONOMICAL AND IMPROVE THE NUTRITIONAL QUALITY OF MEALS THEY PREPARE AND SERVE THEIR FAMILIES. THROUGH AN EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING PROCESS, THEY IMPROVE THEIR ABILITY TO BETTER MANAGE THEIR FOOD DOLLAR TO SELECT AND BUY QUALITY, NUTRITION-RICH FOOD ON A LIMITED FOOD BUDGET; GAIN SKILLS IN FOOD PREPARATION, STORAGE, AND SANITATION; AND LEARN TO MANAGE THEIR FOOD BUDGET AND CONNECT TO RELEVANT RESOURCES. THROUGH 6-8 HOURS OF DIRECT CONTACT USING EFNEP APPROVED EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES, YOUTH AGES 5-18 ENROLLED IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS OR 4-H CLUBS, EXPERIENCE BELONGING, MASTERY, INDEPENDENCE AND GENEROSITY WHILE LEARNING ABOUT BASIC NUTRITION, FOOD PREPARATION AND SAFETY, AND WAYS TO REDUCE SCREEN TIME AND INCREASE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY. EFNEP PROGRAMS ARE EVALUATED USING 24-HOUR FOOD RECALLS FOR ADULT PARTICIPANTS, AND PRE-AND POST-TESTS FOR BOTH YOUTH AND ADULTS.

AAMU-ACES EFNEP 2023  PROJECT ABSTRACT   THE URBAN EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION OUTREACH PROGRAM WILL FOCUS PRIMARILY ON HISPANIC PREGNANT MOTHERS AND MOTHERS WITH YOUNG CHILDREN AGES 0 TO 5 AND HISPANIC YOUTH AGES 6 TO 14. STATISTICS SUPPORT THE CONTENTION THAT THE HEALTH STATUS OF HISPANICS IS CONSISTENTLY LOWER THAN THAT OF WHITES OR BLACKS AMONG ALL AGE GROUPS, JUSTIFYING A NEED FOR MORE NUTRITION AND HEALTH EDUCATION FOR THIS UNDERSERVED, LIMITED RESOURCE AUDIENCE. PROGRAMMING WILL BE CONDUCTED IN 5 COUNTIES, DEKALB, LIMESTONE, MADISON, MARSHALL, AND MORGAN.  NUTRITION CURRICULUM PRESENTED WILL SUPPORT ADULT AND YOUTH LEARNING THROUGH A SERIES OF 6-10 LESSONS WITH FOOD DEMONSTRATIONS CONDUCTED WITH EACH GROUP AS APPROPRIATE.  URBAN EFNEP IS ALSO AN EDUCATION PROGRAM FOR YOUTH AGES 6-14 AND MOTHERS WITH CHILDREN UNDER THE AGE OF FIVE TEACHING THEM HOW TO CONSUME HEALTHY FOODS ON A LIMITED BUDGET AND ENCOURAGING DAILY PHYSICAL ACTIVITY FOR THE WHOLE FAMILY. CLASSES ARE OFFERED IN ENGLISH <(>&<)> SPANISH. THE LESSONS ARE FILLED WITH HANDS-ON ACTIVITIES WITH REAL-WORLD EXAMPLES OFFERING A FUN AND ENGAGING WAY TO LEARN ABOUT NUTRITION.  GOALS OF URBAN EFNEP: • HELP FAMILIES STRETCH THEIR FOOD DOLLARS • ENCOURAGE PEOPLE TO EAT MORE FRUITS AND VEGETABLES • ENCOURAGE FAMILIES TO INCORPORATE DAILY PHYSICAL ACTIVITIES INTO THEIR LIFESTYLES WHILE HAVING FUN • DESCRIBE HOW TO PREPARE, SERVE, AND STORE FOOD SAFELY • PROMOTE GOOD HEALTH AND FITNESS THROUGH NUTRITION AND WELLNESS  LEARNING OUTCOMES: • BASIC NUTRITION AND HOW TO PLAN HEALTHIER MEALS AND SNACKS TO ENCOURAGE HEALTHY EATING HABITS • HOW TO MAKE WISE FOOD CHOICES • HOW TO PREPARE HEALTHY MEALS FOR BABIES, YOUNG CHILDREN, AND YOUTH • HOW TO APPLY FOOD SAFETY SKILLS WHEN PURCHASING, PREPARING, COOKING, AND STORING FOODS • SMART SHOPPING TECHNIQUES • HOW TO MAKE HEALTHY SNACKS AND RECIPES THROUGH HANDS-ON COOKING DEMONSTRATIONS

TEXAS A<(>&<)>M AGRILIFE EXTENSION SERVICE’S, EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP), ASSISTS UNDERSERVED FAMILIES AND YOUTH IN ACQUIRING THE KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, ATTITUDES, AND CHANGED BEHAVIORS NECESSARY FOR NUTRITIONALLY SOUND DIETS AND CONTRIBUTES TO THEIR PERSONAL DEVELOPMENT AND THE IMPROVEMENT OF TOTAL FAMILY DIET AND NUTRITIONAL WELFARE.  PROGRAM SERIES ARE DELIVERED USING RESEARCH‐BASED CURRICULA AND EVIDENCE‐BASED APPROACHES TO LEARNING. EACH EDUCATIONAL SERIES IS FA CILITATED BY ETHNICALLY DIVERSE PARAPROFESSIONAL (PEER) WHO SPEAK LANGUAGES OTHER THAN ENGLISH. EFNEP GRADUATES WILL: IMPROVE THEIR DIETS, IMPROVE THEIR NUTRITION PRACTICES, STRETCH THEIR FOOD DOLLARS FARTHER, HANDLE FOOD MORE SAFELY, AND INCREASE THEIR PHYSICAL ACTIVITY LEVELS.  TEXAS A<(>&<)>M EFNEP AUDIENCES INCLUDE LOW‐INCOME PARENTS AND OTHER ADULT CAREGIVERS (SUCH AS GRANDPARENTS AND GUARDIANS) WHO HAVE PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY FOR CARING AND PREPARING FOOD FOR THEIR CHILDREN, WITH EMPHASIS ON FAMILIES AND CAREGIVERS OF YOUNG CHILDREN. LIMITED RESOURCED PREGNANT WOMEN AND TEENS ARE ANOTHER KEY AUDIENCE FOR PROGRAMMING. CURRENTLY, EFNEP IS OPERATING IN 11 TEXAS URBAN COUNTIES INCLUDING BEXAR, CAMERON, DALLAS, EL PASO, FORT BEND, HARRIS, HIDALGO, NUECES, TARRANT, TRAVIS, AND WILLACY. THE COMBINED POPULATION IN THESE COUNTIES REPRESENT APPROXIMATELY 53% OF THE STATE'S TOTAL POPULATION.

EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM ABSTRACT  THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) IS THE NATION’S FIRST NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM FOR LOW-INCOME POPULATIONS AND REMAINS AT THE FOREFRONT OF NUTRITION EDUCATION EFFORTS TO REDUCE NUTRITION INSECURITY OF LOW-INCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH TODAY.  EFNEP IS A FEDERAL EXTENSION (COMMUNITY OUTREACH) PROGRAM THAT CURRENTLY OPERATES THROUGH THE 1862 AND 1890 LAND-GRANT UNIVERSITIES IN EVERY STATE, THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, AND THE SIX U.S. TERRITORIES – AMERICAN SAMOA, GUAM, MICRONESIA, NORTHERN MARIANAS, PUERTO RICO, AND THE VIRGIN ISLANDS. FUNDED BY THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE, NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF FOOD AND AGRICULTURE (USDA/NIFA), EFNEP USES EDUCATION TO SUPPORT PARTICIPANTS’ EFFORTS TOWARD SELF- SUFFICIENCY, NUTRITIONAL HEALTH, AND WELL-BEING. EFNEP COMBINES HANDS-ON LEARNING, APPLIED SCIENCE, AND PROGRAM DATA TO ENSURE PROGRAM EFFECTIVENESS, EFFICIENCY, AND ACCOUNTABILITY.  EFNEP COMBINES HANDS-ON LEARNING AND APPLIED SCIENCE TO ADDRESS NUTRITION INSECURITY IN LOW- INCOME POPULATIONS THAT DISPROPORTIONATELY EXPERIENCE POOR HEALTH. EFNEP TEACHES THE SKILLS TO MAKE HEALTHIER CHOICES, SAVE MONEY, INCREASE SELF-SUFFICIENCY, AND IMPROVE OVERALL WELL-BEING.  THE UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT (UCONN), COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE, HEALTH AND NATURAL RESOURCES (CAHNR), EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) HELPS FAMILIES LEARN ABOUT HEALTHY EATING, SHOPPING ON A BUDGET, COOKING, AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY. EFNEP STAFF STRIVE TO EMPOWER PARTICIPANTS, PROVIDING KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH OF ALL FAMILY MEMBERS. PARTICIPANTS LEARN THROUGH DOING, WITH COOKING, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND SUPPORTIVE DISCUSSIONS ABOUT NUTRITION AND HEALTHY HABITS.  EFNEP UTILIZES A PEER EDUCATOR MODEL TO PROVIDE A SERIES OF CLASSES ON NUTRITION, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, FOOD SAFETY, AND FOOD SECURITY. EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULA ARE UTILIZED AND NUTRITION EDUCATION ALIGNS WITH THE DIETARY GUIDELINES FOR AMERICANS. THE COURSES ARE OFFERED IN A PRACTICAL, HANDS-ON FORMAT. CLASSES ARE CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE AND OFFERED IN ENGLISH OR SPANISH, AS INDICATED BY THE AUDIENCE. AS REQUIRED BY USDA NIFA, 24 -HOUR DIETARY RECALLS AND THE VALIDATED EFNEP QUESTIONNAIRES ARE ADMINISTERED BEFORE AND AFTER THE CLASS SERIES TO ASSESS PROGRAM EFFECTIVENESS. DATA ARE ENTERED INTO THE WEBNEERS ONLINE SYSTEM TO BE APPROVED AT THE STATE LEVEL, THEN BY USDA NIFA. PARTICIPATION IN EFNEP SHOULD RESULT IN IMPROVED DIETS AND NUTRITIONAL WELL-BEING OF THE TOTAL FAMILY. GOALS INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING 1. INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES SHOULD EXPERIENCE IMPROVEMENTS IN FOUR CORE AREAS: A. DIET QUALITY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY—IMPROVED DIETS AND NUTRITIONAL AND PHYSICAL WELL- BEING THROUGH THE ADOPTION OF FEDERAL FOOD AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY RECOMMENDATIONS. B. FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT—INCREASED ABILITY TO BUY, GROW, OR OTHERWISE APPROPRIATELY OBTAIN, PREPARE, AND STORE FOOD THAT MEETS NUTRITIONAL NEEDS. C. FOOD SAFETY—IMPROVED HOUSEHOLD FOOD SAFETY AND SANITATION PRACTICES.  D. FOOD SECURITY—INCREASED ABILITY TO GET FOOD DIRECTLY—AND FROM FOOD ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS WHERE NECESSARY—TO ENSURE HAVING ENOUGH HEALTHY FOOD TO EAT. 2. COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT WITH EFNEP SHOULD RESULT IN: A. INCREASED REFERRALS ACROSS PROGRAMS, ORGANIZATIONS, AND COMMUNITY GROUPS TO ADDRESS PARTICIPANTS’ NEEDS AND TO STRENGTHEN UNIVERSITIES’ CAPACITIES WITH RESPECT TO EFNEP’S FOUR CORE AREAS. B. INCREASED COORDINATION, COOPERATION, AND COLLABORATION BETWEEN UNIVERSITIES AND COMMUNITIES TO ACCOMPLISH LOCAL AND STATE IDENTIFIED PRIORITIES ASSOCIATED WITH EFNEP’S FOUR CORE AREAS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF OUR PROGRAMS INCLUDE 1) FAMILIES WITH YOUNG CHILDREN (PARENTS AND OTHER CAREGIVERS WITH PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY FOR FEEDING YOUNG CHILDREN); 2) YOUTH/CHILDREN (GRADE RANGE - KINDERGARTEN THROUGH 12TH GRADE); AND 3) YOUNG ADULTS WITH LIMITED FINANCIAL RESOURCES. IN ADDITION, BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE LOW-INCOME COMMUNITIES THROUGHOUT CONNECTICUT; PARTNERSHIPS FOR SITE INCLUDE SCHOOLS, AFTERSCHOOL PROGRAMS, JOBS PROGRAMS, SHELTERS, LOW-INCOME HOUSING, AND COMMUNITY CENTERS.

IDAHO EFNEP FY2020-2024 PLAN OF WORK ABSTRACT  SITUATION: IDAHO’S POPULATION IS JUST OVER 1.7 MILLION (1,787,065), WITH 11.2% LIVING IN POVERTY AND 8.3% RECEIVING SNAP BENEFITS. IDAHO’S EFNEP PROGRAM TARGETS COUNTIES WITH HIGH POPULATION AND SNAP USAGE TO ASSIST LIMITED- RESOURCE FAMILIES AND YOUTH TO ACQUIRE KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ATTITUDES TO IMPROVE DIET AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY BEHAVIORS THAT CONTRIBUTE TO THEIR PERSONAL DEVELOPMENT AND THE IMPROVEMENT OF TOTAL FAMILY HEALTH. THE LOCATION OF SNAP RECIPIENTS IN IDAHO CLOSELY CORRESPONDS TO COUNTY POPULATION, WITH OVER 75% OF IDAHO’S SNAP PARTICIPANTS RESIDING IN THE TEN MOST POPULOUS COUNTIES (ADA, CANYON, KOOTENAI, BONNEVILLE, BANNOCK, TWIN FALLS, BINGHAM, BONNER, NEZ PERCE, AND LATAH). THE PERCENTAGE OF RESIDENTS RECEIVING SNAP BENEFITS VARIES GREATLY AMONG THESE TEN COUNTIES, RANGING FROM A LOW OF 5.36% IN LATAH COUNTY TO 13.09% IN CANYON COUNTY, WITH A STATE AVERAGE OF 9.04%. EVEN AMONG THESE POPULOUS COUNTIES, THERE ARE RURAL AREAS, RANGING FROM 5% OF ADA COUNTY CLASSIFIED AS RURAL TO 28% OF TWIN FALLS COUNTY. OVERALL IN IDAHO, 29.4% OF THE POPULATION LIVES IN RURAL AREAS, WITH 12 COUNTIES IDENTIFIED AS 100% OF THE POPULATION LIVING IN A RURAL AREA.  TWO-THIRDS OF IDAHO ADULTS AND 30% OF YOUTH ARE OVERWEIGHT OR OBESE, INCREASING RISK OF CHRONIC DISEASE. WHILE HEALTHY DIET AND REGULAR PHYSICAL ACTIVITY DECREASE ODDS OF OBESITY-RELATED DISEASES, ONE IN SIX CHILDREN AND 12.3% OF IDAHOANS OVERALL EXPERIENCE HUNGER OR FOOD INSECURITY DUE TO A LACK OF MONEY OR RESOURCES. STRATIFIED BY INCOME, IDAHOANS IN THE LOWEST INCOME BRACKETS REPORT THE HIGHEST PERCENTAGE OF INDIVIDUALS WITH LOW FRUIT AND VEGETABLE INTAKE AND LOW PHYSICAL ACTIVITY. NON-HISPANIC WHITES REPORT CONSUMING LESS FRUITS AND VEGETABLES COMPARED TO HISPANICS AND AMERICAN INDIAN/ALASKA NATIVES. IN 2015, IDAHO YOUTH REPORTED CONSUMING FRUITS AND VEGETABLES LESS OFTEN THAN IN 2013, WITH NON-HISPANIC WHITE ADOLESCENTS REPORTING CONSUMING FRUIT LESS OFTEN THAN HISPANIC WHITES AND HISPANIC ADOLESCENTS REPORTING CONSUMING VEGETABLES LESS OFTEN THAN NON-HISPANIC WHITES. WHILE IDAHO ADULTS REPORT BEING SLIGHTLY MORE ACTIVE THAN THE NATIONAL AVERAGE, THOSE IN THE LOWEST INCOME BRACKETS STILL REPORT LOW LEVELS OF PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, WITH HISPANICS AND AMERICAN INDIAN/ALASKA NATIVES REPORTING THE HIGHEST LEVELS OF PHYSICAL INACTIVITY. IDAHO YOUTH REPORT PHYSICAL ACTIVITY LEVELS SLIGHTLY ABOVE THE NATIONAL AVERAGE. HOWEVER, THE PERCENT OF ADOLESCENTS WHO PARTICIPATED IN DAILY PHYSICAL EDUCATION IN IDAHO WAS 21.4% IN 2013 COMPARED TO 29.8% NATIONWIDE. FURTHERMORE, AS OF 2012, IDAHO WAS NOT AMONG THE STATES THAT PROVIDE STATE GUIDANCE ON POLICY FOR JOINT USE OF SCHOOL FACILITIES, POLICIES FOR SCHOOL RECESS, OR POLICIES FOR WALKING/BIKING TO/FROM SCHOOL.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES (TARGET AUDIENCE): IDAHO EFNEP WILL CONTINUE REACHING LOW- INCOME FAMILIES WITH CHILDREN THROUGH RELATIONSHIPS WITH AND RECRUITING AT NUMEROUS COMMUNITY AGENCIES AND GROUPS THAT SERVE LIMITED RESOURCE FAMILIES. OUR GOALS CONTINUE FOR INCREASED REFERRALS AT HEALTH AND WELFARE OFFICES, PUBLIC HOUSING FACILITIES, SHELTERS FOR WOMEN AND CHILDREN AND EMERGENCY FEEDING SITES. LOW-INCOME YOUTH WILL BE REACHED THROUGH PARTNERSHIPS WITH LOCAL SCHOOL DISTRICTS, CHILDCARE PROVIDERS, EXTENSION 4-H, AND OTHER AGENCIES WHO SERVE YOUTH IN THE EFNEP COUNTIES.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: DELIVERY OF EFNEP IS ANTICIPATED TO BE IN FIFTEEN IDAHO COUNTIES; SPANNING ALL REGIONS OF THE STATE. PLACEMENT OF EFNEP IN THE SELECTED COUNTIES, ALIGNS THE PROGRAM IN THE AREAS WITH THE HIGHEST NUMBERS OF PEOPLE IN POVERTY IN IDAHO, THE LARGEST POPULATION BASES WITHIN THE FOUR IDAHO REGIONS, AND AREAS WITH PARTNERSHIP AND PROGRAMMING OPPORTUNITIES. IDAHO EFNEP NETWORKS WITH A VARIETY OF PARTNERS TO DELIVER CLASSES TO ADULTS AND YOUTH USING EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULA, INCLUDING GO, GLOW, GROW; CHOOSE HEALTH: FOOD, FUN, AND FITNESS; APPETITE FOR HEALTH; THE LEARNING KITCHEN YOUTH CURRICULUM; AND EFNEP FAMILIES EATING SMART, MOVING MORE.  IDAHO EFNEP HAS A ROBUST RELATIONSHIP WITH OTHER WESTERN REGION 1862 INSTITUTIONS, AND IS COLLABORATING WITH THE WESTERN REGION ON A YOUTH PARTICIPATION GOAL. EFNEP PROFESSIONALS  PARTICIPATE IN REGULAR CONFERENCE CALLS, REVIEW NATIONAL CURRICULA, AND ATTEND ANNUAL CONFERENCES. CHILD NUTRITION PROGRAMS ARE LOCATED WITHIN THE STATE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AND SUPPORT EFNEP YOUTH PROGRAMMING THROUGHOUT THE STATE. EFNEP IN IDAHO IS ALIGNED WITH THE SUPPLEMENTAL NUTRITION ASSISTANCE PROGRAM EDUCATION (SNAP-ED). THIS ALIGNMENT INCLUDES PROGRAM CHARACTERISTICS SUCH AS STANDARDIZING CURRICULA, ALIGNING TRAINING FOR STAFF AND COLLABORATING ON EVALUATION METHODS TO ALLOW ASSESSMENT OF COLLECTIVE IMPACTS OF NUTRITION EDUCATION FOR LIMITED RESOURCE AUDIENCES. LOCAL HEAD START PROGRAMS OPERATE INDEPENDENTLY AND HAVE BEEN LONG-TIME EFNEP PARTNERS. EFNEP IN IDAHO ALSO RECRUITS AND TEACHES CLIENTS AT MIGRANT HEAD START. THE UNIVERSITY OF IDAHO PARTNERS WITH THE STATE NUTRITION NETWORK – HEALTHY EATING ACTIVITY LIVING THROUGH WORK ON GRANTS. IDAHO EFNEP PLANS TO IMPROVE OUR RELATIONSHIP WITH THE STATE WIC PROGRAM THROUGH ESTABLISHING LINES OF COMMUNICATION. IN ADDITION, IDAHO EFNEP PLANS TO DEVELOP PARTNERSHIPS WITH LOCAL LIMITED INCOME HEALTH CARE OFFICES AS A RESOURCE FOR INCREASING OUR ADULT PARTICIPATION NUMBERS.  IDAHO EFNEP WILL CONTINUE TO INCORPORATE LOW, MEDIUM, AND HIGH-LEVEL TECHNOLOGY APPROACHES INTO OUR PROGRAMMING. WE WILL BE CONTINUING TO INCORPORATE LOW AND MEDIUM LEVEL TECHNOLOGY APPROACHES INTO OUR PROGRAMMING, INCLUDING: A) DEMONSTRATION OF TECHNOLOGY/SOCIAL MEDIA RESOURCES IN LESSONS B) INTEGRATING EXISTING APPS INTO LESSONS WHERE APPROPRIATE, C) SOCIAL MEDIA ENGAGEMENT TO REINFORCE LEARNING CONCEPTS (FACEBOOK INSTAGRAM, BLOG), D) SOCIAL MEDIA TO REACH AND RECRUIT NEW AUDIENCES (FACEBOOK AND INSTAGRAM) E) ONLINE MAKE-UP LESSONS, F) VIDEO CONTENT TO REINFORCE LEARNING CONCEPTS OR SUPPORT ONLINE SUCCESS STORIES.  IDAHO EFNEP WILL COORDINATE WITH SNAP-ED TO INCORPORATE PSE CHANGES WITH DIRECT NUTRITION EDUCATION AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY CLASSES THROUGH A SMALL SPACES GARDENING PROJECT. GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO EDUCATE SNAP-ELIGIBLE PARTICIPANTS ON GARDEN SEEDS BEING ELIGIBLE TO PURCHASE USING SNAP DOLLARS, TEACH BASIC GARDENING TECHNIQUES FOR CONTAINER GARDENS OR SMALL SPACE GARDENS, INCREASE FRUIT AND VEGETABLE CONSUMPTION, INCREASE LEVELS OF PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, AND REDUCE MENTAL STRESS.  MOVING FORWARD IN YEAR 2 OF THE PROJECT, IDAHO EFNEP WILL COLLABORATE EFFORTS WITH SNAP-ED TO IDENTIFY COMMUNITY PARTNERS AND LOCATIONS IN ORDER TO PILOT ONE PARTNERING SITE. IN ORDER TO WORK WITHIN THE CURRENT COMMUNITY SITES AND CREATE SUSTAINABLE GARDENS, THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO PROVIDE THE START-UP MATERIALS FOR GARDENING IN SMALL SPACES AND CONTAINER GARDENS. THIS TYPE OF LOW-MAINTENANCE GARDEN WILL BE IDEAL AT NUMEROUS LOCATIONS, INCLUDING LOW-INCOME HOUSING, SHELTERS, AND EMERGENCY FOOD ASSISTANCE SITES. THESE ARE ALSO LOCATIONS WHERE EFNEP ALREADY PROVIDES DIRECT NUTRITION EDUCATION AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY PROGRAMMING, THUS ADDING TO THE LAYERING OF PROGRAMMING WHICH IS NECESSARY TO PROMOTE GREATER AND SUSTAINED BEHAVIOR CHANGE. YEAR 3 WILL EXPAND TO PILOT A SITE IN EACH DISTRICT ACROSS THE STATE AND TO COLLABORATE WITH MASTER GARDENERS OR VOLUNTEERS IN LOCAL COMMUNITIES, WHO WILL PROVIDE EDUCATION ON GARDENING TECHNIQUES AND GUIDANCE ON MAINTAINING THE GARDENS AFTER THE INITIAL START-UP YEAR.  DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES 1. EFNEP PROGRAM DESCRIPTION  CHRONIC DISEASE AND FOOD INSECURITY DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECT LOW INCOME AND MINORITY AMERICAN POPULATIONS. RISK FACTORS FOR CHRONIC DISEASE IN MISSOURI INCLUDE OBESITY, POOR NUTRITION CHOICES AND LOW LEVELS OF PHYSICAL ACTIVITY. IN 2016, 31.6% OF PEOPLE OVER 18 WERE CONSIDERED OBESE WITH A BMI > 30. FIFTY-FIVE PERCENT OF MISSOURI WOMEN WERE CLASSIFIED AS OVERWEIGHT OR OBESE. OVERALL, 39.5% OF THE BLACK POPULATION WAS CONSIDERED OBESE. IN 2018, 29.8% OF BLACK ADULTS IN MISSOURI REPORTED FAIR TO POOR HEALTH COMPARED TO 20.4% OF ALL ADULTS. FIFTY-ONE PERCENT OF MISSOURI ADULTS REPORTED LESS THAN 150 MINUTES A WEEK OF PHYSICAL ACTIVITY (57% OF BLACKS). TWENTY-THREE PERCENT OF ADULTS REPORT 1 OR LESS SERVINGS OF VEGETABLES PER DAY WHILE 37.3% OF BLACKS REPORT 1 OR LESS SERVINGS OF VEGETABLES PER DAY ACCORDING TO THE BEHAVIORAL RISK FACTOR SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM (BRFSS). IN MISSOURI, 25% OF ADULTS 20 YEARS OR OLDER ARE INACTIVE COMPARED TO 20% NATIONWIDE.  HUNGER ATLAS 2019 DATA, POVERTY IS THE BEST SINGLE PREDICTOR OF FOOD INSECURITY, AND HUNGER. FOOD INSECURITY AND HUNGER STRONGLY CORRELATE TO LOWER EDUCATIONAL ACHIEVEMENT, JOB PERFORMANCE, AND UNEMPLOYMENT RATES. IN MISSOURI, OF THE 826,358 LIVING BELOW POVERTY LEVEL, ONLY 527, 054 SEEK HEALTHCARE FROM SAFETY NET PROVIDERS. NUTRITION AND WELLNESS CURRICULA IN SCHOOLS, HAS NOT BEEN UPDATED SINCE 2006.  DATA FROM FEEDING MISSOURI, THE COALITION OF MISSOURI FOOD BANKS, FINDS 14.2% OF MISSOURI HOUSEHOLDS ARE FOOD INSECURE. THIS IS CONSISTENT WITH USDA ESTIMATES WHICH IDENTIFY 5.3 % OF MISSOURI HOUSEHOLDS EXPERIENCING VERY LOW FOOD SECURITY WITH HUNGER WHICH TRANSLATES TO 400,000 MISSOURIANS EXPERIENCING HUNGER, MANY OF WHOM ARE CHILDREN. SNAP FIGURES INDICATE THAT 11.8% OF MISSOURIANS UTILIZE THIS BENEFIT, ALTHOUGH 63.2% ARE INCOME ELIGIBLE. SCOTT BAKER, DIRECTOR OF FEEDING MISSOURI INDICATED DEMAND AT MISSOURI FOOD BANKS HAS INCREASED BY 30- 100% STATE-WIDE FROM NOVEMBER 209 TO APRIL 2020. USDA FOOD ACCESS RESOURCE ATLAS, MISSOURI HAS 466 LOW-INCOME AREAS WITH GROCERY STORES HALF MILE TO 10 MILES FROM HOUSING AREAS. CHANGES IN THE FOOD DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM IN THE AFTERMATH OF COVID-19 WILL DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECT MINORITY AND CRITICALLY UNDERSERVED AMERICANS.  LU IDENTIFIES THE CRITICALLY UNDERSERVED, INCLUDING CHILDREN, SENIORS, AND YOUNG ADULTS IN ORDER TO DELIVER EDUCATION, TRAINING, AND SUPPORT. LUCE ADDRESSES THE DIVERSE NEEDS OF THE TARGET AUDIENCES WITH A VARIETY OF DIRECT TO CONSUMER EDUCATION AND TRAINING PROGRAMS THAT INCLUDE HEALTH AND NUTRITION PROGRAMS TO ADDRESS OBESITY AND OTHER CHRONIC CONDITIONS, PHYSICAL INACTIVITY, TRAINING AND PRACTICAL STRATEGIES FOR INCREASING ACCESS TO HEALTHY FOODS, AND RESOURCE UTILIZATION TO INTEGRATE GOOD NUTRITION AND COST-EFFECTIVE MEAL PLANNING INTO DAILY BEHAVIORS. LUCE EXTENSION STAFF SUPPORT AND PARTNER WITH STAKEHOLDERS TO DEVELOP COMMUNITY GARDENS, FOOD DISTRIBUTION PROGRAMS, AND SUMMER PROGRAMMING WHILE INTEGRATING NUTRITION EDUCATION AND FOOD SAFETY TRAINING TO IMPROVE FOOD ACCESS. SINCE 2013, MISSOURIANS WITH VERY LOW FOOD SECURITY HAS DECREASED FROM 6.7 TO 5.3%, DESPITE THE CONTINUED HIGH NUMBER OF LOW FOOD ACCESS AREAS. LU HAS RELIED ON A PERSONALIZED APPROACH WORKING WITH ADULTS, PREGNANT WOMEN, STUDENTS AND FAMILIES. WORKING FACE-TO-FACE TO BUILD SKILLS WERE HALTED BY THE PANDEMIC.  THE PANDEMIC, WITH ITS SHUTDOWN ORDERS AND STAY-AT-HOME ADVICE, ALTERED THE TRADITIONAL EFNEP MODEL.  THE PANDEMIC REVEALED A CRITICAL NEED FOR DIGITAL EQUITY. IT FORCED OUR HAND IN BUILDING OUT A VIRTUAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND ESTABLISHING A DIGITAL BOOT CAMP FOR OUR PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS TO GET THEM AS QUICKLY AND SAFELY AS POSSIBLE THE SKILLS AND EQUIPMENT THEY NEEDED TO PARTICIPATE IN VIRTUAL CLASSES.

EFNEP PROJECT ABSTRACT  SINCE 1969, THE FEDERALLY FUNDED EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) HAS BEEN TEACHING FAMILIES TO MAKE HEALTHIER FOOD CHOICES ON A LIMITED BUDGET, BE MORE ACTIVE, MANAGE THEIR FOOD RESOURCES, AND PREPARE AND HANDLE FOOD SAFELY. EFNEP HELPS LOW-INCOME FAMILIES AND CHILDREN GAIN THE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS NEEDED TO CHANGE CURRENT ATTITUDES AND BEHAVIORS WHEN IT COMES TO CHOOSING NUTRITIOUS FOODS AND IMPROVING THEIR HEALTH.  DATA ON THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN HEALTH AND POVERTY INDICATE THE NEED FOR NUTRITION EDUCATION. THE NORTH CAROLINA JUSTICE CENTER REPORTED IN DECEMBER 2019 THAT OVER 1.4 MILLION NORTH CAROLINIANS (14%) AND ONE OUT OF EVERY FIVE CHILDREN (20%) ARE LIVING IN POVERTY. EAT SMART MOVE MORE NC REPORTS 68% OF ADULTS AND 31% OF YOUTH (10-17) ARE OVERWEIGHT OR OBESE. FURTHERMORE, TWO KEY BEHAVIORS, VEGETABLE CONSUMPTION AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY ARE ALARMINGLY POOR IN OUR CHILDREN. 41% OF YOUTH CONSUME VEGETABLES LESS THAN ONE TIME PER DAYAND 78% DO NOT MEET THE RECOMMENDED 60 MINUTES OF PHYSICAL ACTIVITY PER DAY.  FAMILIES AND CHILDREN LIVING IN POVERTY SUFFER FROM HIGHER RATES OF OBESITY AND POOR NUTRITION LEADING TO OTHER HEALTH CONCERNS. RESEARCH SUGGESTS A STRONG CORRELATION BETWEEN POVERTY, FOOD INSECURITY, AND OBESITY AND A CORRELATION BETWEEN OBESITY AND CHRONIC DISEASE.  NOT ONLY DO THE STATISTICS DEMONSTRATE THE NEED FOR NUTRITION EDUCATION, BUT 9 LISTENING SESSIONS HELD BY EFNEP ACROSS THE STATE IN 2019 ALSO INDICATE THE VALUE AND INTEREST IN NUTRITION EDUCATION OF STAKEHOLDERS. THESE LISTENING SESSIONS RESULTED IN THREE RECOMMENDATIONS: 1) PARTNER WITH HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS; 2) PARTNER WITH COMMUNITIES TO CHANGE THE NUTRITION ENVIRONMENT: AND 3) GROW AND EXPAND THE PROGRAM SO THAT HEALTHY EATING AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY BECOME THE NORM FOR CHILDREN IN NC.  EFNEP, DELIVERED THROUGH NC COOPERATIVE EXTENSION AND OPERATED THROUGH NC STATE UNIVERSITY, IS COMMITTED TO IMPROVING THE HEALTH OF LOW-INCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH. EFNEP, THROUGH COOPERATIVE EXTENSION CENTERS THROUGHOUT THE STATE, EMPLOYS PEER EDUCATORS TO DELIVER A SERIES OF NUTRITION EDUCATION LESSONS USING EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULA. PEER EDUCATORS PARTNER WITH LOCAL COMMUNITY AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS TO RECRUIT AND ENROLL ELIGIBLE LOW-INCOME AUDIENCES. BY TEACHING PARTICIPANTS NEW KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS TO HELP THEM MAKE HEALTHY FOODS FOR THEIR FAMILIES WITHIN THEIR LIMITED INCOMES, EFNEP PROVIDES THE MOST VULNERABLE OF OUR CITIZENS WITH TOOLS TO ACHIEVE GOOD HEALTH ON A LIMITED BUDGET.

THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) IS DESIGNED TO ASSIST LIMITED-RESOURCE AUDIENCES IN GAINING THE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS NEEDED TO MAKE INFORMED CHOICES ABOUT FOOD, NUTRITION, AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY.  OUR EFNEP TARGET AUDIENCE IS LIMITED RESOURCE ADULTS RESPONSIBLE FOR PLANNING AND PREPARING THE FAMILY'S FOOD, EMPHASIZING HOUSEHOLDS WITH YOUNG CHILDREN. YOUTH AUDIENCES ARE LIMITED RESOURCE YOUTH LIVING IN RURAL OR URBAN AREAS AND SCHOOLS WHERE 50% OR MORE OF YOUTH RECEIVE FREE AND/OR REDUCED LUNCH. THIS PROGRAM IS DELIVERED BY PARAPROFESSIONALS USING A SERIES OF DIRECT NUTRITION EDUCATION LESSONS IN COLLABORATION WITH COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS THAT SERVE OUR TARGET AUDIENCE. OUR PROGRAM UTILIZES CURRICULA FOCUSING ON DIET QUALITY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, FOOD SAFETY, AND FOOD SECURITY. AFTER COMPLETING EFNEP, WE EXPECT PARTICIPANTS TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF THEIR DIETS, INCREASE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, IMPROVE FOOD SAFETY PRACTICES, AND INCREASE THEIR ACCESS TO FOOD. PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS GAIN KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND CONFIDENCE TO MAKE INFORMED CHOICES ABOUT LOW-COST, NUTRITIOUS FOODS, MANAGE THEIR FAMILY FOOD BUDGETS BETTER, AND BECOME SELF-SUFFICIENT.

THE PURPOSE OF THE FEDERAL AWARD IS FOR MONTANA STATE UNIVERSITY EXTENSION TO IMPLEMENT THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) TO IMPROVE DIET QUALITY, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, FOOD SAFETY, AND FOOD SECURITY AMONG MONTANANS WITH LOW INCOME WHO PARTICIPATE IN OR QUALIFY FOR MEANSTESTED PROGRAMS SUCH AS SNAP, WIC, AND FREE AND REDUCED SCHOOL MEALS.  EVIDENCEBASED, RESEARCHTESTED CURRICULA WILL BE USED BY MONTANA STATE UNIVERSITY EXTENSIONS EFNEP PROGRAM STAFF TO PROVIDE EDUCATION RELATED TO THE TOPICS ABOVE. CURRICULA ARE EITHER NINELESSONS OR SIXLESSONS IN LENGTH AND WILL BE PROVIDED TO QUALIFYING YOUTH, TEENS, AND ADULTS WITH CHILDREN OR ADULTS WHO MAY SOMEDAY HAVE CHILDREN. CURRICULUM TO BE USED INCLUDES EATING SMART BEING ACTIVE, YOUTH UNDERSTANDING MYPLATE, AND CHOOSE HEALTH: FOOD, FUN, AND FITNESS. CLASSES WILL BE PROVIDED INPERSON WITHIN MISSOULA COUNTY AND YELLOWSTONE COUNTY THOUGH PARTNERSHIP BUILDING WITH AGENCIES THAT WORK WITH THE TARGET AUDIENCE. EXAMPLES OF PARTNERSHIPS INCLUDE ADULT REHABILITATION CENTERS, EXTENSION OFFICES, FARMERS MARKETS, COMMUNITY CENTERS, SHELTERS, WIC PROGRAM SITES, HEAD START SITES, AND SCHOOLS. VIRTUAL CLASS SERIES WILL ALSO BE PROVIDED FOR ADULTS IN MONTANA WHO QUALIFY TO PARTICIPATE.  PRE AND POST SURVEYS WILL BE PROVIDED AT THE BEGINNING AND AGAIN AT THE END OF CLASS SERIES TO MEASURE THE PROGRAMS IMPACT ON BEHAVIORS. THE REPORTING SYSTEM WEBNEERS WILL BE USED TO DOCUMENT AND REPORT ON OUTCOMES. EXPECTED OUTCOMES FOR ADULTS WHO PARTICIPATE IN PROGRAMMING INCLUDE IMPROVEMENTS IN BEHAVIORS RELATED TO DIET QUALITY, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, FOOD SAFETY, AND FOOD SECURITY. EXPECTED OUTCOMES FOR YOUTH WHO PARTICIPATE IN PROGRAMMING INCLUDE IMPROVEMENTS IN KNOWLEDGE AND BEHAVIORS RELATED TO DIET QUALITY, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, AND FOOD SAFETY.  EDUCATION APPROACHES WILL BE LAYERED WITH POLICY, SYSTEMS, AND ENVIRONMENT APPROACHES TO PROMOTE AND INFLUENCE ACCESS TO HEALTHY FOODS AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY OPPORTUNITIES THROUGH PARTICIPATION ON STATEWIDE COALITIONS. COALITIONS INCLUDE MONTANA FARM TO SCHOOL LEADERSHIP TEAM, MONTANA FOOD SECURITY COUNCIL, AND MONTANA DOUBLE SNAP DOLLARS NETWORK. OUTCOMES EXPECTED FROM THIS WORK INCLUDES INCREASED PUBLICLY AVAILABLE EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS AND VIDEOS, INCREASED PARTNERSHIPS AND REFERRALS TO EFNEP PROGRAMMING, INCREASED ACCESS TO FOOD AVAILABLE TO EFNEPELIGIBLE ADULTS THROUGH THE DOUBLE SNAP DOLLARS PROGRAM.

WASHINGTON STATE UNIVERSITY EXTENSION EFNEP RFA FFY23 THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) IMPROVES THE DIETS AND FOOD- RELATED BEHAVIORS OF WASHINGTON FAMILIES AND YOUTH WITH LOW INCOMES IN CLARK, PIERCE, AND SPOKANE COUNTIES. THERE IS A NEED FOR NUTRITION EDUCATION IN EACH OF THESE COUNTIES, GIVEN THE POPULATION’S EXPERIENCE OF FOOD AND NUTRITION INSECURITY. DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC; 32% OF RESIDENTS IN SPOKANE COUNTY, 33% OF RESIDENTS IN PIERCE COUNTY, AND 35% OF RESIDENTS IN CLARK COUNTY EXPERIENCED LOW FOOD SECURITY IN 2021 (WA FOOD SURVEY). FOOD SECURITY WAS LOWEST AMONG VULNERABLE POPULATIONS SUCH AS PEOPLE IDENTIFYING AS BLACK, HISPANIC, AND AMERICAN INDIAN/ALASKA NATIVE. THESE RESIDENTS ARE AT RISK OF DEVELOPING DIET-RELATED DISEASES SUCH AS OBESITY, DIABETES, AND HEART DISEASE BECAUSE OF THEIR LACK OF ACCESS TO NUTRITIOUS AND ADEQUATE FOODS.  EFNEP PARTNERS WITH 124 COMMUNITY AGENCIES IN WASHINGTON TO DELIVER CURRICULUM THROUGH PRACTICAL DIRECT NUTRITION EDUCATION LESSONS. OUR ESTABLISHED COMMUNITY PARTNERS INCLUDE EARLY LEARNING CENTERS, SCHOOLS, INCOME-BASED HOUSING COMPLEXES, AND COMMUNITY CENTERS. OUR NUTRITION CLASSES ARE TAUGHT BY PEER EDUCATORS WHO BELONG TO THE COMMUNITIES THEY SERVE. WE USE EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULUM IN OUR ADULT AND YOUTH SERIES, INCLUDING EATING SMART•BEING ACTIVE; CHOOSE HEALTH FOOD, FUN, AND FITNESS (CHFFF); AND FOOD SMARTS. IN 2021, WASHINGTON EFNEP REACHED 387 ADULTS AND 689 YOUTH, AFFECTING OVER 1,501 FAMILY MEMBERS INDIRECTLY. NINETY-FOUR PERCENT OF THESE EFNEP PARTICIPANTS REPORTED INCOME AT OR BELOW 185% OF THE FEDERAL POVERTY LEVEL, EARNING $46,435 A YEAR OR LESS FOR A FAMILY OF FOUR.  EFNEP PARTICIPANTS REPORT IMPROVED BEHAVIORS IN DIET QUALITY, FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, AND FOOD SAFETY PRACTICES. IN 2021, 98% OF ADULTS AND 88% OF YOUTH REPORTED IMPROVED DIET QUALITY SUCH AS EATING MORE FRUITS AND VEGETABLES AND DRINKING FEWER SUGARY DRINKS. NINETY-SIX PERCENT OF ADULT PARTICIPANTS REPORTED MAKING POSITIVE BEHAVIOR CHANGES IN FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT WHICH INCLUDES PLANNING MEALS, MAKING A FOOD BUDGET, AND COMPARING FOOD PRICES. FAMILIES REPORTED SAVING $23 A MONTH ON THEIR FOOD COSTS, HELPING THEM LEAD HEALTHIER LIVES ON A BUDGET. IN 2021, 87% OF ADULTS AND 61% OF YOUTH REPORTED IMPROVED PHYSICAL ACTIVITY BEHAVIORS. THIS INCLUDES MEETING THE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY GUIDELINES FOR AMERICANS OF GETTING 150 MINUTES OF MODERATE ACTIVITY PER WEEK FOR ADULTS AND 60 MINUTES OF ACTIVE PLAY FOR YOUTH PER DAY. FOR FOOD SAFETY PRACTICES, 89% OF ADULTS AND 57% OF YOUTH REPORTED POSITIVE CHANGES SUCH AS PROPER HANDWASHING AND HOW TO COOK FOOD TO CORRECT TEMPERATURES. THESE BEHAVIOR CHANGES MAY REDUCE THE RISK OF DIET-RELATED DISEASES AND CONTRIBUTE TO A HEALTHIER LIFESTYLE FOR EFNEP PARTICIPANTS.  IN FISCAL YEAR 2023, WE WILL CONTINUE DIRECT EDUCATION TO ADULTS AND YOUTH WITH LOW-INCOMES AND GROW OUR COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS IN W ASHINGTON. IN ADDITION TO DIRECT EDUCATION, EFNEP SUPERVISORS ENGAGE IN POLICY, SYSTEMS, AND ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE ACTIVITIES SUCH AS PARTICIPATING IN COMMUNITY COALITIONS THAT ADDRESS FOOD SECURITY, INCREASING ACCESS TO LOCAL FOODS, AND PREVENTING CHRONIC DISEASES. EFNEP FUNDS IN THE NEXT FISCAL YEAR WILL SUPPORT NINE TO ELEVEN PARAPROFESSIONAL EDUCATORS AND THREE PROFESSIONAL STAFF. IN ADDITION TO STAFFING, THESE FUNDS WILL PROVIDE DOLLARS TO COVER SUPPLIES, MATERIALS, TRAINING, AND TRAVEL COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH DELIVERING EFNEP IN WASHINGTON.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS FUNDING IS TO INCREASE THE IMPACT OF NUTRITION EDUCATION DISSEMINATED TO LOW- INCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH IN THE 50 STATES, THE U.S. TERRITORIES, AND THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA. THE OVERALL GOAL OF THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) IS TO ASSIST LOW-INCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH IN ACQUIRING KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, ATTITUDES, AND CHANGED BEHAVIORS NECESSARY FOR NUTRITIONALLY SOUND DIETS AND TO CONTRIBUTE TO THEIR PERSONAL DE VELOPMENT AND IMPROVEMENT OF THE TOTAL FAMILY DIET AND NUTRITIONAL WELL-BEING.  INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES SHOULD EXPERIENCE IMPROVEMENTS IN FOUR CORE AREAS: A. DIET QUALITY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY—IMPROVED DIETS AND NUTRITIONAL AND PHYSICAL WELL-BEING THROUGH THE ADOPTION OF FEDERAL FOOD AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY RECOMMENDATIONS. B. FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT—INCREASED ABILITY TO BUY, GROW, OR OTHERWISE APPROPRIATELY OBTAIN, PREPARE, AND STORE FOOD THAT MEETS NUTRITIONAL NEEDS. C. FOOD SAFETY—IMPROVED HOUSEHOLD FOOD SAFETY AND SANITATION PRACTICES. D. FOOD SECURITY—INCREASED ABILITY TO GET FOOD DIRECTLY—AND FROM FOOD ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS WHERE NECESSARY—TO ENSURE HAVING ENOUGH HEALTHY FOOD TO EAT.  UVM EXTENSION WILL ACHIEVE THESE GOALS BY WORKING WITH STATEWIDE, REGIONAL, AND LOCAL PARTNERS TO RECRUIT PARTICIPANTS FOR EVIDENCE-BASED NUTRITION AND COOKING WORKSHOPS WITH PARAPROFESSIONAL EDUCATORS. EFNEP IS ALIGNED WITH NIFA’S STRATEGIC GOAL 4: MAKE SAFE, NUTRITIOUS FOOD AVAILABLE TO ALL AMERICANS; OBJECTIVE 4.1 INCREASE FOOD SECURITY THROUGH ASSISTANCE AND ACCESS TO NUTRITIOUS AND AFFORDABLE FOOD.

THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP), FUNDED BY THE USDAS NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF FOOD AND AGRICULTURE (NIFA), IS THE NATIONS FIRST NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM FOR LOWINCOME POPULATIONS. EFNEP EDUCATION IS CONDUCTED THROUGH THE NATIONS LANDGRANT INSTITUTIONS AND PROVIDES COMMUNITYBASED, HANDSON EDUCATION. THE AUBURN UNIVERSITY EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (AU EFNEP) TEACHES LIMITED RESOURCE YOUTH, FAMILIES, AND PREGNANT WOMEN THROUGH A SERIES OF LESSONS, PRIMARILY IN SMALL GROUPS, HOW TO IMPROVE DIETARY PRACTICES AND BECOME MORE EFFECTIVE MANAGERS OF THEIR AVAILABLE RESOURCES. THE OVERALL GOAL OF AU EFNEP IS TO HELP LIMITEDRESOURCE AUDIENCES TO GAIN KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS TO IMPROVE NUTRITION, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, AND OVERALL HEALTH. EFNEP EDUCATION IS PROVIDED BY EDUCATORS WHO COME FROM THE COMMUNITIES THEY SERVE. THIS IS BASED ON THE EFNEP PEERTOPEER EDUCATION MODEL THAT EMPHASIZES BUILDING CAPACITY WITHIN LOWINCOME COMMUNITIES. THE FOCUSAREAS OF EFNEP ARE: DIET QUALITY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY  FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT  FOOD SAFETY  FOOD SECURITY THE TARGET AUDIENCE FOR ENFEP EDUCATION INCLUDES LIMITED RESOURCE: FAMILIES  ADULTS WITH CHILDREN  YOUTH IN GRADES 512  PREGNANT WOMEN AND TEENS AU EFNEP REACHES THIS AUDIENCE THROUGH COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS, INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO:  SCHOOLS  HEALTHCARE  HOUSING SITES  COMMUNITY CENTERS  SOCIAL SERVICE AGENCIES  FAITHBASED INSTITUTIONS EFNEP IS DESIGNED TO TEACH THE HARD TO TEACH AND REACH THE HARD TO REACH. THIS MEANS EFNEP EDUCATORS MEET THEIR PARTICIPANTS WHERE THEY ARE, INCLUDING LOCAL GAS STATIONS, GROCERY STORES, AND PARKS!  DELIVERABLES/EXPECTED OUTCOMES  PROVIDE NUTRITION EDUCATION TO TARGET AUDIENCE  IMPROVE DIET QUALITY OF PARTICIPANTS  IMPROVE FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT SKILLS  IMPROVE KNOWLEDGE OF PREPARING AND STORING FOOD SAFELY  INCREASE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY  PROMOTE BREASTFEEDING AMONG LOWINCOME MOMSTOBE  HELP MOMSTOBE HAVE FULLTERM, NORMAL WEIGHT BABIES  MAINTAIN SERVICE TOTARGET AUDIENCE THROUGH HYBRID EDUCATION MODEL TO ACCOMPLISH THESE OUTCOMES, EVIDENCEBASED CURRICULA ARE UTILIZED IN A SERIES OF HANDSON, INTERACTIVE CLASSES, COVERING TOPICS INCLUDING, AMONG OTHERS:  MYPLATE  READING FOOD LABELS  PREPARING FOOD SAFELY  MAKING HEALTHY CHOICES WHEN DINING OUT CREATING A MEAL PLAN AND FOOD BUDGET  SELECTING HEALTHY FOOD OPTIONS  HOW TO HANDLE COMMON PREGNANCY DISCOMFORTS AND BARRIERS  BREASTFEEDING FEDERAL FUNDING SUPPORTS THE OPERATION AND IMPLEMENTATION OF NUTRITION EDUCATION ACROSS ALABAMA COUNTIES WITH HIGH RATES OF POVERTY, FOOD INSECURITY, AND OBESITY. THE MAJORITY OF FUNDS ARE SPENT ON THE SUPPORT OF EDUCATORS PROGRAMMING EFFORTS. THIS INCLUDES RECRUITMENT AND RETENTION OF PARTICIPANTS, EDUCATION, AND EVALUATION. CONTINUOUS TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES ARE ALSO PROVIDED TO EDUCATORS TO CONTINUE TO IMPROVE THEIR KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS. FREE NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAMMING PROVIDES BENEFITS TO THETARGET AUDIENCE NOW AND IN THE LONG TERM. PARTICIPANTS RECEIVE EDUCATION ON HEALTHY EATING, ACTIVE LIVING, AND ALSO RECEIVE MANY LESSON REINFORCEMENTS THAT ENCOURAGE THEM TO CONTINUE WHAT THEY LEARN IN CLASSES IN THEIR OWN HOMES. YOUTH WHO GAIN SKILLS AND KNOWLEDGE THROUGH AU EFNEP YOUTH PROGRAMMING ARE PREPARING FOR A LIFELONG IMPROVEMENT IN HEALTH AND OVERALL DIET QUALITY. THEY CAN BRING WHAT THEY LEARN HOME TO THEIR FAMILIES AND AFFECT CHANGE ACROSS GENERATIONS. ADDITIONALLY, EFNEP PROGRAMMING PROVIDES COMMUNITY BENEFITS. PERSONAL IMPROVEMENTS IN HEALTH BEHAVIORS ARE LARGELY AFFECTED BY OVERALL COMMUNITY HEALTH. OUR PROGRAM WORKS TO CHANGE INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIORS, SUCH AS HEALTHIER EATING HABITS AND BETTER RESOURCE MANAGEMENT. LIMITEDRESOURCE COMMUNITIES OFTEN LACK ACCESS TO HEALTHY FOOD OPTIONS AND EXPERIENCE A GREATER BURDEN OF DIETRELATED DISEASE. WORKING WITH A KNOWLEDGE OF THESE BARRIERS MEANS THAT PARTICIPANTS ARE EQUIPPED TO SHARE THE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS THEY HAVE GAINED WITH THEIR FRIENDS, FAMILY, AND COMMUNITY. THIS MEANS THAT THE REACH OF OUR PROGRAMMING GOES FAR BEYOND JUST THOSE WHO ARE PRESENT TO ALL WITH WHOM THEY INTERACT, WHO ALSO EXPERIENCE THESE COMMUNITYLEVEL BARRIERS. WE ALSO KNOW THAT HEALTHY INDIVIDUALS ARE MORE ENGAGED MEMBERS OF SOCIETY. BY IMPROVING INDIVIDUAL HEALTH BEHAVIORS, WE CAN IMPACT COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT.

PROJECT ABSTRACT  EFNEP FOCUSES ON FAMILIES THAT HAVE LOW INCOME WITH AN EMPHASIS ON PARENTS OR CAREGIVERS OF YOUNG CHILDREN. PEER EDUCATORS WHO REFLECT THE DIVERSITY OF EFNEP PARTICIPANTS AND HAVE EXPERIENCES THAT CAN HELP THEM RELATE TO FAMILIES WITH LIMITED INCOMES ARE SUPERVISED BY UW- MADISON EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS AND DELIVER EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS THROUGH A SERIES OF LESSONS TO PARENTS/CAREGIVERS AND YOUTH IN COLLABORATION WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS. WISCONSIN EFNEP LESSONS ARE DESIGNED AND TAUGHT AS LEARNER-CENTERED SESSIONS, AND THE PROGRAM AIMS TO ENSURE LESSONS ARE CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE FOR PARTICIPANTS.  WISCONSIN EFNEP SERVES LEARNERS IN SIX PREDOMINANTLY URBAN COUNTIES IN SOUTHERN AND SOUTHEASTERN WISCONSIN. LIMITED-INCOME NEIGHBORHOODS, APARTMENTS AND OTHER HOUSING OPTIONS WITH SUBSIDIZED RENTAL OPTIONS, PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION OPTIONS, AND LARGE CONCENTRATIONS OF ETHNICALLY AND RACIALLY DIVERSE FAMILIES COMBINE TO MAKE THESE URBAN COUNTIES THE BEST LOCATIONS FOR EFNEP IN WISCONSIN. THESE SIX COUNTIES—MILWAUKEE, DANE, RACINE, ROCK, KENOSHA, AND WAUKESHA RANK 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, AND 8 IN THE NUMBERS OF SNAP RECIPIENTS AMONG THE 72 COUNTIES OF WISCONSIN. EACH WISCONSIN EFNEP COUNTY DEVELOPS PARTNERSHIPS AND PROGRAMMING RELATIONSHIPS WITH AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS IN THEIR LOCAL COMMUNITIES.  AUDIENCES REACHED WITH WISCONSIN EFNEP EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING ARE FAMILIES WITH YOUNG CHILDREN THAT HAVE LOW INCOME AND YOUTH WITH LIMITED INCOME. WISCONSIN EFNEP STRIVES TO BALANCE ADULT AND YOUTH PROGRAM REACH. EFNEP ADULT PROGRAMMING IS TARGETED TO GROUPS OF PARENTS/CAREGIVERS OF CHILDREN OR WOMEN WHO ARE PREGNANT. YOUNGER CHILDREN ARE REACHED BY WISCONSIN EFNEP THROUGH ONE OF TWO VENUES, DEPENDING ON THE SPECIFIC OPPORTUNITIES AVAILABLE IN THE COUNTY: EITHER AT AFTER SCHOOL OR SUMMER PROGRAMMING FOR CHILDREN IN GRADES 3 THROUGH 5, OR IN SCHOOL CLASSROOMS FOR 1ST, 2ND, AND 5TH-GRADE CHILDREN. FROM 2020-2024, WISCONSIN EFNEP WILL INCREASINGLY TARGET YOUTH PROGRAMMING TOWARD OLDER YOUTH AND TEENS (GRADES 6-12). WISCONSIN EFNEP ALSO REACHES OLDER YOUTH (AGES 18-21) WITH DIVERSE COGNITIVE ABILITIES WITH CURRICULUM THAT IS APPROPRIATE FOR THIS GROUP’S DEVELOPMENTAL ABILITIES AS IT PROVIDES THEM WITH KNOWLEDGE ON NUTRITION AND FOOD SAFETY AND THE FOOD PREPARATION SKILLS TO SUPPORT THEIR TRANSITION TO INDEPENDENT LIVING.  WISCONSIN EFNEP DELIVERS NUTRITION EDUCATION THROUGH A SERIES OF CONTACTS WITH THE SAME LEARNERS OVER TIME USING EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULA CENTERED AROUND THE EFNEP CORE AREAS (DIET QUALITY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, FOOD SAFETY, AND FOOD SECURITY) AND APPLIES LEARNING PRINCIPLES PROVEN TO SUPPORT MEASURABLE BEHAVIOR CHANGE. WISCONSIN EFNEP HAS IDENTIFIED FIVE STRATEGIC PRIORITIES FOR THE 2020-2024 PERIOD: 1. ADULT IMPROVEMENT IN ONE OR MORE DIET QUALITY INDICATORS 2. ADULT IMPROVEMENT IN FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES 3. YOUTH IMPROVEMENT IN DIET QUALITY 4. INCREASE IN OLDER YOUTH AND TEEN PARTICIPANTS 5. IMPROVEDBALANCE IN ADULT TO YOUTH PROGRAMMING  WISCONSIN EFNEP WILL USE STRATEGIES IN SUPPORT OF ACHIEVING THESE PRIORITIES, INCLUDING INCORPORATION OF TECHNOLOGY TO IMPROVE PARTICIPANT RECRUITMENT AND RETENTION BY INCREASING CHOICE RELATED TO PREFERRED LEARNING STYLE AND MODE OF DELIVERY WHILE ALSO PROVIDING EVIDENCE- BASED CONTENT THROUGH LEARNER-CENTERED DELIVERY METHODS.

UNH EFNEP IS A FEDERALLY-FUNDED PROGRAM THROUGH THE UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF FOOD AND AGRICULTURE (USDA NIFA) THAT OFFERS NUTRITION EDUCATION TO LIMITED-RESOURCE FAMILIES AND CHILDREN. ADULT PARTICIPANTS MUST SATISFY AT LEAST ONE OF THE FOLLOWING: (1) RECEIVE OR BE ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE FEDERAL FOOD ASSISTANCE. (2) HAVE A MONTHLY HOUSEHOLD CASH INCOME THAT IS AT OR BELOW 185% OF THE FEDERAL POVERTY LEVEL. (3) BE A PREGNANT TEEN OR FOSTER YOUTH IN TRANSITION, REGARDLESS OF INCOME OR AGE. EFNEP PROMOTES GOOD NUTRITION AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AS A MEANS OF MAINTAINING A HEALTHY LIFESTYLE FREE OF CHRONIC DISEASE. OUR GOAL IS TO HELP ADULTS AND THEIR FAMILIES ESTABLISH <(>&<)> MAINTAIN HEALTHY EATING HABITS <(>&<)> PHYSICALLY ACTIVE LIFESTYLES. PARTICIPANTS LEARN TO: (1) PLAN NUTRITIOUS MEALS, (2) INCREASE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, (3) STRETCH THEIR FOOD DOLLARS, (4) PRACTICE SAFE FOOD HANDLING, AND (5) PREVENT OBESITY THROUGH HEALTHY LIFESTYLES. EFNEP NUTRITION EDUCATION OCCURS THROUGH A SERIES OF INTERACTIVE LESSONS LED BY A PARAPROFESSIONAL EDUCATOR FROM THE COMMUNITY THEY SERVE. CONSISTENTLY, ANNUAL DATA SHOWS THAT MORE THAN 90 PERCENT OF ADULTS AND 80 PERCENT OF YOUTH REPORT IMPROVED BEHAVIORS FOLLOWING EFNEP INVOLVEMENT. INDIVIDUAL AND FAMILY IMPROVEMENTS ARE SEEN FOR FOUR CORE AREAS: (1) DIET QUALITY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, (2) FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, (3) FOOD SAFETY, AND (4) FOOD SECURITY.

THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) AT THE UNIVERSITY OF DELAWARE PROVIDES HANDS ON NUTRITION EDUCATION THROUGH A SERIES OF LESSONS. THE PROGRAMS GOAL IS TO REACH LOW INCOME FAMILIES THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF DELAWARE AND TEACH THEM ABOUT HEALTHY EATING, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, USING THEIR FOOD RESOURCES WISELY AND FOOD SAFETY. IN FY2021, 212 ADULTS AND 549 CHILDREN WERE REACHED THROUGH THE EFFORTS OF THE PARAPROFESSIONALS WHO PROVIDE THE EDUCATION UNDER THE DIRECTION OF THE EFNEP COORDINATOR. EFNEP AT THE UNIVERSITY OF DELAWARE CONTINUES TO EXPLORE WAYS TO REACH THE TARGET POPULATION TO MAKE DELAWARE A HEALTHIER PLACE TO LIVE.

VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY NIFA PROJECT ABSTRACT OVERVIEW VIRGINIA COOPERATIVE EXTENSION (VCE) A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY (VT) AND VIRGINIA STATE UNIVERSITY (VSU) THE VIRGINIA AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION (VAES) AND THE VIRGINIA STATE UNIVERSITY AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH STATION (VSUARS) ENABLES PEOPLE TO IMPROVE THEIR LIVES THROUGH RESEARCH AND EDUCATION USING SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE FOCUSED ON THE ISSUES AND NEEDS OF THE CITIZENS OF VIRGINIA. AUDIENCES ARE INVOLVED IN DESIGNING IMPLEMENTING AND EVALUATING NEEDSDRIVEN PROGRAMS. VCE VAES AND VSUARS ARE DYNAMIC ORGANIZATIONS WHICH STIMULATE POSITIVE PERSONAL AND SOCIETAL CHANGE LEADING TO MORE PRODUCTIVE LIVES FAMILIES FARMS AND FORESTS AS WELL AS A BETTER ENVIRONMENT IN URBAN AND RURAL COMMUNITIES.
