UTAH STATE UNIVERSITY USES EXTENSION CAPACITY FUNDS TO SUPPORT VARIOUS PROGRAMS. PROGRAMMATIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE WORKSHOPS, DEMONSTRATIONS, E-COURSES, IN-PERSON CLASSES, AS WELL AS THE DEVELOPMENT OF PRINT AND ELECTRONIC RESOURCES. THESE PROGRAMS, AND ASSOCIATED DELIVERABLES, OUTCOMES, AND BENEFICIARIES, INCLUDE:  UTAH 4-H: POSITIVE YOUTH DEVELOPMENT  4 H PROGRAMS ARE GROUNDED IN THE BELIEF THAT YOUTH LEARN BEST BY DOING. KIDS AND TEENS COMPLETE HANDS-ON PROJECTS IN MANY EDUCATIONAL AREAS INCLUDING SCIENCE, HEALTH, AGRICULTURE, AND CIVIC ENGAGEMENT. 4-H ALLOWS YOUTH TO ENGAGE IN THEIR EDUCATIONAL INTERESTS IN A POSITIVE ENVIRONMENT WHERE THEY RECEIVE GUIDANCE FROM ADULT MENTORS, WHILE ALSO BEING ENCOURAGED TO TAKE ON PROACTIVE LEADERSHIP ROLES. KIDS CAN CONCENTRATE ON ONE FOCUS AREA OR THEY CAN TRY A VARIETY OF PROGRAMS THROUGHOUT THEIR 4 H EXPERIENCE. MAJOR EDUCATIONAL AREAS IN UTAH 4-H AT UTAH STATE UNIVERSITY (USU) EXTENSION INCLUDE 4-H STEM, 4-H HEALTHY LIVING, AND CIVIC ENGAGEMENT.  4-H STEM AND AGRICULTURE PROGRAMS EQUIP YOUNG PEOPLE WITH THE SKILLS THEY NEED TO FIND THEIR PASSION AND SUCCEED IN A CAREER. FOCUS AREAS INCLUDE COMPUTER SCIENCE, ROBOTICS, ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE, AGRI-SCIENCE, FINANCIAL LITERACY, ENTREPRENEURSHIP, AND VETERINARY SCIENCE. 4-H HEALTHY LIVING EMPOWERS YOUTH TO BE HEALTHY – BODY AND MIND – WITH THE SKILLS TO MAKE HEALTHY DECISIONS AND LEAD HEALTHY LIFESTYLES. HAVING THE CONFIDENCE AND SKILLS TO LEAD HEALTHY LIFESTYLES NOT ONLY IMPROVES OVERALL WELL-BEING BUT ALSO ENABLES YOUTH TO TACKLE LIFE’S CHALLENGES TODAY AND BECOME LEADERS IN THEIR LIVES, CAREERS, AND COMMUNITIES AS THEY GROW INTO RESPONSIBLE ADULTHOOD. 4-H CIVIC ENGAGEMENT EMPOWERS YOUTH TO BE WELL-INFORMED CITIZENS WHO ARE ACTIVELY ENGAGED IN THEIR COMMUNITIES AND THE WORLD.  RESEARCH SHOWS THAT THE 4-H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM PLAYS A SPECIAL AND VITAL ROLE IN THE LIVES OF AMERICA’S YOUNG PEOPLE. YOUTH CAN THRIVE WHEN PRESENTED WITH RESOURCES FOR HEALTHY DEVELOPMENT FOUND IN FAMILIES, SCHOOLS, AND COMMUNITIES - REGARDLESS OF THEIR BACKGROUND, SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS, RACE, AND GENDER. 4-H PROGRAMS LAUNCH YOUNG PEOPLE INTO HEALTHY AND PRODUCTIVE LIVES. THE LONG-TERM GOALS OF 4-H UTAH ARE TO (A) FACILITATE POSITIVE YOUTH DEVELOPMENT THROUGH EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES THAT FOSTER YOUTH COMPETENCE, CHARACTER, CONNECTION, CARING, CONFIDENCE, AND CONTRIBUTION, AND (B) EMPOWER YOUTH TO PURSUE THEIR PASSION FOR A SUCCESSFUL CAREER AND HEALTHY LIFE.  FACULTY INVOLVED IN UTAH 4-H ACTIVELY CONDUCTS RESEARCH IN EARLY EDUCATION, POSITIVE YOUTH DEVELOPMENT, CIVIC ENGAGEMENT, YOUTH LEAD ERSHIP, AND CAREER READINESS. ALL RESEARCH IS INCORPORATED INTO EXTENSION ACTIVITIES TO INFORM BEST PRACTICES, BEHAVIOR CHANGE, AND EVIDENCE- BASED CURRICULA DEVELOPMENT. MAJOR ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED IN UTAH 4-H INCLUDE FIELD DAYS, AFTERSCHOOL PROGRAMMING, AND PROJECTS FOCUSING ON TOPICS RELATED TO AGRICULTURE, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND ANIMAL SCIENCE, ART AND CRAFTS, CIVIC ENGAGEMENT, FAMILY ANDCONSUMER SCIENCES, HEALTHY LIVING, AND SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, AND MATHEMATICS (STEM).   AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES: AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTIVITY  UTAH HAS OVER 18,000 FARMS AND RANCHES SPANNING 11 MILLION ACRES, WHICH GENERATE MORE THAN $21 BILLION IN TOTAL ECONOMIC OUTPUT (AFTER ADJUSTING FOR THE MULTIPLIER EFFECT). WHILE IT IS TRUE THAT UTAH BECOMES MORE URBANIZED EACH YEAR, IT IS ALSO TRUE THAT AGRICULTURE CONTINUES TO PLAY A VITAL PART IN OUR STATE. AS THE POPULATION OF UTAH AND THE UNITED STATES CONTINUES TO GROW, FOOD PRODUCTION IS MORE IMPORTANT THAN EVER BEFORE. UTAH STATE UNIVERSITY (USU) EXTENSION HAS LED THE WAY FOR 105 YEARS IN PROVIDING NON-BIASED, RESEARCH-BASED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PRODUCERS AND THE UTAH AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRY. USU EXTENSION HAS NATIONALLY AND INTERNATIONALLY RECOGNIZED FACULTY WITH EXPERTISE IN ALL AREAS OF AGRICULTURE PRODUCTION AND SCIENCE. OUR ON-CAMPUS AND COUNTY FACULTY CONDUCT CUTTING-EDGE RESEARCH THAT IS DISSEMINATED TO PRODUCERS AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS THROUGH METHODS SUCH AS FIELD DAYS, WORKSHOPS, PRINTED AND ONLINE PUBLICATIONS, CLASSES, ONLINE COURSES, AND SOCIAL MEDIA OUTLETS.  EXTENSION CONTINUES TO MEET THE NEEDS OF TRADITIONAL AGRICULTURE WHILE EVOLVING TO MEET THE NEEDS OF DEVELOPING AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRIES. AS WE FOCUS OUR EFFORTS ON PERSISTENT AND EMERGING NEEDS, WE RECOGNIZE UTAH IS THE SECOND DRIEST STATE IN THE NATION, SO IRRIGATION EFFICIENCY, WATER CONSERVATION, AND IMPROVED WATER-EFFICIENT CROP VARIETIES CONTINUE TO BE FOCUS AREAS FOR OUR FACULTY AND RESEARCHERS. WITH URBAN AND SMALL FARMS BECOMING MORE POPULAR, EXTENSION FACULTY ARE WORKING WITH PRODUCERS TO FIND INNOVATIVE WAYS TO PRODUCE FOOD ON MINIMAL ACREAGE. THE LONG-TERM GOALS OF THE AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCE (AG/NR) PROGRAM ARE TO (A) INCREASE THE PRODUCTIVITY AND EFFICIENCY OF UTAH AGRICULTURAL OPERATIONS, AND (B) PROMOTE SUSTAINABLE NATURAL RESOURCE USE THROUGH RELEVANT EDUCATION ON CONSERVATION PRACTICES.  FACULTY INVOLVED IN AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCE PROGRAM ACTIVELY CONDUCTS RESEARCH ON A WIDE VARIETY OF TOPICS INCLUDING CROP AND LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION, RANGELAND MANAGEMENT, FORESTRY, AND AGRICULTURAL ECONOMICS. ALL RESEARCH IS INCORPORATED INTO EXTENSION ACTIVITIES TO INFORM BEST PRACTICES, BEHAVIOR CHANGE, AND EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULA DEVELOPMENT. MAJOR ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED IN AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES INCLUDE EDUCATIONAL WORKSHOPS, DEMONSTRATIONS, CONFERENCES, FIELD VISITS, AND CONSULTATIONS ON TOPICS RELATED TO (BUT NOT LIMITED TO) AGRONOMY, LIVESTOCK SCIENCE, DROUGHT, FORESTRY, RANGELAND, AGRICULTURAL ECONOMICS, MENTAL HEALTH IN AGRICULTURE, PEST MANAGEMENT, AND WETLANDS.  CLIMATE CHANGE AND MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES  THE WESTERN U.S. CONTAINS STATES WITH VAST TRACTS OF PUBLIC LAND SURROUNDING SMALLER AREAS THAT ARE PRIVATELY OWNED, MOSTLY ADJACENT TO WATER. THE NATURAL RESOURCE BASE OF ANY ECONOMY IS CRITICALLY IMPORTANT TO THE ECONOMIC AND AESTHETIC ENVIRONMENTS FOR THATAREA. CHANGES IN THE NATURAL RESOURCE BASE BRING VARIATION IN THE UNDERLYING ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL STRUCTURE. CRITICAL ISSUES AFFECTING NATURAL RESOURCE CHARACTERISTICS ARE FOUND IN SOILS, WATER, RANGE, FOREST, ANIMALS, AND AIR RESOURCES. THE PROPER AND EFFICIENT MANAGEMENT OF THESE RESOURCES IS A PRIMARY CONCERN, PARTICULARLY FOR ENVIRONMENTS AS VARIED AND UNIQUE AS IN THE WEST.  THIS CRITICAL ISSUE INVOLVES IMPROVING DECISION-MAKING RELATIVE TO ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP IN AN ECONOMIC, SOCIAL, AND BIOLOGICAL SENSE. USU EXTENSION ADDRESSES THE CRITICAL ISSUE OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND THE MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES THROUGH THE SUSTAINABLE NATURAL RESOURCES PROGRAM. THE GOAL OF THIS EXTENSION PROGRAM IS TO PROVIDE NON-FORMAL EDUCATION TO RESIDENTS, STAKEHOLDERS, AND ORGANIZATIONS TO PROMOTE, FACILITATE, AND STRENGTHEN ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP  AND SUSTAINABLE NATURAL RESOURCE USE IN UTAH. THIS PROJECT PRIMARILY FOCUSES ON FOREST MANAGEMENT, WATER CONSERVATION, AND STEWARDSHIP OF PUBLICLANDS. THE PROJECT TARGETS ADULTS AND YOUTH, AND THE DESIRED LONG-TERM OUTCOMES ARE TO (A) EQUIP RESIDENTS WITH THE COMPETENCY TO EFFECTIVELY ENGAGE IN NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND PRESERVATION, AND (B) FACILITATE PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND PUBLIC AND PRIVATE STAKEHOLDERS TO STRENGTHEN NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND ENABLE SUSTAINABLE RESOURCE USE.  FACULTY INVOLVED IN THE SUSTAINABLE NATURAL RESOURCES PROGRAM ACTIVELY CONDUCTS RESEARCH ON A WIDE VARIETY OF TOPICS INCLUDING WATER MANAGEMENT, IRRIGATION TECHNOLOGIES, AND TOURISM. ALL RESEARCH IS INCORPORATED INTO EXTENSION ACTIVITIES TO INFORM BEST PRACTICES, BEHAVIOR CHANGE, AND EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULA DEVELOPMENT. MAJOR ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED IN CLIMATE CHANGE AND MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES INCLUDE EDUCATIONAL WORKSHOPS, DEMONSTRATIONS, CONFERENCES, AND FIELD VISITS ON TOPICS RELATED TO WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY, CLIMATE SCIENCE, BIOMASS, PERMACULTURE, OUTDOOR RECREATION, AND RESOURCE CONSERVATION.FOOD SAFETY  WITH A LARGE VARIETY OF FOOD PRODUCTS MOVING THROUGH COMPLEX DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS, FOOD SAFETY IS A CRITICAL ISSUE FOR PRODUCERS, PR OCESSORS, DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS, AND THE FINAL CONSUMER. FOODBORNE ILLNESS IS A MAJOR CAUSE OF DEATH, CLAIMING THE LIVES OF OUR MOST VULNERABLE POPULATIONS; THE ELDERLY, YOUNG, PREGNANT WOMEN, PEOPLE WITH IMPAIRED IMMUNE FUNCTION, AND THE CHRONICALLY ILL. IMPROPER FOOD HANDLING AND PREPARATION OF FOOD IN FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS AND THE HOME CONTRIBUTE TO FOOD-BORNE ILLNESSES. THE PUBLIC FOOD SAFETY EDUCATION PROGRAM AT USU EXTENSION AIMS TO PROVIDE RELEVANT RESEARCH-BASED EDUCATION TO UTAH RESIDENTS ON BEST PRACTICES TO REDUCE THE RISK OF FOOD CONTAMINATION AND FOODBORNE ILLNESSES. THE MAJOR FOCUS AREAS OF THIS PROGRAM ARE FOOD PRESERVATION TECHNIQUES AND HOUSEHOLD FOOD STORAGE.  THE DESIRED LONG-TERM OUTCOMES OF THE PUBLIC FOOD SAFETY EDUCATION PROGRAM ARE TO (A) REDUCE THE OCCURRENCES OF FOODBORNE ILLNESSES IN UTAH THROUGH RESEARCH-BASED EDUCATION ON FOOD SAFETY PRACTICES IN HOUSEHOLDS, AND (B) TO REDUCE FOOD CONTAMINATION IN THE FOOD SUPPLY CHAIN BY PROVIDING RELEVANT EDUCATION ON BEST PRACTICES TO PROCESSORS AND PRODUCERS. MAJOR ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED IN FOOD SAFETY INCLUDE EDUCATIONAL WORKSHOPS, CONSULTATIONS, AND (VIRTUAL AND FACE-TO- FACE) DEMONSTRATIONS TARGETED AT RESIDENTS AND SMALL BUSINESSES ON FOOD PRESERVATION, CANNING, PRESSURE TESTING, FOOD PRODUCT TESTING, AND FOODBORNE ILLNESSES.  NUTRITION AND HEALTH  THERE IS A NEED TO PROVIDE EFFECTIVE NUTRITION INFORMATION AND EDUCATION TO THE PUBLIC TO ENABLE CONSUMERS TO MAKE WISE DIETARY CHOICES. AS THE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN DIET, PHYSICAL AND MENTAL HEALTH, AND DISEASE PREVENTION BECOME CLEARER, THE PROMOTION OF HEALTHY EATING BEHAVIORS AND LIFESTYLES FOR BOTH YOUTH AND ADULTS HAS RECEIVED INCREASED ATTENTION IN RECENT YEARS. WITH HIGH LEVELS OF OBESITY, CHRONIC DISEASE, AND POOR DIETARY HABITS, THERE IS A NEED FOR NON-FORMAL NUTRITION EDUCATION THAT ADDRESSES INDIVIDUAL AND FAMILY HEALTH AND WELLNESS. THE PUBLIC NUTRITION AND HEALTH EDUCATION PROGRAM AT USU EXTENSION SEEKS TO DECREASE THE INCIDENCES OF CHRONIC DISEASES AND OTHER NUTRITION-RELATED HEALTH ISSUES AMONG RESIDENTS THROUGH NON-FORMAL NUTRITION EDUCATION.  THE PRIORITIES FOR THIS PROGRAM ARE TO EXPAND NUTRITIONAL RESEARCH AND EDUCATION, AND TO PROMOTE HEALTHY DIETARY HABITS. THEREFORE, THE DESIRED LONG-TERM OUTCOMES ARE THE PUBLIC NUTRITION AND HEALTH EDUCATION PROGRAM ARE TO (A) EMPOWER RESIDENTS TO MAKE HEALTHY FOOD CHOICES AND IMPROVE THEIR NUTRITIONAL INTAKE, AND (B) REDUCE THE ECONOMIC COST OF CHRONIC DISEASES IN UTAH THROUGH ONGOING NUTRITION EDUCATION TO YOUTH AND ADULTS.  FACULTY INVOLVED IN PUBLIC NUTRITION AND HEALTH EDUCATION PROGRAM ACTIVELY CONDUCTS RESEARCH ON A WIDE VARIETY OF TOPICS INCLUDING N UTRITION, OBESITY, CHRONIC DISEASES, AND FOOD SCIENCE. RESEARCH IS INCORPORATED INTO EXTENSION ACTIVITIES TO INFORM BEST PRACTICES, BEHAVIOR CHANGE, AND EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULA DEVELOPMENT. MAJOR ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED IN NUTRITION AND HEALTH INCLUDE EDUCATIONAL WORKSHOPS AND CONSULTATIONS ON TOPICS RELATED TO CHRONIC DISEASES, NUTRITION EDUCATION, HEALTHY AND AFFORDABLE RECIPES, DIET BEHAVIOR CHANGES, AND YOUTH NUTRITION.  COMMUNITY RESILIENCE  UTAH CONSISTS OF MANY RURAL COUNTIES SPREAD OUT OVER VAST AREAS OF LAND, AND ONLY A FEW URBAN COUNTIES IN CENTRALIZED LOCATIONS. AS A RESULT, THERE IS AN INCREASING DISPARITY IN ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES FOR RESIDENTS IN RURAL COUNTIES. THE MAJORITY OF CURRENT AND NEW JOBS ARE LOCATED ALONG THE URBAN COUNTIES IN THE WASATCH FRONT, INCLUDING JOBS IN THE GROWING TECHNOLOGY SECTOR IN UTAH'S "SILICON SLOPES." IN CONTRAST, RURAL RESIDENTS STRUGGLE TO FIND WELL-PAYING AND STABLE WORK IN THEIR COMMUNITIES AND ARE OFTEN FACED WITH THE DECISION TO RELOCATE TO URBAN CENTERS. THIS EXACERBATES THE PROBLEM OF ECONOMIC DEPRESSION IN RURAL COUNTIES SINCE RURAL-URBAN MIGRATION LEADS TO LOW PRODUCTIVITY IN THESE COUNTIES. THERE IS A NEED TO SUPPORT RURAL COMMUNITIES THROUGH COMMUNITY AND CAPACITY-BUILDING INITIATIVES.  IN ADDITION TO ECONOMIC HARDSHIPS, INDIVIDUALS IN RURAL COUNTIES SUFFER FROM RELATIVELY HIGH RATES OF SUBSTANCE ABUSE DISORDERS. THE RATES OF OPIOID OVERDOSES IN RURAL UTAH HAVE CONSISTENTLY BEEN HIGHER THAN THE NATIONAL AVERAGE. UTAH HAD EIGHT (8) OUT OF 10 ADULT OVERDOSE DEATHS EACH WEEK DUE TO OPIOIDS IN 2019, AND HALF OF THOSE WERE SPECIFICALLY DUE TO PRESCRIPTION OPIOIDS (UTAH DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH [UDOH] INDICATOR-BASED SYSTEM FOR PUBLIC HEALTH [IBIS], 2021). IN 2020, THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC CREATED ADDITIONAL CHALLENGES, INCLUDING INCREASES IN OPIOID-RELATED DEATHS DUE TO FENTANYL.  THEREFORE, THE AIM OF THE VIBRANT COMMUNITIES PROGRAM AT USU EXTENSION IS TO STRENGTHEN COMMUNITIES ACROSS UTAH THROUGH FACILITATED COMMUNITY-FOCUSED COALITIONS AND PARTNERSHIPS, ENTREPRENEURSHIP EDUCATION, AND STRATEGIC INITIATIVES TO FACILITATE ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL WELL-BEING. THE DESIRED LONG-TERM OUTCOMES OF THE VIBRANT COMMUNITIES PROGRAM ARE TO (A) CONNECT RURAL COMMUNITIES TO ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES IN URBAN CENTERS THROUGH INNOVATIVE WORKPLACE PRACTICES (E.G., REMOTE WORKING ARRANGEMENTS), AND (B) FACILITATE EDUCATIONAL INTERVENTIONS, AND COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS AND COALITIONS TO REDUCE SUBSTANCE ABUSE DISORDERS IN RURAL COUNTIES. MAJOR ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED IN COMMUNITY RESILIENCE INCLUDE EDUCATIONAL WORKSHOPS AND INTERVENTIONS ON TOPICS RELATED TO RURAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT, RURAL EMPLOYMENT, REMOTE WORKING, BUILDING COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS AND COALITIONS, AND TRIBAL INITIATIVES.  INDIVIDUAL AND FAMILY RESOURCE MANAGEMENT  UTAH IS IN THE TOP 5 U.S. STATES WITH BANKRUPTCY, AND THERE IS A NEED FOR OUTREACH EDUCATION TO FACILITATE IMPROVED FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AMONG INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES. BECAUSE OF UTAH'S TYPICALLY LARGER FAMILY SIZE, THE AMOUNT OF INCOME AVAILABLE FOR BASIC FAMILY NEEDS SLIPS BELOW THE MEAN FOR THE REST OF THE UNITED STATES. UTAH FAMILIES ALREADY FACE HIGH DEBT LOADS LEADING TO BANKRUPTCY, LOW SAVINGS, AND A LACK OF LIQUID ASSETS. HENCE, THE MAJOR GOAL OF THIS PLANNED EXTENSION PROGRAM IS TO ENHANCE INDIVIDUAL AND FAMILY RESOURCE MANAGEMENT (FRM).  FRM, WHICH RELATES TO FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT, ALSO TIES TO OTHER ASPECTS OF FAMILY HEALTH, SUCH AS HEALTHY MARITAL AND FAMILY RELATIONSHIPS, AND MENTAL HEALTH AND WELLBEING. AS A BROAD PROGRAM AREA, THE TARGET AUDIENCE FOR THIS PROGRAM INCLUDES YOUTH, ADULTS, AND FAMILIES IN UTAH. DESIRED LONG-TERM OUTCOMES ARE TO; (A) STRENGTHEN FAMILY RELATIONSHIPS, AND (B) IMPROVE THE ECONOMIC WELL-BEING OF INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES.  FACULTY INVOLVED IN THIS PROGRAM ACTIVELY CONDUCT RESEARCH IN FAMILY RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, MENTAL HEALTH AND WELLBEING, RELATIONSHIPS, AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT. THE RESEARCH IS INCORPORATED INTO EXTENSION ACTIVITIES TO INFORM BEST PRACTICES, BEHAVIOR CHANGE, AND EVIDENCE- BASED CURRICULA DEVELOPMENT. MAJOR ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED IN COMMUNITY RESILIENCE INCLUDE EDUCATIONAL WORKSHOPS, CONFERENCES, AND CONSULTATIONS ON TOPICS RELATED TO INDIVIDUAL AND FAMILY FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT, HOMEOWNER AND HOMEBUYER EDUCATION, FAMILY RELATIONSHIPS, COUPLES, AND FAMILY RELATIONSHIPS, AND MENTAL WELLNESS.

THE MISSION OF THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) IN NEW MEXICO IS TO “ASSIST LIMITED RESOURCE AUDIENCES IN ACQUIRING THE KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, ATTITUDES, AND CHANGED BEHAVIOR NECESSARY FOR NUTRITIONALLY SOUND DIETS”, AND TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OF THOSE AUDIENCES AS WELL AS IMPROVING THE NUTRITIONAL WELL-BEING OF THE TOTAL FAMILY.  NEW MEXICO IS A SOUTHWESTERN STATE IN WHICH NEARLY HALF THE POPULATION IS HISPANIC. 38.86% OF NEW MEXICANS LIVE AT OR BELOW 185% OF THE FEDERAL POVERTY LEVEL, AND 71.32% OF K-12 STUDENTS IN THE STATE ARE ELIGIBLE FOR FREE OR REDUCED PRICE LUNCHES. THESE POVERTY INDICATORS ARE 9% AND 22% OVER THE NATIONAL AVERAGE, RESPECTIVELY. IN NEW MEXICO EFNEP, WE PLAN TO HELP OUR PARTICIPANTS IMPROVE IN FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND INCREASE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY IN ADULTS. NEW MEXICO EFNEP ALSO WORKS WITH YOUTH, IN GRADES 3-10 TO INCREASE FRUIT AND VEGETABLE CONSUMPTION AND INCREASE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY.  OVER A THIRD OF NEW MEXICANSARE OVERWEIGHT OR OBESE. IN THE POPULATION ELIGIBLE FOR THE SUPPLEMENTAL NUTRITION ASSISTANCE PROGRAM (SNAP) EDUCATIONAL COMPONENT, ONLY ABOUT 36% INTAKE ADEQUATE AMOUNTS OF FRUITS AND VEGETABLES EVERY DAY. ONLY 29% OF CHILDREN IN THIS POPULATION HAVE 2 OR FEWER HOURS OF SCREENTIME PER DAY.  NEW MEXICO IS A UNIQUE STATE IN THE NATION WITH MANY CHALLENGES TO IMPROVING THE HEALTH AND DIET QUALITY OF ITS SUBSTANTIAL LOW-INCOME POPULATION. THESE UNDERSERVED FAMILIES BENEFIT IMMENSELY FROM THE PRESENCE OF EFNEP, WHICH PROVIDES ANNUAL IMPROVEMENTS IN KNOWLEDGE AND BEHAVIORS CONCERNING THE TOPICS OF DIET QUALITY AND FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT. 91% OF EFNEP PARTICIPANTS IN NEW MEXICO SHOW IMPROVEMENT IN ONE OR MORE DIET QUALITY INDICATORS AFTER TAKING CLASSES, AND 70% SHOW IMPROVEMENT IN ONE OR MORE BEHAVIORS SUCH AS COOKING DINNER AT HOME, PLANNING MEALS BEFORE SHOPPING, AND COMPARING FOOD PRICES TO MAKE THE MOST OF A LIMITED BUDGET.

MISSISSIPPI IS RANKED ONE (1) OUT OF FIFTY-ONE (51) STATES AND THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA FOR CHILDHOOD OBESITY AGES 10 – 17. THE DATA FOR THIS SPECIFIC AGE GROUP IS 25.4% OVERWEIGHT. ADULTS IN MISSISSIPPI ALSO RANK NUMBER ONE (1) OUT OF FIFTY-ONE (51) STATES IN OBESETY WITH A TOTAL OF 39.5% OVERWEIGHT. HEALTH RELATED ISSUES FOR MISSISSIPPIANS OVERWEIGHT INCLUDE DIABETES, HYPERTENSION, HEART DISEASE, ARTHRITIS, AND OBESITY RELATED CANCERS SUCH AS COLON AND RECTAL. MISSISSIPPI RANKED NUMBER 1 IN THE NATION FOR OVERALL DIABETES PREVALENCE WITH 1,083 DEATHS IN 2016. THERE ARE ROUGHLY 371,662 MISSISSIPPIANS LIVING WITH DIABETES AND OF THAT NUMBER 79,000 ARE UNAWARE THAT THEY HAVE DIABETES. FURTHERMORE, THERE ARE 810,000 PREDIABETICS IN THIS STATE. MISSISSIPPI IS ALSO RANKED NUMBER FIFTY-ONE (51) IN 2017 FOR THE HIGHEST POVERTY. FOR HYPERTENSION MISSISSIPPI RANKED NUMBER FOUR (4) OUT OF 51 STATES WITH A PROJECTED 751 , 568 BY THE YEAR 2030 (STATECHILDHOODOBESITY2017). HEART DISEASE CASES INMISSISSIPPI ARE 183, 417 AND PROJECTED TO REACH 814, 504 BY THE YEAR 2030 AS WELL AS OBESITY CANCER AT 46,018 WITH A PREDICTED INCREASE OF 111,069. THE HEALTH STATISTICS FOR THE STATE OF MISSISSIPPI DEMONSTRATES THE NEED TO CONDUCT THE ASUEP EFNEP IN THE FOLLOWING FIFTEEN (15) COUNTIES IN SOUTHWEST MS: ADAMS, WILKINSON, FRANKLIN, AMITE, JEFFERSON, CLAIBORNE, COPIAH, WARREN, HINDS, MADISON, WALTHALL, AND PIKE.

PROJECT SUMMARY EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM  ACCORDING TO THE FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH, IN THE FIVE TARGETED AREAS, APPROXIMATELY 24% OF THE RESIDENTS LIVE IN POVERTY. IN THESE COUNTIES, 30% OF DEATHS ARE FROM NUTRITION RELATED DISEASES, INCLUDING HEART DISEASE, STROKE AND DIABETES, 74% EAT LESS THAN FIVE SERVINGS OF FRUITS AND VEGETABLES EACH DAY, AND 68% ARE CONSIDERED OVERWEIGHT OR OBESE. THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) TEACHES NUTRITION AND FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT TO LOW INCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH. FLORIDA A<(>&<)>M UNIVERSITY (FAMU) EFNEP ASSIST FAMILIES IN ACQUIRING KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, ATTITUDES, AND CHANGED BEHAVIOR NECESSARY FOR MAKING HEALTHY FOOD CHOICES FOR THE WHOLE FAMILY, PREPARE DELICIOUS AND SAFE FOOD, AND MAKE MONEY AND FOOD STAMPS GO FURTHER. FAMU EFNEP PROGRAM DELIVERS A SERIES OF NUTRITION LESSONS TO PARTICIPANTS IN SIX TARGETED COUNTIES. COLLABORATION WITH LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS AND EXPANSION INTO NONTRADITIONAL SETTINGS, SUCH AS FAITHBASED ORGANIZATIONS AND COMMUNITY PROGRAMS WITH FOCUSED AUDIENCES, PROVIDE A MECHANISM TO INSURE THE TARGETED AUDIENCE IS REACHED. THE PROGRAM TARGETS YOUTH AND ADULTS IN UNDERSERVED AND LOWINCOME COMMUNITIES IN FOUR RURAL AND TWO URBAN COUNTIES. THE PROGRAM SEEKS TO REACH AT LEAST 80 ADULTS IN THE TARGET COUNTIES, AND INCREASE THIS NUMBER BY 5% EACH YEAR OVER THE FIVEYEAR PERIOD. ADULT PARTICIPATION WILL CONSIST OF GROUP AND INDIVIDUAL SESSIONS AT VARIOUS LOCATIONS INCLUDING CHURCHES, COMMUNITY CENTERS, HOUSING AUTHORITIES AND HEALTH DEPARTMENTS. THE PROGRAM WILL FOCUS ON DEVELOPING KEY COMMUNITY AND OTHER COLLABORATIONS TO ASSIST WITH RECRUITING AND MAINTAINING ADULT PARTICIPATION. THE YOUTH AUDIENCES CONSIST OF LOWINCOME CHILDREN AND YOUTH, 4H YOUTH OF VARIOUS ETHNIC AND SOCIAL ECONOMIC BACKGROUNDS. THE PROGRAM SEEKS TO REACH AT LEAST 350 YOUTH AND INCREASE THIS NUMBER BY 5% EACH YEAR OVER THE FIVEYEAR PERIOD.

ABSTRACT FOR THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM NDSU EXTENSION  THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) OF NORTH DAKOTA PROVIDES INTERACTIVE, SKILLS-BASED NUTRITION EDUCATION TO INCOME-ELIGIBLE ADULTS WITH CHILDREN (INCLUDING CUSTODIAL GRANDPARENTS), PREGNANT MOTHERS OF LOW INCOME, AND YOUTH (AGED 5-17) FROM LOW INCOME HOUSEHOLDS. EFNEP HIRES AND TRAINS PEER EDUCATORS FROM THE TARGET COMMUNITIES TO PROVIDE OUTREACH AND EDUCATION TO THE TARGET AUDIENCE. ADULT EFNEP PROVIDES A SERIES OF FREE LESSONS WITH EVIDENCE-BASED CONTENT AIMED AT CULTIVATING POSITIVE NUTRITION, FOOD SAFETY, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. AFTER A SERIES OF FIVE OR MORE LESSONS, EFNEP ADULT PARTICIPANTS ARE ELIGIBLE FOR GRADUATION AND COMPLETE A FOOD RECALL AND SURVEY TO ASSESS THEIR KNOWLEDGE AND BEHAVIOR CHANGES. YOUTH EFNEP WORKS WITH LOCAL YOUTH GROUPS TO PROVIDE COMPLEMENTARY PROGRAMMING TO INCREASE FRUIT, VEGETABLE, WHOLE GRAIN AND LOW- FAT DAIRY INTAKE AND BALANCE HEALTHFUL FOOD WITH PHYSICAL ACTIVITY. ELIGIBLE AUDIENCES ARE LARGELY REACHED BY PARTNERING WITH OTHER AGENCIES THAT PROVIDE SERVICES FOR POPULATIONS OF LOW INCOME (HEAD START, FOOD PANTRIES, SCHOOLS WITH A MAJORITY OF ENROLLEES RECEIVING FREE/REDUCED-PRICE MEALS, ETC.) AND COLLABORATING WITH INDIAN TRIBAL ORGANIZATIONS (ITOS) AND OTHER PARTNERS IN TRIBAL COMMUNITIES, INCLUDING 1994 LAND-GRANT INSTITUTIONS.  EFNEP PARTICIPANTS REPORT IMPROVED DIET QUALITY, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, FOOD SAFETY AND FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT BEHAVIORS FOLLOWING EFNEP LESSONS. ADDITIONALLY, EFNEP PARTICIPANTS REPORT IMPROVED FOOD SECURITY.

EFNEP PROJECT ABSTRACT  FEDERAL AWARD PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF EFNEP FUNDING IS TO INCREASE THE IMPACT OF NUTRITION EDUCATION DISSEMINATED TO LOW-INCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH IN THE 50 STATES, THE U.S. TERRITORIES, AND THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA. THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) SHOULD CONSTITUTE THE EMPLOYMENT AND TRAINING OF PROFESSIONAL AND PARAPROF ESSIONAL (PEER EDUCATOR) STAFF TO ENGAGE IN DIRECT NUTRITION EDUCATION AND OTHER APPROPRIATE NUTRITION EDUCATION EFFORTS, SUCH AS SUPPORTING TECHNOLOGY, WITH LOW-INCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH. TO THE MAXIMUM EXTENT PRACTICABLE, PEER EDUCATORS SHALL BE HIRED FROM THE “ INDIGENOUS TARGET POPULATION.” EFNEP SERVES TWO PRIMARY LOW-INCOME AUDIENCES: 1) FAMILIES WITH YOUNG CHILDREN (PARENTS AND OTHER CAREGIVERS WITH PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY FOR FEEDING YOUNG CHILDREN); AND 2) YOUTH/CHILDREN (GRADE RANGE - KINDERGARTEN THROUGH 12TH GRADE). YOUNG ADULTS WITH LIMITED FINANCIAL RESOURCES WOULD ALSO BE APPROPRIATE FOR EFNEP, AS THEY MAY BECOME PARENTS IN THE NEAR FUTURE. THE PRIORITIES OF EFNEP ARE TO ASSIST LOW-INCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH IN ACQUIRING KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, ATTITUDES, AND CHANGED BEHAVIORS NECESSARY FOR NUTRITIONALLY SOUND DIETS AND TO CONTRIBUTE TO THEIR PERSONAL DEVELOPMENT AND IMPROVEMENT OF THE TOTAL FAMILY DIET AND NUTRITIONAL WELL-BEING. PARTICIPATION IN EFNEP SHOULD RESULT IN IMPROVED DIETS AND NUTRITIONAL WELL-BEING OF THE TOTAL FAMILY. 1. INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES SHOULD EXPERIENCE IMPROVEMENTS IN FOUR CORE AREAS: A. DIET QUALITY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY—IMPROVED DIETS AND NUTRITIONAL AND PHYSICAL WELL-BEING THROUGH THE ADOPTION OF FEDERAL FOOD AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY RECOMMENDATIONS. B. FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT—INCREASED ABILITY TO BUY, GROW, OR OTHERWISE APPROPRIATELY OBTAIN, PREPARE, AND STORE FOOD THAT MEETS NUTRITIONAL NEEDS. C. FOOD SAFETY—IMPROVED HOUSEHOLD FOOD SAFETY AND SANITATION PRACTICES. D. FOOD SECURITY—INCREASED ABILITY TO GET FOOD DIRECTLY—AND FROM FOOD ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS WHERE NECESSARY—TO ENSURE HAVING ENOUGH HEALTHY FOOD TO EAT. 2. COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT WITH EFNEP SHOULD RESULT IN: A. INCREASED REFERRALS ACROSS PROGRAMS, ORGANIZATIONS, AND COMMUNITY GROUPS TO ADDRESS PARTICIPANTS’ NEEDS AND TO STRENGTHEN UNIVERSITIES’ CAPACITY WITH RESPECT TO EFNEP’S FOUR CORE AREAS. B. INCREASED COORDINATION, COOPERATION, AND COLLABORATION BETWEEN UNIVERSITIES AND COMMUNITIES TO ACCOMPLISH LOCAL AND STATE IDENTIFIED PRIORITIES ASSOCIATED WITH EFNEP’S FOUR CORE AREAS. EFNEP IS ALIGNED WITH ONE SPECIFIC STRATEGIC GOAL FROM THE USDA STRATEGIC PLAN FOR FY 2022- 2026. STRATEGIC GOAL 4: MAKE SAFE, NUTRI TIOUS FOOD AVAILABLE TO ALL AMERICANS; OBJECTIVE 4.1: INCREASE FOOD SECURITY THROUGH ASSISTANCE AND ACCESS TO NUTRITIOUS AND AFFORDABLE FOOD.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: IN THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA-LINCOLN (UNL) INSTITUTE OF AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES (IANR), WE ARE ALL ABOUT PEOPLE AND THE FOOD, WATER AND NATURAL RESOURCES THAT SUSTAIN THEM. IANR INNOVATION IN RESEARCH, TEACHING, AND EXTENSION EDUCATION  PLACES NEBRASKA ON THE LEADING EDGE OF FOOD PRODUCTION, ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP, HUMAN NUTRITION, BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT, AND YOUTH ENGAGEMENT. COMPOSED OF THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES AND NATURAL RESOURCES (CASNR), THE AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH DIVISION (ARD), NEBRASKA EXTENSION, AND THE ARD AND EXTENSION COMPONENTS OF THREE DEPARTMENTS IN THE COLLEGE OF EDUCATION AND HUMAN SCIENCES; IANR IS COMMITTED TO GROWING THE FUTURE OF NEBRASKA'S PEOPLE, BUSINESSES, AND COMMUNITIES. STRATEGIC PLANNING IS INTEGRAL TO IANR'S FUNCTION AS A LAND-GRANT INSTITUTION, AND IT PRIDES ITSELF ON WORKING AS AN INTEGRATED SYSTEM AND COLLABORATIVE ENVIRONMENT ACROSS THE THREE MISSION AREAS. IANR STRIVES TO COMBINE RESEARCH, TEACHING AND EXTENSION IN A MULTIDISCIPLINARY, COLLABORATIVE ENVIRONMENT THAT ENCOURAGES THE BEST THINKING AND EXPERTISE FROM ACROSS THE UNIVERSITY AND PRIVATE ENTERPRISE TO ENSURE NEBRASKA’S COMPETITIVENESS IN A WORLD OF CHANGE AND CHALLENGE. SPECIFIC TO EFNEP, NEBRASKA MAIN PRIORITIES FALL IN ALIGNMENT WITH: 1. IMPROVING FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT FOR ADULTS - EFNEP NEBRASKA WILL INCREASE THE PERCENTAGE OF ADULT PARTICIPANTS THAT IMPROVE IN ONE OR MORE FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (I.E., COOK DINNER AT HOME, COMPARE FOOD PRICES, PLAN MEALS BEFORE SHOPPING, LOOK IN REFRIGERATOR OR CUPBOARD BEFORE SHOPPING, OR MAKE A LIST BEFORE SHOPPING) FROM 75% TO 80% BY 2025. 2. IMPROVING PHYSICAL ACTIVITY FOR ADULTS - NEBRASKA EFNEP WILL INCREASE THE PERCENTAGE OF ADULT PARTICIPANTS WHO IMPROVE IN ONE OR MORE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY BEHAVIORS (I.E., EXERCISING FOR AT LEAST 30 MINUTES, DOING WORKOUTS TO BUILD AND STRENGTHEN MUSCLES, OR MAKING SMALL CHANGES TO BE MORE ACTIVE) FROM 73% TO 78% BY 2025. 3. IMPROVING PHYSICAL ACTIVITY FOR YOUTH - NEBRASKA EFNEP WILL INCREASE THE PERCENTAGE OF YOUTH PARTICIPANTS WHO IMPROVE IN ONE OR MORE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY BEHAVIORS FROM 45% TO 53% BY 2025. 4. INCREASE OLDER YOUTH REACH - NEBRASKA EFNEP WILL UTILIZE NEW 6-12TH GRADE-FOCUSED CURRICULA: TEEN CUISINE AND HUSKER PERFORMANCE. 5. TECHNOLOGY - BY 2025 NEBRASKA EFNEP WILL BE USING THE WEB-BASED MEDIA PLATFORM TO TEACH 60 ONLINE LESSONS AND MAKE-UP LESSONS YEARLY TO ADULT EFNEP PARTICIPANTS, AS WELL AS REINFORCE LESSON CONCEPTS BETWEEN CLASSES AND FOR POST-GRADUATES.  DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE CAPACITY FUNDING IANR RECEIVES IS ALLOCATED WITHIN TWO KEY, CRITICAL ISSUES TO ADDRESS THE ABOVE FOCUS AREAS. EFNEP FALLS UNDER THE FOSTERING HEALTHY AND PRODUCTIVE PEOPLE FOCUS AREA.  FOSTERING HEALTHY AND PRODUCTIVE PEOPLE THIS PROGRAM FOCUSES ON USING BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH IN THE LIFE/AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES TO GENERATE KNOWLEDGE CRITICAL TO MAXIMIZING PRODUCTIVITY IN FOOD SCIENCES; BUSINESS/COMMUNITY VITALITY; ENTREPRENEURSHIP; HEALTHY LIVING; AND DEVELOPMENT AND SUCCESS OF YOUNG CHILDREN, YOUTH, AND FAMILIES. RESEARCH EFFORTS SPAN THE BASIC/FUNDAMENTAL TO THE APPLIED/TRANSLATIONAL, RELATING TO NUTRITION/HE ALTH, FOOD SAFETY, EARLYCHILDHOOD, YOUTH DEVELOPMENT, FAMILY STRENGTHENING, AND COMMUNITY CAPACITY  BUILDING. EXTENSION PROGRAMS WILL ENGAGE CLIENTELE BY TRANSLATING EXISTING AND NEW RESEARCH TO NEBRASKANS THAT OPTIMIZE PRODUCTIVITY AND LIKELIHOOD OF SUCCESS. THESE EFFORTS WILL BE SUPPORTED BY UNDERGRADUATE/GRADUATE EDUCATION DESIGNED TO CONTRIBUTE THE STATE’S LONG-TERM ECONOMIC GROWTH. WEST VIRGINIA UNIVERSITY EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROJECT ABSTRACT  WVUS EFNEP PROGRAM FACILITATES LEARNING AMONG PARTICIPANTS, HELPING THEM TO MAKE HEALTHY FOOD CHOICES FOR THEIR FAMILIES, INCORPORATE MORE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY INTO THEIR DAILY LIVES AND STRETCH THEIR FOOD DOLLARS. THIS ALLOWS OUR STATE TO CONSERVE RESOURCES, LOWER HEALTH CARE COSTS AND REDUCE THE BURDEN ON FOOD ASSISTANCE AND OTHER PUBLIC ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS. THROUGH PARTICIPATION IN EFNEP PROGRAMS, INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES INCREASE THEIR SELF-CONFIDENCE AND SELF- RELIANCE WHICH BUILDS STRENGTH AND RESILIENCE IN OUR COMMUNITIES. OUR PRIORITY POPULATION INCLUDES YOUTH (3RD-12TH GRADE) IN SCHOOLS LOCATED IN CENSUS TRACTS WHERE 50% OF INCOMES ARE EQUAL TO OR LESS THAN 185% THE FEDERAL POVERTY LEVEL OR WHERE AT LEAST 50% OF CHILDREN RECEIVE FREE AND REDUCED PRICED MEALS OR IN SCHOOLS PARTICIPATING IN THE COMMUNITY ELIGIBILITY PROVISION (CEP). YOUTH PROGRAMS ARE GENERALLY HELD IN SCHOOLS BUT CAN ALSO OCCUR IN THE AFTER-SCHOOL AND SUMMER PROGRAM ENVIRONMENTS IN PARTNERSHIP WITH YOUTH-SERVING AGENCIES. WE ALSO SERVE LOW- INCOME ADULTS WITH CHILDREN ARE RECRUITED VIA PARTNERSHIPS WITH STATE AND LOCAL AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS WHO ALSO SERVE THIS AUDIENCE VIA THEIR MISSIONS AND PROGRAMS. IT IS THROUGH DEVELOPMENT OF THESE PARTNERSHIPS THAT EFNEP AND SNAP-ED FRONT-LINE STAFF ARE ABLE TO PROVIDE EDUCATION PROGRAMS TO THEIR CLIENTS AND PARTICIPANTS. THESE PARTNERSHIPS INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO ADULT BASIC EDUCATION PROGRAMS WHERE ATTENDANCE IS TIED TO PARTICIPANTS RECEIVING UNEMPLOYMENT BENEFITS, WIC PROGRAMS, SUBSTANCE MISUSE PROGRAMS, PREGNANCY CENTERS, FOSTER CARE AGENCIES AS WELL AS PROGRAMS FOR GRANDPARENTS RAISING GRANDCHILDREN, FOOD PANTRIES, TRANSITIONAL LIVING FACILITIES, AND DAY REPORT CENTERS. ALL EDUCATION INCLUDES A SERIES OF 6-9 LESSONS FOR EACH PARTICIPANT. DEMOGRAPHICS AND PRE-POST TEST BEHAVIORAL CHANGE DATA ARE COLLECTED FOR ALL PARTICIPANTS AND REPORTED IN WEBNEERS.

ACCORDING TO HEALTHY PEOPLE 2020, GOOD NUTRITION, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND HEALTHY BODY WEIGHT ARE ESSENTIAL FOR GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT, HEALTH AND WELL-BEING. PRACTICING ALL OF THESE ESSENTIAL PARTS OF WELL-BEING CONTRIBUTES SUBSTANTIALLY TO THE BURDEN OF PREVENTABLE ILLNESS AND PREMATURE DEATH IN THE UNITED STATES AND TO THE NATION'S ECONOMIC BURDEN. HOWEVER, MOST ADULTS AND YOUTH DO NOT PRACTICE HEALTHY EATING HABITS OR GET ENOUGH PHYSICAL ACTIVITY IN THEIR DAILY LIVES, LEADING TO A DRASTIC INCREASE IN OBESITY. ACCORDING TO THE CDC BETWEEN 2001 AND 2010, CONSUMPTION OF SUGAR-SWEETENED BEVERAGES AMONG CHILDREN AND ADOLESCENTS DECREASED, BUT STILL ACCOUNTS FOR 10% OF TOTAL CALORIC INTAKE. BETWEEN 2003 AND 2010, TOTAL FRUIT INTAKE AND WHOLE FRUIT INTAKE AMONG CHILDREN AND ADOLESCENTS INCREASED. HOWEVER, MOST YOUTH STILL DO NOT MEET FRUIT AND VEGETABLE RECOMMENDATIONS. EMPTY CALORIES FROM ADDED SUGARS AND SOLID FATS CONTRIBUTE TO 40% OF DAILY CALORIES FOR CHILDREN AND ADOLESCENTS AGE 2–18 YEARS—AFFECTING THE OVERALL QUALITY OF THEIR DIETS. APPROXIMATELY H ALF OF THESE EMPTY CALORIES COME FROM SIX SOURCES: SODA, FRUIT DRINKS, DAIRY DESSERTS, GRAIN DESSERTS, PIZZA, AND WHOLE MILK. MOST YOUTH DO NOT CONSUME THE RECOMMENDED AMOUNT OF TOTAL WATER. ACCORDING TO THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION (CDC), DIETARY FACTORS ARE ASSOCIATED WITH 4 OF THE 10 LEADING CAUSES OF DEATH: CORONARY HEART DISEASE, SOME TYPES OF CANCER, STROKE, AND TYPE 2 DIABETES. CHILDHOOD OBESITY IS A SERIOUS PROBLEM IN THE UNITED STATES PUTTING CHILDREN AND ADOLESCENTS AT RISK FOR POOR HEALTH. OBESITY PREVALENCE AMONG CHILDREN AND ADOLESCENTS IS STILL TOO HIGH. FOR CHILDREN AND ADOLESCENTS AGED 2-19 YEARS: THE PREVALENCE OF OBESITY WAS 18.5% AND AFFECTED ABOUT 13.7 MILLION CHILDREN AND ADOLESCENTS. OBESITY PREVALENCE WAS 13.9% AMONG 2- TO 5-YEAR-OLD, 18.4% AMONG 6- TO 11-YEAR-OLD, AND 20.6% AMONG 12- TO 19-YEAR-OLD. CHILDHOOD OBESITY IS ALSO MORE COMMON AMONG CERTAIN POPULATIONS. IN WEST VIRGINIA 16.4 PERCENT OF THE 9TH GRADE STUDENTS ARE OBESE AND 22.3 PERCENT OF 12 GRADE. EACH GRADE YEAR GETS PROGRESSIVELY WORSE WITH A DECLINE TO 16.7 PERCENT GRADE 11 AND THEM SHOOTS BACK UP IN 12 GRADE. THE RAPID SPREAD DURING THE 1990'S OCCURRED ACROSS ALL STATES, REGIONS, AND DEMOGRAPHIC GROUPS. HIGHEST RATES OF OBESITY FOR 10- TO 17-YEAR-OLD, WEST VIRGINIA (20.3%), WAS RANKED SECOND HIGHEST WITH MISSISSIPPI (26.1%), BEING 1ST. WERE AND KENTUCKY (19.3%). ACCORDING TO THE 2019 KIDS COUNT, 26 PERCENT OF WEST VIRGINIA CHILDREN (94,000) UNDER THE AGE OF 18 LIVED IN POVERTY COMPARED WITH 18 PERCENT OF U.S. CHILDREN. CHILDREN FARE WORSE THAN ADULTS ON POVERTY MEASURES, AND CHILDREN UNDER AGE SIX SUFFER THE HIGHEST POVERTY RATES OF ALL. A SMALL NUMBER OF STUDIES HAVE DOCUMENTED THE PROBLEM OF OVERWEIGHT AND OBESITY AMONG CHILDREN IN FOSTER CARE / AS WELL AS AMONG CHILDREN BEING RAISED BY GRANDPARENTS. STATE EFFORTS WILL NEED TO BE COORDINATED WITH NATIONAL AND LOCAL INTERVENTIONS TO CONTROL THIS EPIDEMIC. BASED ON THE US CENSUS THE 2019 ESTIMATE SHOWED THE POPULATION OF WEST VIRGINIA AT 1,792,147 W ITH 16% OF THE TOTAL POPULATION LIVING IN POVERTY.   OUTLINED ARE THE ARE THE CHILD AND ADULT COMORBIDITIES THAT OUR CURRENT EFNEP PROGRAMING IS CURRENTLY ADDRESSING. IDENTIFYING LOCAL AND REGIONAL HEALTH CONCERNS, SPECIFICALLY, IN WEST VIRGINIA HAS BEEN THE PRIMARY GOAL OF EFNEP PROGRAMING. OUR DEVELOPMENT OF NOVEL RESEARCH BASED SOLUTIONS IN COMBINATION WITH COMMUNITY BASED HEALTH LITERACY EXTENSION PROGRAMING HAS BEEN VERY EFFECTIVE WHEN ADDRESSING CHILDHOOD OBESITY, TYPE 2 DIABETES AND OTHER METABOLIC DISEASES.
