PUERTO RICO IS A CARIBBEAN ISLAND, AND COMMONWEALTH WITH THE UNITED STATES. EFNEP IS IMPLEMENTED THROUGH PUERTO RICO AGRICULTURAL EXTENSION SERVICE WHICH IS PART OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO (UPR), THE MAIN PUBLIC UNIVERSITY SYSTEM OF THE ISLAND WHICH CONSISTS OF 11 CAMPUSES. IN 2021, THE UNITED STATES CENSUS BUREAU ESTIMATED THE POPULATION OF PUERTO RICO AT 3,263,584. IN THE ISLAND, MORE THAN HALF OF THE POPULATION RECEIVES COMBINED BENEFITS FROM SNAP, WIC, OR OTHER PUBLIC ASSISTANCE. ACCORDING TO THE INSTITUTE OF STATISTICS OF PUERTO RICO (2015), NEARLY 33.2% OF THE POPULATION ON THE ISLAND FACES FOOD INSECURITY.  EFNEP PUERTO RICO REMAINS AT THE FOREFRONT IN PROVIDING NUTRITIONAL EDUCATION TO LOW- INCOME FAMILIES WHO ARE VULNERABLE TO ECONOMIC CHANGES AND ENVIRONMENTAL EVENTS. THE OBJECTIVES OF OUR PROGRAM ARE TO ACHIEVE IMPROVEMENT IN FOUR CORE AREAS:  - DIET QUALITY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY: IMPROVED DIETS AND NUTRITIONAL AND PHYSICAL WELL-BEING THROUGH THE ADOPTION OF FEDERAL FOOD AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY RECOMMENDATIONS. - FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT: INCREASED ABILITY TO BUY, PREPARE, AND STORE FOOD THAT MEETS NUTRITIONAL NEEDS. - FOOD SAFETY: IMPROVED HOUSEHOLD FOOD SAFETY AND SANITATION PRACTICES. - FOOD SECURITY: INCREASED ABILITY TO GET FOOD DIRECTLY—AND FROM FOOD ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS WHERE NECESSARY—TO ENSURE HAVING ENOUGH HEALTHY FOOD TO EAT.  PARAPROFESSIONALS PROVIDE NUTRITION EDUCATION IN THE MUNICIPALITIES THROUGH FIVE REGIONAL UNITS: SAN JUAN, CAGUAS, COAMO, ARECIBO AND TOA BAJA. THE PRIMARY TARGET AUDIENCE IS LOW-INCOME ADULTS WITH CHILDREN AND YOUTH. PARENTS AND CAREGIVERS WHO ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR FOOD PLANNING, BUYING, PREPARING, AND FEEDING CHILDREN AND YOUTH ARE THE OBJECT OF OUR PROGRAMMING EFFORTS. PARAPROFESSIONALS SERVE THEM IN THEIR COMMUNITIES WITH THE COLLABORATION OF VOLUNTEERS, AGENCIES, COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS, AND LEADERS. ANOTHER TARGET AUDIENCE IS LOW-INCOME CHILDREN AND YOUTH, THIRD THROUGH GRADE 12. THESE ARE SERVED IN COMMUNITY SCHOOLS, AS WELL AS CHILDREN IN HOMESCHOOLING, SUMMER CAMPS, AND OTHER COMMUNITY GROUPS IDENTIFIED AS LOW-INCOME.  FOR ADULTS WE IMPLEMENT EATING SMART - BEING ACTIVE CURRICULUM (2017), SPANISH VERSION, DEVELOPED BY COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY. IT IS DESIGNED FOR PARAPROFESSIONAL NUTRITION EDUCATORS TO TEACH LOW-INCOME FAMILIES WITH CHILDREN ABOUT HEALTHY LIFESTYLE CHOICES. FROM THIRD THROUGH FIFTH GRADE, PARAPROFESSIONALS IMPLEMENT THE LIVE, HEALTHY AND ACTIVE (VIVE SALUDABLE Y ACTIVO) CHILDREN CURRICULUM, AND FROM NINTH TO TWELFTH GRADE THE P.A.R.A (PIENSA, ALIMÉNTATE, REDUCE, ACTÍVATE) YOUTH CURRICULUM. BOTH CURRICULA ARE DESIGNED FOR PARAPROFESSIONALS TO TEACH LOW-INCOME CHILDREN AND YOUTH HOW TO MAKE HEALTHIER LIFESTYLE CHOICES THROUGH SIX INTERACTIVE LESSONS. THROUGH DELIVERING NUTRITION EDUCATION, FOOD RESOURCES MANAGEMENT CONTENT, AND OTHER HEALTHY LIFESTYLES ACTIVITIES (I.E., HEALTHY RECIPES DEMONSTRATIONS AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITIES) WE HAVE A GREAT OPPORTUNITY TO IMPROVE NUTRITIONAL HEALTH AND PREVENT HEALTH RELATED CONDITIONS OF THE MOST VULNERABLE PUERTO RICAN FAMILIES. CONSIDERING THE HIGH LEVELS OF POVERTY AND THE INCREASING UNEMPLOYMENT RATE, TODAY MORE THAN EVER EFNEP PARAPROFESSIONALS CAN TEACH SKILLS AND GUIDE PARTICIPANTS TO MAKE BETTER DECISIONS AND INCREASE THEIR ABILITY TO HAVE ENOUGH FOOD FOR THEMSELVES AND THEIR FAMILIES.

FLORIDA EFNEP WILL PROVIDE PROGRAMMING IN ESCAMBIA, HILLSBOROUGH, MIAMI-DADE, AND PALM BEACH COUNTIES FOR FFY2023. CONTENT TAUGHT IN EFNEP FOCUS ON CONCEPTS FROM THE 2020-2025 DIETARY GUIDELINES FOR AMERICANS, MYPLATE AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY GUIDELINES FOR AMERICANS. OUR ADULT PROGRAM UTILIZES THE CURRICULUM, EATING SMART, BEING ACTIVE (COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY, 2017). THIS 9 TO 12-LESSON CURRICULUM, BASED ON SOCIAL COGNITIVE THEORY, IS RESEARCH-BASED AND FOCUSES ON THE FOUR CORE AREAS INCLUDING FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, FOOD SAFETY, DIET QUALITY/PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, AND FOOD SECURITY. THE THREE SUPPLEMENTAL LESSONS ALLOW FOR MORE SPECIFIC GUIDANCE RELEVANT TO PREGNANCY AND FEEDING INFANTS AND TODDLERS. COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY HAS ALSO DEVELOPED A REMOTE DELIVERY STRATEGY FOR THE 9 CORE LESSONS OF ESBA THAT WE WILL UTILIZE TO EXPAND OUR REACH WHILE FACE-TO-FACE PROGRAMMING IS SUSPENDED OR LESSENED DUE TO SOCIAL DISTANCING. EACH LESSON HAS A PRE-RECORDED VIDEO WITH CLOSED CAPTIONING INENGLISH AND SPANISH AS WELL AS A SCRIPTED LIVE DISCUSSION TEMPLATE THAT CAN BE FACILITATED VIA THE PHONE OR WEBINAR. FURTHER USE OF REMOTE LESSONS AS SOCIAL DISTANCING GUIDELINES DECREASE IS DISCUSSED IN THE TECHNOLOGY PLAN. FLORIDA EFNEP WILL ALSO TARGET PREGNANT TEENS AND CHILDREN AND YOUTH IN GRADE K TO 12.

OBESITY POOR NUTRITION AND LIMITED PHYSICAL ACTIVITY ARE MAJOR HEALTH CONCERNS. EFNEP IMPROVES THE HEALTH AND WELLBEING OF FAMILIES AND YOUTH WITH LIMITED INCOMES. ADDITIONALLY EFNEP LEADS TO PUBLIC SAVINGS. RESEARCH SHOWS THAT BETTER HEALTH IS ASSOCIATED WITH REDUCED HEALTHCARE COSTS LESS ABSENTEEISM FROM WORK AND LESS DEPENDENCE ON EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE. ARKANSAS FACES A MORE SIGNIFICANT CHALLENGE REGARDING OBESITY IN THE STATE. ARKANSAS IS THE SEVENTH STATE WITH A PREVALENCE OF OBESITY EQUAL TO OR GREATER THAN 30%. ACCORDING TO THE STATE OF OBESITY REPORT THE AVERAGE BMI IN ARKANSAS IS 37% COMPARED TO THE NATIONAL AVERAGE OF 30% (THE STATE OF OBESITY 2020). ARKANSAS EFNEP IS POSITIONED TO ADDRESS OBESITY IN THE STATE. EFNEP IS A COMMUNITY DRIVEN COMPREHENSIVE EFFORT WITH CLEARLY DEFINED GOALS TO IMPACT BEHAVIORAL CHANGES IN ENROLLED PARTICIPANTS.THOSE GOALS INCLUDE ENCOURAGING INCREASED CONSUMPTION OF FRUITS AND VEGETABLES REDUCED FAT DAIRY FOODS WHOLE GRAINS AND INCREASED PHYSICAL ACTIVITY.  IN ARKANSAS THIRTYEIGHT PERCENT OF FAMILIES WITH A FEMALE HEAD OF HOUSEHOLD HAVE INCOMES BELOW THE POVERTY LEVEL. ACCORDING TO THE NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHILDREN IN POVERTY 53% OF THE CHILDREN IN ARKANSAS LIVE IN A LOWINCOME HOUSEHOLDS COMPARED TO THE NATIONAL AVERAGE OF 41% (NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHILDREN IN POVERTY 2020). ACCORDING TO THE ARKANSAS HUNGER RELIEF ALLIANCE ARKANSAS IS RANKED 2ND IN THE NATION FOR THE MOST INCIDENCES OF FOOD INSECURITY AND 17.2% OF HOUSEHOLDS IN ARKANSAS ARE FOOD INSECURE (ARKANSAS HUNGER RELIEF ALLIANCE 2020). ACCORDING TO A RECENT RELEASE BY THE ARKANSAS HUNGER ALLIANCE 1 IN 4 ARKANSAS KIDS ARE FOOD INSECURE AND WILL NOT KNOW WHERE THEIR NEXT MEAL WILL COME FROM (ARKANSAS HUNGER RELIEF ALLIANCE 2020). WHEN FOOD AND NUTRIENTS ARE CHRONICALLY INADEQUATE TO SUSTAIN PHYSICAL AND MENTAL WELLBEING HUNGER LEADS TO HIGH MEDICAL EDUCATIONAL PSYCHOLOGICAL ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COSTS.  FOR THE NEXT FIVE YEARS THE UNIVERSITY OF ARKANSAS AT PINE BLUFF (UAPB) 1890 COOPERATIVE EXTENSION PROGRAM IN EFFORTS TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF HEALTH OF ARKANSANS UABP WILL PROVIDE JOB OPPORTUNITIES FOR ARKANSAS CITIZENS AS WELL. WE WILL EMPLOY TWO TO THREE PROGRAM EDUCATORS TO DELIVER QUALITY NUTRITION EDUCATION TO THE JEFFERSON COUNTY AND PULASKI COUNTY ADULT AND YOUTH COMMUNITIES.  THE UNIVERSITY OF ARKANSAS AT PINE BLUFF (UAPB) EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) WORKS WITH LOWINCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH. INDIVIDUALS CAN QUALIFY FOR THE PROGRAM IF THEIR INCOME IS 185% OR LESS OF THE POVERTY GUIDELINES. THE ADULT EFNEP TARGETS INDIVIDUALS WHO HAVE CHILDREN BELOW AGE 19 OR WHO ARE PREGNANT AND RESPONSIBLE FOR PLANNING AND PREPARING THE FAMILYS FOOD. THE ADULTS WILL BE TAUGHT IN SMALL GROUP SESSIONS BY TRAINED NUTRITION EDUCATORS (PARAPROFESSIONALS).  THE EFNEP YOUTH PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS RANGE IN AGE FROM 5 TO 19. THE YOUTH LIVE IN LOWINCOME GEOGRAPHIC AREAS RECEIVE FREE OR REDUCEDPRICE LUNCHES OR PARTICIPATE IN OTHER LOWINCOME ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS. EFNEP EMPHASIZES PROVIDING FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE PERSONAL DEVELOPMENT OF YOUTH. THE YOUTH ARE TAUGHT IN SUMMER OR YEARROUND ENRICHMENT PROGRAMS CONDUCTED BY EFNEP ASSISTANTS AND VOLUNTEERS.  UAPB EFNEP WORKS CLOSELY WITH PARTNERING AGENCIES TO RECEIVE ONGOING PROGRAM REFERRALS.

PENN STATE EXTENSION’S EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) PROVIDES FREE RESEARCH-BASED EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS TO IN COME-ELIGIBLE PARTICIPANTS TO DEVELOP THE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS NECESSARY TO ACHIEVE A HEALTHFUL DIET ON A LIMITED BUDGET. OUR GOAL IS TO HELP THEM USE THE RESOURCES AVAILABLE IN THE MOST BENEFICIAL AND ECONOMICAL WAYS POSSIBLE.  THE PROGRAM CONSISTS OF A SERIES OF LESSONS, TAUGHT IN SMALL GROUPS, LED BY NUTRITION EDUCATION ADVISERS (NEAS) WHO ARE PART OF THE COUNTY EXTENSION STAFF. THE NEAS ARE PARAPROFESSIONAL STAFF HIRED BECAUSE OF THEIR COMMUNITY CONNECTIONS AND ABILITY TO BUILD RAPPORT WITH THE PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS. THEY ALSO SERVE AS ROLE MODELS FOR THE PARTICIPANTS. NEAS RECEIVE TRAINING ON NUTRITION EDUCATION AND ARE SUPERVISED BY EXTENSION EDUCATORS.  ALL EFNEP SERIES ARE FREE. PROGRAMMING IS HELD VIRTUALLY AND, WHENEVER POSSIBLE, IN- PERSON IN COMMUNITY CENTERS, LOW-INCOME HOUSING DEVELOPMENTS, LIBRARIES, CHURCHES, AND VARIOUS OTHER SITES. ALL SESSIONS HAVE HANDS-ON ACTIVITIES TO REINFORCE LESSON CONTENT, AND IN-PERSON PROGRAMMING INCLUDES FOOD DEMONSTRATIONS TO BUILD COOKING SKILLS AND ENCOURAGE PARTICIPANTS TO TRY NEW HEALTHY RECIPES. PENN STATE EXTENSION’S EFNEP DOES NOT SUPPLY FREE FOOD.  EFNEP PROGRAMMING TARGETS INCOME-ELIGIBLE YOUTH, YOUNG ADULTS (18-25 YEARS OLD) WITHOUT CHILDREN, AND CARETAKERS OF YOUNG CHILDREN.  PENN STATE EXTENSION’S EFNEP ADULT PROGRAMMING COVERS FOOD PREPARATION, MEAL PLANNING, FOOD STORAGE AND SANITATION, SHOPPING SKILLS, FAMILY NUTRITION, AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY FOR A HEALTHY LIFESTYLE. THE YOUTH PROGRAMS INCLUDE FOOD PREPARATION, FOOD SAFETY, SNACK CHOICES, NUTRITION AND HEALTH, AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY. PARTICIPANTS MAY JOIN 4-H CLUBS OR GROUPS LED BY VOLUNTEERS AND PARTICIPATE IN REGULAR MEETINGS. THEY MAY ALSO HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO ATTEND SPECIAL SUMMER ACTIVITIES. YOUTH ACTIVITIES ARE ALSO AVAILABLE TO TEACHERS FOR IN-SCHOOL USE.  EFNEP EVALUATIONS CONTINUE TO SHOW PARTICIPANTS MAKING IMPROVEMENTS IN DIET QUALITY AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. EVERY YEAR, PENN STATE EXTENSION’S EFNEP HELPS 96-98% OF PARTICIPANTS MAKE A POSITIVE CHANGE IN ANY FOOD GROUP.

OREGON EFNEP  THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) IN OREGON ASSISTS LOW-INCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH IN ACQUIRING THE KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, ATTITUDES, AND CHANGED BEHAVIORS NECESSARY FOR NUTRITIONALLY SOUND DIETS AND CONTRIBUTES TO THEIR PERSONAL DEVELOPMENT AND THE IMPROVEMENT OF TOTAL FAMILY DIET AND NUTRITIONAL WELFARE. CURRENT RESEARCH REPORTS SHOW THE NEED FOR EFNEP IS GREATER THAN EVER IN THIS STATE. SINCE MID-MARCH OF 2020 THERE HAS BEEN A 60% SPIKE IN DEMAND FOR HUNGER RELIEF SERVICES. OVER 13.2% OF THE POPULATION LIVES BELOW THE POVERTY LEVEL AND 18.9% OF CHILDREN ARE FOOD INSECURE. OREGON EFNEP WILL CONTINUE TO TARGET LOW-INCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH MOST AT RISK WITH INFORMATION ON HEALTHY EATING, BUDGETING, SHOPPING, MEAL PLANNING, AND ACCESSING FOOD RESOURCES. PARAPROFESSIONAL EDUCATORS TEACH CLASSES IN COMMUNITIES WHERE FAMILIES LIVE. HANDS-ON FOOD PREPARATION HELPS FAMILIES GAIN NEW COOKING SKILLS SO THAT LOW-COST, NUTRITIOUS MEALS ARE COOKED AND EATEN AT HOME. EFNEP FOCUSES ON HELPING FAMILIES GAIN KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND CONFIDENCE IN MAKING INFORMED DECISIONS ABOUT DIET QUALITY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, FOOD SAFETY AND FOOD SECURITY. WE’RE IMPLEMENTING A HYBRID (REMOTE AND IN-PERSON) MODEL, TO ACCOMMODATE THE NEEDS OF EACH COUNTY AND CONTINUE TO DO WHAT HAS SEEMED TO WORK DURING THE PANDEMIC. PROVIDING OPTIONS IN TERMS OF IN-PERSON AND VIRTUAL, AS WELL AS MORNING AND EVENING SCHEDULES FOR CLASSES HAS PROVEN TO BE A GOOD STRATEGY THAT PROMOTES RETENTION OF PARTICIPANTS AND MINIMIZES THE NEED TO SCHEDULE SEPARATE MAKE-UP LESSONS WITH INDIVIDUAL PARTICIPANTS. FOR FY2023 THERE WILL BE A NEW BILINGUAL EDUCATOR HIRED IN THE MOST POPULOUS REGION OF THE STATE, WHICH IS THE PORTLAND METRO AREA, WHERE THERE IS ALSO A GREAT NEED AND DEMAND FOR EFNEP CLASSES.  PRIORITIES #1: IMPROVING FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT SKILLS IN ADULTS WHILE PARTICIPATING IN OREGON EFNEP CLASSES, ADULTS LEARN NEW SKILLS IN FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, INCLUDING PURCHASING, SELECTING, OR OTHERWISE OBTAINING, PREPARING, AND STORING HEALTHY FOODS. IN THE NEXT 5 YEARS, WE WILL EMPHASIZE INTRODUCING PARTICIPANTS TO NEW LOW-COST, HEALTHY FOODS, PLANNING MEALS IN ADVANCE, PREPARING FOODS AT HOME, STRETCHING FOOD RESOURCES, AND REDUCING FOOD WASTE. OREGON’S EFNEP GOAL IS TO INCREASE BY 1% PER YEAR (FOR THE NEXT 5 YEARS) THE PERCENTAGE OF PARTICIPANTS WHO IMPROVE ON ONE OR MORE FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. BASED ON THE FFY2021 FOOD AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY QUESTIONNAIRE, OUR BASELINE FIGURE IS 83%.  #2: IMPROVING ADULT PARTICIPANT HANDWASHING SKILLS REGULAR HANDWASHING IS ONE OF THE BEST WAYS TO REMOVE GERMS, AVOID GETTING SICK AND PREVENT THE SPREAD OF GERMS TO OTHERS. IT IS ALSO ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT THINGS TO DO TO PREVENT FOOD POISONING WHEN PREPARING FOOD. IN 2020, THE CDC LAUNCHED LIFE IS BETTER WITH CLEAN HANDS, A NEW NATIONAL CAMPAIGN DESIGNED TO HELP RAISE AWARENESS ABOUT THE IMPORTANCE OF HANDWASHING AT KEY TIMES IN BOTH HOMES AND PUBLIC SETTINGS, SUCH AS BEFORE COOKING OR AFTER USING THE BATHROOM. BASED ON PARTICIPANT DATA FROM FFY 2018 AND 2019, WE DISCOVERED THAT HAND WASHING IS ONE OF THE SKILLS WITH THE SMALLEST PROGRESS ACROSS EFNEP’S CORE AREAS, WITH ONLY 19% OF ADULTS WASHING THEIR HANDS MORE OFTEN BEFORE PREPARING FOOD. FOR THE NEXT 5 YEARS, IMPROVING ADULT PARTICIPANT HAND WASHING SKILLS BY 1% EACH YEAR WILL BE A MAJOR PRIORITY FOR EFNEP.  #3: IMPROVING ADULT PARTICIPANT PHYSICAL ACTIVITY REGULAR PHYSICAL ACTIVITY IMPROVES STRENGTH AND ENDURANCE, HELPS TO CONTROL WEIGHT, AND IMPROVES BLOOD PRESSURE AND CHOLESTEROL LEVELS. OUR GOAL IS TO INCREASE THE PERCENT OF ADULTS WHO INDICATE A POSITIVE CHANGE IN PHYSICAL ACTIVITY BY 1% FOR EACH OF THE NEXT 5 YEARS. BASED ON THE NEW FOOD AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY QUESTIONNAIRE, OUR BASELINE TARGET IS 84%.  #4: INCREASE REACH OF YOUTH IN 6-8TH GRADES A PROGRAM PRIORITY OVER THE NEXT FIVE YEARS FOR WESTERN REGION EFNEP PROGRAMS, AND THUS OREGON EFNEP, ISTO SHIFT OUR YOUTH REACH TO FOCUS ON OLDER GRADES. TO CONTRIBUTE TO MEETING THIS GOAL, OREGON WILL INCREASE BY 1% EACH YEAR THE PERCENTAGE OF YOUTH REACHED IN 6-8TH GRADES. ACCORDING TO THE 2019 TIER DATA, OUR BASELINE FROM FFY2019 IS 55%.  OREGON EFNEP FOCUSES ON LOW-INCOME FAMILIES, WITH AN EMPHASIS ON PARENTS AND OTHER ADULT CAREGIVERS (I.E., GRANDPARENTS) WHO HAVE PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY FOR FEEDING YOUNG CHILDREN, PREGNANT TEENS, YOUTH AND SCHOOL-AGED CHILDREN. EMANCIPATED TEEN PARENTS ARE ANOTHER FOCUS AREA. EFNEP DOES NOT TARGET PRESCHOOL CHILDREN OR ELDERLY ADULTS. FOR ADULT AUDIENCES: WE WILL CONTINUE OUR ONGOING EFFORTS TO REACH OUT TO ADULT PARTICIPANTS IN THE COMMUNITIES WHERE THEY LIVE AND/OR IN COLLABORATION WITH OTHER AGENCIES SERVING LOW-INCOME FAMILIES. HISPANIC AUDIENCES, PARTICULARLY NEW MIGRANT FAMILIES, WILL CONTINUE TO BE A FOCUS POPULATION. SITES WHERE WE HAVE HAD THE MOST SUCCESS INCLUDE LOW-INCOME APARTMENT COMPLEXES, CHURCHES, PUBLIC HEALTH OFFICES, DOMESTIC VIOLENCE SHELTERS, FOOD BANKS/PANTRIES, SCHOOL SETTINGS (WHERE 50% OR MORE STUDENTS QUALIFY FOR FREE AND/OR REDUCED MEALS), AND AGENCY SITES (I.E., WIC, HEAD START). WE WILL CONTINUE TO RECRUIT AND ENROLL PARTICIPANTS THROUGH AGENCY REFERRALS, WORD-OF-MOUTH PARTICIPANT REFERRALS, AND DIRECT MARKETING TECHNIQUES. FOR YOUTH AUDIENCES: IN SCHOOL, CLASSROOM PROGRAMMING WILL FOCUS ON 3RD GRADE AND ABOVE. AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAMMING AND SUMMER PROGRAMMING WILL BE CONDUCTED IN SCHOOLS, HOUSING COMPLEX COMMUNITY ROOMS, PARK <(>&<)> RECREATION SETTINGS, CHURCHES, USDA SUMMER FOOD SITES, AND IN COLLABORATION WITH YOUTH-SERVING AGENCIES, I.E. BOYS AND GIRLS CLUBS. MULTIPLE AGE GROUPS PARTICIPATE IN AFTER-SCHOOL AND SUMMER CLASSES.

UC ANR EFNEP PROGRAM ABSTRACT DESCRIPTION <(>&<)> BENEFICIARIES  THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) PROVIDES FEDERAL FUNDING FOR SCIENCE-BASED OR EVIDENCE BASED ACTIVITIES TO ENABLE LOW-INCOME INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES TO ENGAGE IN NUTRITIONALLY SOUND FOOD PURCHASE AND PREPARATION PRACTICES. EFNEP IS AUTHORIZED BY SECTION 1425 OF THE NATIONAL AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH, EXTENSION, AND TEACHING POLICY ACT OF 1977 (7 U.S.C. 3175), AND APPROPRIATIONS ARE MADE AVAILABLE PURSUANT TO SECTION 3(D) OF THE SMITH-LEVER ACT.  UC AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES (UC ANR) MANAGES EFNEP IN 24 COUNTIES ACROSS CALIFORNIA. EFNEP DELIVERS RESEARCH-BASED NUTRITION EDUCATION TO LIMITED-RESOURCE FAMILIES WITH YOUNG CHILDREN TO ACQUIRE SKILLS, ATTITUDES, AND CHANGED BEHAVIORS NECESSARY FOR NUTRITIONALLY SOUND DIETS THAT CONTRIBUTE TO THEIR PERSONAL DEVELOPMENT AND NUTRITIONAL WELL-BEING. IN FFY2021, UC ANR’S EFNEP PROGRAMS HAD OVER 9 ,200 ENROLLED IN ITS EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS. ACTIVITIES <(>&<)> OUTCOMES UC COOPERATIVE EXTENSION (UCCE) ACADEMICS PROVIDED OVERSIGHT, LEADERSHIP, AND GUIDANCE FOR EFNEP STATEWIDE PROGRAMS. CURRICULA WERE SUCH AS MAKING EVERY DOLLAR COUNT (MEDC), EATING SMART BEING ACTIVE (ESBA), AND PLAN, SHOP, SAVE, AND COOK (PSSC) WERE DELIVERED TO HELP ADULT PARTICIPANTS GAIN THE TOOLS NEEDED TO TAKE CONTROL OF THEIR MONEY BY TEACHING FAMILIES FOOD BUYING/BUDGETING SKILLS AND FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES. THE CHALLENGES OF MEETING AMID COVID RESTRICTIONS HIGHLIGHTED THE STRENGTHS OF THE CALIFORNIA EFNEP PROGRAM IN ADAPTING TO THE NEEDS OF THE AUDIENCE IT SERVES. MANY PROGRAMS PIVOTED THEIR PROGRAMMING TO BE OFFERED ONLINE, WHICH HELPED MEET THE NEEDS OF FAMILIES AND COMMUNITY SAFETY. IN ALAMEDA AND CONTRA COSTA COUNTIES, FOR EXAMPLE, EFNEP EDUCATORS PROVIDED A NINE-PART VIRTUAL SERIES, UCCE CONNECTS TO YOU! IN ENGLISH AND SPANISH FOCUSED ON STRATEGIES TO STRETCH THE HOUSEHOLD FOOD BUDGET AND PROVIDED INFORMATION ON COVID-19 RELATED EMERGENCY FOODASSISTANCE PROGRAMS. THEY ALSO DEMONSTRATED RECIPES FOR THE FOOD ITEMS PARENTS RECEIVED AT THEIR LOCAL DISTRIBUTION PROGRAMS.  EFNEP EVALUATION RESULTS FROM FFY2021 FOUND THAT ADULT GRADUATES FROM THE PROGRAM STATEWIDE AVERAGED A $41.62 MONTHLY SAVINGS IN THEIR GROCERY BUDGET, WHICH EQUATING TO A $500 SAVINGS ANNUALLY. GIVEN THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC’S SIGNIFICANT DISRUPTION TO HOUSEHOLD FINANCES FROM CASCADING SHUTDOWNS AND LAYOFFS, THIS EXTRA MONEY MONTHLY MADE A DIFFERENCE. DURING FFY 2021, PROGRAM FAMILIES MADE STRIDES IN HEALTHY EATING KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND BEHAVIORS SUCH AS: - 84% OF ADULTS AND 57% OF YOUTH IMPROVED FOOD SAFETY, INCLUDING HAND-WASHING, CLEANING FOOD PREPARATION SURFACES, NOT THAWING FOOD AT ROOM TEMPERATURE, AND USING A MEAT THERMOMETER - 98% OF ADULTS AND 83% OF YOUTH IMPROVED DIET QUALITY, WITH 60% OF PARTICIPANTS CONSUMING MORE TYPES OF FRUITS AND VEGETABLES EACH DAY - 97% OF ADULTS AND 48% OF YOUTH PRACTICED FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, WITH 79% OF PARTICIPANTS REPORTING INCREASED SKILLS IN PLANNING MEALS, SHOPPING FOR SALE ITEMS, AND INVENTORYING THEIR FOOD SUPPLY BEFORE SHOPPING - 85% OF ADULTS AND 57% OF YOUTH INCREASED PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, WITH 66% OF PARTICIPANTS REPORTING THAT THEY EXERCISED FOR AT LEAST 30 MINUTES MORE DAYS PER WEEK AFTER PARTICIPATING IN EFNEP PROGRAMMING.

ABSTRACT: FY2023 EFNEP APPLICATION (THE UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA)  THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (UGA EFNEP) HELPS GEORGIA FAMILIES TO STRETCH THEIR FOOD DOLLARS, EAT BETTER FOR LESS, IMPROVE NUTRITION PRACTICES, AND PREVENT FOOD BORNE ILLNESS. FUNDED SINCE 1969 BY THE USDA NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF FOOD AND AGRICULTURE AND DELIVERED THROUGH THE UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA COOPERATIVE EXTENSION, EFNEP OFFERS PRACTICAL NUTRITION AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY INFORMATION, FOOD SAFETY EDUCATION, FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES, AND RECIPE DEMONSTRATIONS WITHIN COMMUNITY SETTINGS THROUGHOUT THE STATE. EFNEP INCLUDES PROGRAMMING TO A DIVERSE AUDIENCE OF ADULTS, YOUTH, AND CHILDREN WITH LIMITED-FINANCIAL RESOURCES. THE FOCUS SHOULD BE ON FAMILIES. SPECIFICALLY, EFNEP AUDIENCES INCLUDE LOW-INCOME PARENTS AND OTHER ADULT CAREGIVERS (SUCH AS GRANDPARENTS AND GUARDIANS) WHO HAVE PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY FOR OBTAINING AND PREPARING FOOD FOR THEIR CHILDREN, WITH EMPHASIS ON FAMILIES AND CAREGIVERS OF YOUNG CHILDREN AND LOW-INCOME PREGNANT WOMEN/TEENS. UGA EFNEP ALSO DELIVERS PROGRAMMING TO LOW-INCOME ADOLESCENT YOUTH (HIGH SCHOOL 9TH-12TH GRADE—AGES 14-19 YEARS). UGA EFNEP PEER EDUCATORS, WHO OFTEN LIVE IN THE COMMUNITIES THEY SERVE, DELIVER SERIES-BASED PROGRAMMING TO ELIGIBLE ADULTS AND YOUTH. THEY TEACH EVIDENCE-BASED NUTRITION CURRICULA DEPENDING ON THE AUDIENCE. (ADULT OR YOUTH) THAT INCLUDE INTERACTIVE LESSONS, RECIPE DEMONSTRATIONS AND EDUCATIONAL EXTENDERS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES FOR PARTICIPANTS INCLUDED: IMPROVEMENTS IN DIETARY QUALITY, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, FOOD SAFETY PRACTICES, FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, AND FOOD SECURITY, AS MEASURED BY VALIDATED FEDERAL SURVEYS PROVIDED PRE/POST PROGRAMMING (ADULT 30 QUESTION QUESTIONNAIRE, 9TH-12TH GRADE YOUTH NUTRITION SURVEY)

SOUTH DAKOTA COMMUNITIES NEED ASSISTANCE TO IDENTIFY STRATEGIES TO ADDRESS THE CHANGING SOCIAL, ENVIRONMENTAL, HUMAN, AND ECONOMIC L ANDSCAPE. ACCORDING TO THE US CENSUS BUREAU, THE U.S. AND SD ARE GROWING OLDER. CURRENTLY, 16.3% OF SOUTH DAKOTANS ARE AGE 65+. CHANGES TO MEET THE DEMANDS OF THIS AGING DEMOGRAPHIC ARE EXPECTED IN HEALTH AND WELLNESS; HOME AND WORK RELATIONSHIPS; AGRICULTURE; COMMUNITY LIFE AND THE ECONOMY. TOO MANY INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES ARE EXPERIENCING FINANCIAL CRISIS BECAUSE OF INADEQUATE SAVINGS AND TOO MUCH DEBT. RESEARCH AND EXTENSION STRATEGIES CAN ENHANCE FAMILY LIFE ISSUES SUCH AS BUILDING FINANCIAL SECURITY, COMMUNITY LEADERSHIP, YOUTH DEVELOPMENT, AND CONNECT INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES TO MENTAL AND EMOTIONAL SUPPORT RESOURCES.  HEART DISEASE, CANCER, STROKE, AND DIABETES ARE INCLUDED IN THE TOP LEADING SEVEN CAUSES OF DEATH IN SOUTH DAKOTA AND STRESSRELATED HEALTH PROBLEMS ARE ON THE RISE. LIVING A HEALTHY LIFESTYLE GREATLY REDUCES A PERSONS RISK FOR DEVELOPING CHRONIC DISEASE. LOCAL GARDENS, HIGHTUNNELS, AND GREENHOUSE FACILITIES HELP INCREASE FRUIT AND VEGETABLE CONSUMPTION IN THE STATE. AQUAPONICS, A SUSTAINABLE FOOD PRODUCTION METHOD THAT COMBINES ADVANCED AQUACULTURE WITH HYDROPONICS, IS ON THE RISE IN SD TO MEET THE NEED FOR MORE FRESH PRODUCE. NATURAL FERMENTATION PROCESSES REPLACE CHEMICAL ADDITIVES FOR EXTENDING SHELFLIFE OF FOODS AND BEVERAGES. RESEARCH AND EXTENSION STRATEGIES THAT PROMOTE DIETARY AND LIFESTYLE CHANGES CAN REDUCE THE INCIDENCE OF CHRONIC DISEASE ACROSS THE STATES POPULATION.

NJ EFNEP PROGRAM ABSTRACT ACCORDING TO THE JULY 2019 US CENSUS, IN NEW JERSEY (NJ), NEARLY 10% (817,161 OF 8,882,190) LIVE BELOW THE POVERTY LEVEL. OUT OF NJ’S 21 COUNTIES, NJ’S EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) SERVES THE 5 OF GREATEST NEED, I.E., CAMDEN, ESSEX, HUDSON, MIDDLESEX, AND PASSAIC COUNTIES, WHICH SERVE AS HOME TO 64.1% OF THE STATE’S IMPOVERISHED POPULATION. THE COUNTIES IN WHICH NJ EFNEP IS LOCATED HAS BEEN CHOSEN BASED ON THE NUMBER OF HOUSEHOLDS ENROLLED IN SNAP. DATA FROM MARCH 2020, RELEASED BY THE NJ DIVISION OF FAMILY DEVELOPMENT, SHOWED THEIR HOUSEHOLD SNAP ENROLLMENTS TO BE: 70,364, 59,142, 41,552, 39,218, AND 29,759 IN ESSEX, HUDSON, PASSAIC, CAMDEN AND MIDDLESEX COUNTIES, RESPECTIVELY. THE PASSAIC COUNTY OFFICE IN PATERSON CITY CLOSED IN MAY 2020, DUE TO THE LOSS OF THE PATERSON OFFICE. HOWEVER, IT IS IN THE PROGRAM’S BEST INTEREST TO CONTINUE TO SERVE PASSAIC COUNTY WITH PARAPROFESSIONALS FROM THE ESSEX COUNTY OFFICE LOCATION. GIVEN THESE RATES OF POVERTY, NOT SURPRISINGLY, THE MOST RECENT DATA FROM THE NJ HEALTH ASSESSMENT THERE ARE 865,900 PEOPLE, INCLUDING 260,340 CHILDREN, WHO WERE FOOD INSECURE. FURTHER, NJ’S UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS EXPERIENCED HUNGER AT TWO TO THREE TIMES THE RATE OF WHITE HOUSEHOLDS. NJ EFNEP OFFER NUTRITION EDUCATION CLASS SERIES’ TO HELP PEOPLE EAT BETTER AND GET MORE ACTIVE ON A BUDGET. THIS IS ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH CLASS SERIES’ OFFERED IN THE AFOREMENTIONED COMMUNITIES AT LOCATIONS, LIKE CHURCHES, JOB TRAINING PROGRAMS AND SCHOOLS, WHERE LOW-INCOME RESIDENTS CONGREGATE. AS OF JULY 2020, THE LARGEST RACE/ETHNICITIES SERVED WERE HISPANIC (58%) AND NON- HISPANIC BLACK (21%) AND 61% WERE WOMEN AND 39% WERE MEN. GIVEN NEW DATA THAT SUGGESTS UNDER-SERVED MINORITIES HAVE SUFFERED FROM COVID-19 MORE THAN OTHER POPULATIONS, NJ EFNEP WILL CONTINUE TO FOCUS ON THE HISPANIC AND NON-HISPANIC BLACK COMMUNITIES. SINCE MORE THAN 50% OF THE AUDIENCE REACHED THROUGH NJ EFNEP IS HISPANIC, CLASSES ARE TAUGHT IN BOTH ENGLISH AND SPANISH. PARTICIPANTS ARE TARGETED THROUGH COLLABORATIONS WITH OTHER AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS THAT OFFER PROGRAMMING TO LOW-INCOME INDIVIDUALS, IN WHICH SMALL GROUPS OF PARTICIPANTS CAN BE REACHED REPEATEDLY FOR A MINIMUM OF EIGHT TIMES, OVER A MINIMUM OF SIX WEEKS, FOR A MINIMUM OF 45 MINUTES. DUE TO OUR ABILITY TO REACH ADDITIONAL PARTICIPANTS USING TECHNOLOGICAL APPROACHES, NJ EFNEP WILL OFFER VIRTUAL PROGRAMMING OUTSIDE OF THE COUNTIES NJ EFNEP SERVES. ADULT GROUPS SERVED BY NJ EFNEP ARE SUPPOSED TO BE THOSE IN WHICH A MINIMUM OF 80% OF THE INDIVIDUALS ATTENDING ARE SELF-IDENTIFIED AS EITHER LOW-INCOME PARENTS/CAREGIVERS, PREGNANT WOMEN, OR YOUTH. HOWEVER, DURING THE 2015-2019 FEDERAL FISCAL YEARS (FFYS), NJ EFNEP REACHED AN EXCESSIVE PERCENTAGE OF ADULTS WHO EITHER DID NOT HAVE CHILDREN OR WHO WERE NOT PREGNANT. TO DEAL WITH THIS ISSUE WORK UNIT SUPERVISORS HAVE RE-EXAMINED THE SITES WITH WHICH THEY CURRENTLY PARTNER AND THEY HAVE REMOVED OR RENEGOTIATED WITH SITES THAT CONSISTENTLY FAILED TO DELIVER THE APPROPRIATE ADULT TARGET AUDIENCE. THEY HAVE PUT EXTENSIVE EFFORT INTO IDENTIFYING ADDITIONAL ADULT SITES THAT MORE EXCLUSIVELY SERVE THE NJ EFNEP TARGET AUDIENCE. IN THE PAST 3 YEARS, WE HAVE INCREASED THE PERCENTAGE OF ADULTS WITH CHILDREN OR WHO ARE PREGNANT FROM 67% TO EXCEED THE REQUIRED 80%, (I.E., TO 85%). THIS YEAR WE PLAN TO CONTINUE TO INCREASE THE PERCENTAGE OF THESE ADULTS REACHED TO 86% OF OUR TOTAL ADULT POPULATION. PROGRESS WILL BE MEASURED THROUGH AN EXAMINATION OF THE DATA REGARDING THE NUMBER OF PARTICIPANTS WITH CHILDREN OR WHO ARE  PREGNANT, WHICH IS FOUND IN THE DISTRIBUTION OF HOUSEHOLD CHILDREN SECTION OF THE ADULT SUMMARY REPORT IN WEBNEERS (THE EFNEP REPORTING SYSTEM). ONE OF THE LARGEST NUTRITION ISSUES AMONG OUR AUDIENCE IS LOW VEGETABLE INTAKE. THE CDC HAS STATED THAT ONLY 8.3% OF ADULTS IN NJ MEET THEIR DAILY VEGETABLE INTAKE RECOMMENDATION. THUS, THIS IS ONE OF THE ISSUES NJ EFNEP IS INTENT ON ADDRESSING. MANY OF OUR PARTICIPANTS RECEIVE VEGETABLES FROM FOOD PANTRIES THAT ARE NOT COMMONLY USED BY THEIR CULTURES AND, CONSEQUENTLY, THEY DO NOT KNOW HOW TO PREPARE THEM, AND THEY ARE NOT CONSUMED. TO INCREASE THIS PERCENTAGE, PARAPROFESSIONALS WILL FOCUS EDUCATION ON THIS AREA AND EMPHASIZE THE IMPORTANCE OF INCREASING VEGETABLE INTAKE AND INCORPORATE TASTE-TESTING OF NJ EFNEP RECIPES, WHICH INCLUDE A VARIETY OF VEGETABLES FOUND IN FOOD PANTRIES. PARTICIPANTS WILL ALSO BE INSTRUCTED TO GO TO THE EFNEPHELPS.ORG WEBSITE WHERE THEY CAN FIND QUICK, EASY, AND LOW-COST RECIPES WHICH INCORPORATE A VARIETY OF VEGETABLES FOUND AT FOOD PANTRIES. TEACHING OBSERVATIONS ARE CONDUCTED BY THE PROFESSIONAL STAFF WHO EVALUATE THE PARAPROFESSIONALS’ WORK AND PROVIDE THEM WITH FEEDBACK. IF NECESSARY ADDITIONAL TRAINING FOR THE EFFECTIVE DELIVERY OF THIS TOPIC IS PROVIDED. IN FFY 2019 OUR DATA SHOWED THAT 49% OF THE ADULT PARTICIPANTS SERVED BY NJ EFNEP ATE VEGETABLES MORE OFTEN EACH DAY. LAST YEAR 89% OF NJ EFNEP CLASSES WERE CONDUCTED VIRTUALLY, HENCE PARAPROFESSIONALS WERE NOT ABLE TO INCORPORATE THE TASTE-TESTING COMPONENT IN THEIR CLASSES, AND DATA SHOWED THAT ONLY 38% OF ADULT PARTICIPANTS ATE VEGETABLES MORE OFTEN EACH DAY. THIS YEAR MANY OF THE NJ EFNEP SITES ARE REQUESTING IN PERSON CLASSES, THEREFORE TASTE-TESTING WILL ONCE AGAIN BE INCORPORATED IN THE LESSONS, AND EFFORTS WILL CONTINUE TO INCREASE PERCENTAGE ADULTS WHO MORE OFTEN EAT VEGETABLES EACH DAY TO 51%. PROGRESS WILL BE MEASURED THROUGH EXAMINATION OF THE DATA WHICH IS FOUND IN THE “3.02 EAT VEGETABLES MORE OFTEN EACH DAY” SECTION OF THE EFNEP ADULT FOOD AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY BEHAVIOR QUESTIONNAIRE FOUND IN THE ADULT QUESTIONNAIRE SUMMARY REPORT IN WEBNEERS.  ANOTHER ISSUE AMONG NJ RESIDENTS AND CONSEQUENTLY ONE ON WHICH NJ EFNEP WILL WORK, IS PHYSICAL ACTIVITY. THE MOST RECENT DATA FROM THE NJ DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH (2017) INDICATED THAT THE PERCENTAGE OF PEOPLE WHO MET THE RECOMMENDED LEVEL OF PHYSICAL ACTIVITY IN THE TOTAL POPULATIONWAS 49.2%, WITH BLACKS AND HISPANICS ONLY BEING ACTIVE 41.3% AND 41.2%, RESPECTIVELY. THERE ARE LIKELY MANY REASONS FOR THIS ISSUE. MANY LOW-INCOME RESIDENTS LIVE IN UNSAFE AREAS AND DO NOT HAVE THE MEANS TO JOIN A GYM. OTHERS LIVE IN SMALL APARTMENTS WITH LITTLE SPACE FOR ACTIVITY AND THEY DO NOT HAVE THE NECESSARY EQUIPMENT TO PARTICIPATE IN PHYSICAL ACTIVITY. TO INCREASE THE PERCENTAGE OF ADULTS WHO IMPROVE THEIR PHYSICAL ACTIVITY BEHAVIORS, PARAPROFESSIONALS USE THE WALK INDOORS! DVD TO INCORPORATE A DIFFERENT PHYSICAL ACTIVITY SEGMENT, ALL WALKING INDOORS BUT SOMETIMES USING HOUSEHOLD OBJECTS FOR WEIGHTS OR DOING INTERVALS, ETC., IN EACH OF THE ADULT LESSONS. PARAPROFESSIONALS ALSO DIRECT PARTICIPANTS TO THE EFNEPHELPS.ORG WEBSITE WHERE THEY CAN ACCESS THE VIDEOS AND CONTINUE THEIR PHYSICAL ACTIVITY ROUTINE WITH THEIR FAMILIES IN THE COMFORT OF THEIR HOMES AT NO COST. IN FFY 2019 NJ EFNEP PARTICIPANTS’ PHYSICAL ACTIVITY RATE WAS LOW (74%) COMPARED TO THE NATIONAL DATA AVERAGE (78%). LAST YEAR 67% OF ADULT PARTICIPANTS SHOWED IMPROVEMENT IN ONE OR MORE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY BEHAVIORS. THIS YEAR EFFORTS WILL CONTINUE TO INCREASE THIS PERCENTAGE UNTIL THE NATIONAL DATA AVERAGE OF 78% HAS BEEN MET. PROGRESS WILL BE MEASURED THROUGH EXAMINATION OF THE DATA WHICH  IS FOUND IN THE “1.3 PHYSICAL ACTIVITY” SECTION OF THE EFNEP ADULT FOOD AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY BEHAVIOR QUESTIONNAIRE IN THE ADULT QUESTIONNAIRE SUMMARY REPORT OF WEBNEERS. OF NOTE, COMPLETION OF THE PROGRAM WITHIN THE ADULT PARTICIPANTS IS OFTEN CHALLENGING. MANY TIMES, PARTICIPANTS CANNOT ATTEND CLASSES DUE TO WEATHER CONDITIONS, LACK OF TRANSPORTATION, AND THE INABILITY TO FIND CHILDCARE, WHICH RESULTS IN LOW NJ EFNEP COURSE SERIES’ COMPLETION RATES. IN FFY 2019 ONLY 55% OF THE ADULTS WHO STARTED AN NJ EFNEP CLASS SERIES COMPLETED IT. WHEREAS, THE NATIONAL DATA AVERAGE FOR EFNEP COMPLETION IN OTHER STATES IS 67%. TO INCREASE THE RATE OF ADULT GRADUATION IN NJ, PROFESSIONAL STAFF HAVE CREATED INTERACTIVE, LIVE, VIRTUAL EDUCATION AND TRAINED THE PARAPROFESSIONALS TO DELIVER EDUCATION VIA ZOOM. LAST YEAR NJ EFNEP ADULT GRADUATION RATE IMPROVED TO 62%. THIS YEAR WE PLAN TO CONTINUE TO INCREASE THE ADULT GRADUATION RATES BY AN ADDITIONAL 2%. PROGRESS WILL BE MEASURED THROUGH EXAMINATION OF THE DATA REGARDING WHO COMPLETED THE PROGRAM, FOUND IN THE STATUS OF PARTICIPANTS SECTION OF THE ADULT SUMMARY REPORT IN WEBNEERS. WHILE MUCH OF NJ EFNEP’S EFFORTS FOCUSES ON ADULTS, AS THEY ARE CHIEFLY RESPONSIBLE FOR THEIR FAMILIES’ DIETARY INTAKE, OUR SECONDARY TARGET AUDIENCES WILL BE HIGH SCHOOL-AGED TEENS AND EMERGENT ADULTS (I.E., RECENT HIGH SCHOOL GRADUATES) SINCE THEY MAKE A SUBSTANTIAL NUMBER OF THEIR OWN DECISIONS. IN FFY 2022 THE TOTAL NUMBER OF YOUTH SERVED BY NJ EFNEP WAS 1,068. OF THIS TOTAL, ONLY 28% WERE HIGH SCHOOLERS. IN THE NEXT YEAR NJ EFNEP PLANS TO INCREASE THIS PERCENTAGE. PROGRESS WILL BE MEASURED ACCORDING TO THE DATA WHICH IS FOUND IN THE GRADE DISTRIBUTION SECTION OF THE YOUTH SUMMARY REPORT IN WEBNEERS. WHEN WORKING WITH ADOLESCENTS IT IS IMPORTANT TO UNDERSTAND THAT ONE OF THEIR PRIMARY NUTRITION ISSUES IS A HIGH INTAKE OF SUGAR-SWEETENED BEVERAGES. WHILE IT HAS DECREASED SOMEWHAT, THEIR INTAKE REMAINS HIGH. TO DECREASE THE PERCENTAGE OF OUR ADOLESCENT PARTICIPANTS WHO REGULARLY CONSUME SUGAR-SWEETENED BEVERAGES, PARAPROFESSIONALS UNIVERSALLY TEACH INTERACTIVE, HANDS-ON, AND FUN LESSONS FROM THE REV IT UP! TEEN CURRICULUM THAT ARE PERTINENT TO THIS BEHAVIOR CHANGE. IN FFY 2019, THE NJ EFNEP YOUTH SUMMARY REPORTS DATA INDICATED THAT 29% OF PROGRAM HIGH SCHOOL AGED ADOLESCENTS, IMPROVED IN THEIR RESPONSES TO THE QUESTION “YESTERDAY, HOW MANY SUGARY DRINKS DID YOU DRINK?” LAST YEAR DATA REFLECTED THAT 43% OF THE HIGH SCHOOLERS REACHED IMPROVED IN THEIR RESPONSES TO THIS QUESTION. THIS YEAR NJ EFNEP WILL CONTINUE EFFORTS TO INCREASE THESE PERCENTAGE OF HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS WHO DECREASE THEIR SUGAR-SWEETENED BEVERAGE INTAKE BY 1% PER YEAR. PROGRESS WILL BE MEASURED THROUGH EXAMINATION OF THE DATA WHICH IS FOUND IN QUESTION #4 ON THE 9-12 SURVEY FOUND IN THE YOUTH QUESTIONNAIRE SUMMARY REPORT OF WEBNEERS. IN ADDITION TO THE WORK NJ EFNEP DOES WITH INDIVIDUALS, OUR PROFESSIONAL STAFF ENGAGE IN NATIONAL COLLABORATIONS TO ENHANCE PROGRAMMING. THE EFNEP COORDINATORS IN THE NORTHEAST REGION MEET ON A REGULAR BASIS TO WORK TOGETHER TOWARDS SUCH IMPROVEMENTS. IN TERMS OF COLLABORATIONS WITHIN NJ, PROFESSIONAL LEVEL STAFF WILL ATTEND THE NJ CENTER FOR FOOD AND ACTION'S NJ FOOD FOR THOUGHT CAMPAIGN MEETINGS WHERE THEY WILL PARTICIPATE IN NETWORKING OPPORTUNITIES TO MEET IMPORTANT STATE ENTITIES AND INCREASE VISIBILITY OF OUR PROGRAM.  IN FFY 2022, THE SR. PROJECT ADMINISTRATOR JOINED THE NJ DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH'S HEALTHY 2030: HEALTHY EATING AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY ACTION TEAM, WHOSE CHARGE IT WAS TO ENSURE ACTIVITIES THAT HELP MEET THE STATE'S 2030 HEALTHY PEOPLE OBJECTIVES. IN THESE MEETINGS COLLABORATIONS WERE EXPANDED, AS THEY HAVE BEEN BY STAFF ATTENDING MORE HEALTH FAIRS. THESE COLLABORATION GENERATING OPPORTUNITIES WILL CONTINUE. ONE EXAMPLE OF THE COLLABORATIONS ESTABLISHED WAS ONE WITH THE MAYOR OF PATERSON. NJ EFNEP IS COLLABORATING AS PART OF THE MAYOR’S WELLNESS CAMPAIGN. CAMPAIGN ACTIVITIES TO BE CONDUCTED WERE PUT ON HOLD DUE TO COVID, BUT NEW EFFORTS ARE ON THE WAY, WITH SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES YET TO BE DETERMINED. TO FURTHER LOCAL COLLABORATIONS IN THE UPCOMING YEARS, NJ EFNEP WILL BE CONDUCTING COMMUNITY MAPPING TO IDENTIFY NEW PARTNERS, AND ATTENDING SCHOOL BOARD MEETINGS, COUNTY SUPERINTENDENT ROUND TABLE, COUNTY COUNCIL AND COMMISSIONS, AND MUNICIPAL ALLIANCES.

REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA EFNEP PROJECT ABSTRACT FEDERAL AWARD PURPOSE THE EXPAND FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) PROVIDES DIRECT NUTRITION EDUCATION TO ELIGIBLE PARENTS AND CAREGIVERS OF CHILDREN, AND ELIGIBLE YOUTH IN 3RD-12TH GRADES. IN MINNESOTA, EFNEP IS OFFERED IN A 4-COUNTY METRO REGION. OBJECTIVES, METHODS, AND ACTIVITIES EFNEP’S 5 CORE COMPETENCIES OF DIET QUALITY, FOOD SAFETY, FOOD SECURITY, FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY ARE DELIVERED USING A PARAPROFESSIONAL MODEL WHERE EDUCATORS SHARE SOCIO-CULTURAL CHARACTERISTICS OF THE POPULATIONS THEY WORK WITH. UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA EXTENSION USED EFNEP FUNDS SOLELY FOR PROGRAMMING; PER LEGISLATIVE MANDATE, AT LEAST 51% OF FUND SUPPORT PAR APROFESSIONALS WHO TEACH IN COMMUNITY SITES, EITHER IN PERSON OR REMOTELY.  THE DIVERSITY OF THE TWIN CITIES METRO IS REFLECTED IN EFNEP’S STAFF, WITH EDUCATORS FROM HMONG, LATINO, AMERICAN INDIAN, AND HISTORICAL BLACK POPULATIONS. MINNESOTA EFNEP’S ROBUST EVALUATION MEASURES OF PAIRED PRE-POST DIET RECALL AND FOOD BEHAVIOR QUESTIONNAIRES USE AN AUDIO/VISUAL APP IN 5 LANGUAGES.  CLASSES ARE 1 TO 2 HOURS LONG, OCCUR WEEKLY OVER 6 TO 8 WEEKS, AND EMPHASIZE HEALTHY FOOD PREPARATION SKILLS. INTENDED AUDIENCE AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES AS LIFESTYLE-RELATED CHRONIC DISEASES ARE ON THE RISE, MINNESOTA EFNEP USES CULTURALLY RELEVANT EDUCATION TO EQUIP PARTICIPANTS WITH THE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS TO MAKE BEHAVIOR CHANGES LEADING TO BETTER HEALTH FOR THEMSELVES AND THEIR FAMILIES.  EACH YEAR, MINNESOTA EFNEP REACHES ~800 UNIQUE ADULT PARTICIPANTS AND ~1,500 YOUTH PARTICIPANTS. THE INTENDED AUDIENCE IS LOW-WEALTH, UNDER-RESOURCED YOUTH AND FAMILIES IN THE TWIN CITIES METRO, WITH EMPHASIS ON NEW IMMIGRANT, REFUGEE POPULATIONS, AS WELL AS OTHER MARGINALIZED GROUPS, INCLUDING HISTORICAL BLACK AND AMERICAN INDIAN POPULATIONS.

UNIVERSITY OF MAINE COOPERATIVE EXTENSION  THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) IS THE FIRST FEDERAL NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM FOR LOW-INCOME POPULATIONS. THE GOAL OF EFNEP IS TO IMPROVE KNOWLEDGE AND BEHAVIOR IN FOUR PRIORITY AREAS OF ELIGIBLE ADULTS AND YOUTH AFTER PROGRAM PARTICIPATION. THE FOUR PRIORITY AREAS ARE: 1) DIET QUALITY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, 2) FOOD SAFETY, 3) FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT (FRM), AND 4) FOOD SECURITY.  FEDERAL FUNDS DISTRIBUTED TO 1862 AND 1890 LAND GRANT INSTITUTIONS ARE USED TO DELIVER EVIDENCE BASED, INTERACTIVE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS THAT ARE TAUGHT USING PARAPROFESSIONALS. THE AUDIENCE ELIGIBLE TO PARTICIPATE IN EFNEP ARE LOW-INCOME ADULTS WITH CHILDREN IN THE HOUSEHOLD, LOW-INCOME YOUNG ADULTS, AND LOW-INCOME YOUTH AGED 5 TO 18 YEARS. AFTER PARTICIPATING IN EFNEP, ADULT AND YOUTH PARTICIPANT SELF-REPORTED BEHAVIOR CHANGES ARE ASSESSED AND REPORTED TO LOCAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL PARTNERS.

PROJECT ABSTRACT FOR SMITH LEVER EFNEP CAPACITY GRANT UNIVERSITY OF WYOMING EXTENSION THE DESCRIPTION AND PURPOSE OF THE FEDERAL AWARD IS TO PROVIDE EFNEP PROGRAMMING IN WYOMING. WYOMING EFNEP PROMOTES HEALTHY BEHAVIORS FOR ELIGIBLE ADULTS AND YOUTH RESULTING IN BETTER NUTRITION, INCREASED PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND IMPROVED OVERALL HEALTH. WYOMING EFNEP FOCUSES ON IMPROVING DIET QUALITY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY CONSISTENT WITH CURRENT DIETARY GUIDELINES FOR AMERICANS AND MYPLATE USING A SERIES OF LESSONS. THE LESSONS ALSO INCORPORATE FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, FOOD SAFETY AND FOOD SECURITY. THROUGH THE SERIES OF LESSONS, WYOMING EFNEP EMPOWERS THE LOW-INCOME FAMILY AND INDIVIDUAL TO IMPROVE THEIR HEALTH AND WELL-BEING. WYOMING EFNEP PARTNERS WITH OTHER AGENCIES TO INCREASE REFERRALS ACROSS PROGRAMS, ORGANIZATIONS, AND COMMUNITIES TO ADDRESS PARTICIPANT NEEDS WITH THE GOAL OF INCREASING COORDINATION, COOPERATION AND COLLABORATION TO ACCOMPLISH STATE AND LOCAL PRIORITIES. EFNEP’S TARGET ADULT AUDIENCE IS DEFINED AS LOW-INCOME FAMILIES WITH AN EMPHASIS ON PARENTS AND OTHER ADULT CAREGIVERS WITH PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY FOR FEEDING YOUNG CHILDREN; PREGNANT TEENS, YOUTH, AND CHILDREN. PRIMARY RECRUITMENT LOCATIONS IN WYOMING INCLUDE THE LOCAL DEPARTMENT OF FAMILY SERVICES OFFICES, WIC OFFICES, COUNSELING AND REHABILITATION CENTERS, FOOD BANKS, LOW-INCOME HOUSING COMMUNITY CENTERS, GROCERY STORES IN LOW-INCOME AREAS, LOW-INCOME SCHOOLS, AND OTHER COMMUNITY AGENCIES SERVING LIMITED RESOURCE AUDIENCES. REFERRALS FROM THESE AND OTHER AGENCIES THAT SERVE THE TARGET AUDIENCE ARE ALSO ENCOURAGED. THE PROGRAM IS OPEN TO LIMITED-INCOME (ESTABLISHED BY FEDERAL POVERTY GUIDELINES) INDIVIDUALS WITH CHILDREN, AND PREGNANT WOMEN AND TEENS WHO SHOP FOR AND PREPARE FOOD FOR CHILDREN ON A REGULAR BASIS. A FAMILY ENROLLED IN ANY OTHER FEDERAL NUTRITION PROGRAM IS ALSO ELIGIBLE FOR EFNEP (FOR EXAMPLE, THOSE USING WIC, SNAP, TANF, FREE/REDUCED SCHOOL MEALS, HEADSTART, ETC.). YOUTH AUDIENCES INCLUDELIMITED RESOURCE CHILDREN OF ELIGIBLE ADULT PARTICIPANTS, OR STUDENTS IN TITLE I (LOW INCOME) SCHOOLS THAT HAVE 50% OR GREATER FREE AND REDUCED LUNCH PARTICIPATION. THE TARGET AUDIENCE IS REACHED THROUGH RECRUITMENT AND DEMONSTRATIONS AT AGENCIES SERVING LOW-INCOME INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES. RECRUITING AND DEMONSTRATING LESSONS AT SITES AND LOCATIONS THAT THE TARGET AUDIENCE FREQUENTS IS A MEANS OF BOTH REACHING POTENTIAL PARTICIPANTS WHO ARE ELIGIBLE FOR THE PROGRAM, AND ALSO ENGAGING THEM IN A WAY THAT HELPS TO BUILD RAPPORT TO INCREASE CHANCES OF FULL PARTICIPATION AND GRADUATION. RECRUITMENT'S AND DEMONSTRATIONS AT PARTNERING AGENCIES ALSO ASSIST IN BUILDING PARTNERSHIPS AND COLLABORATIONS IN ORDER TO BETTER REACH LOW-INCOME FAMILIES IN THE COMMUNITIES SERVED BY EFNEP. EFNEP SERVES THE MOST DENSELY POPULATED COUNTIES IN WYOMING, WHICH ARE LARAMIE AND NATRONA. THE CORE ISSUES ADDRESSED BY EFNEP PROGRAMMING ARE DIET QUALITY, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, FOOD SAFETY, AND FOOD SECURITY. PRIORITY ISSUES TO BE ADDRESSED BY WYOMING EFNEP IN THE FIVE-YEAR PLAN (FFY2020-2024) ARE: 1. INCREASE THE PERCENT OF 6-8TH GRADE YOUTH REACHED USING A CURRICULUM ADDRESSING DIET QUALITY, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, AND FOOD SAFETY. 2. INCREASE VEGETABLE INTAKE OF ADULT PARTICIPANTS 3. USE OF PRE-RECORDED MAKE-UP LESSONS THAT ADDRESS THE CORE AREAS TO INCREASE THE ADULT GRADUATION RATE. 4. INCREASE VEGETABLE INTAKE OF 3-5TH GRADE YOUTH PARTICIPANTS. 5. ADULT PARTICIPANTS WILL USE A MEAT THERMOMETER MORE OFTEN.   OUTCOME DATA IS REPORTED ANNUALLY THROUGH THE EFNEP NATIONAL WEBNEERS SYSTEM.

UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS - FISCAL YEAR: 2023 EFNEP’S MAIN GOAL IS TO ADDRESS HEALTH ISSUES FOR FAMILIES LIVING IN POVERTY BY PROVIDING EDUCATION FOCUSED ON DIETARY QUALITY, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, AND ACCESS TO FOOD. THE BEHAVIOR CHANGE PRECIPITATED BY EFNEP CREATES LASTING CHANGES THAT ADDRESS THE HEALTH INEQUITIES THAT ARE COMPOUNDED BY LOW SOCIO- ECONOMIC STATUS. DATA TRENDS CONTINUE TO SHOW THAT CHILDREN, WOMEN, AND MINORITY (BLACK, AND HISPANIC WHITE) POPULATIONS ARE DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED BY POVERTY, FOOD INSECURITY, AND CORRESPONDINGLY HIGHER RATES OF CHRONIC DISEASE INCLUDING OBESITY. AS A RESULT, EFNEP WILL FOCUS ON THESE POPULATIONS IN THE NEXT 5-YEAR PLAN. SOURCES: COUNTY HEALTH RANKINGS, COUNTY HEALTH RANKINGS <(>&<)> ROADMAPS, WWW.COUNTYHEALTHRANKINGS.ORG/, CONTENT: POVERTY HEARTLANDALLIANCE.ORG TARGET AUDIENCE  THE TARGET AUDIENCES FOR EFNEP IN ILLINOIS ARE LOW-INCOME PARENTS WITH YOUNG CHILDREN, CAREGIVERS OF THOSE YOUNG CHILDREN, AND LOW-INCOME YOUTH 3RD – 12 GRADES. GEOGRAPHIC AREA  CHAMPAIGN COUNTY, COOK COUNTY, MADISON COUNTY, ST. CLAIR COUNTY, VERMILION COUNTY. PRIORITIES  #1 INCREASE ADULT GRADUATION RATES, #2 INCREASE FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, #3 IMPROVE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, #4 INCREASE TEEN PROGRAM REACH CURRICULA  ADULT: EATING SMART MOVING MORE, HEALTH CHILDREN HEALTHY FAMILIES, PREGNANT TEENS: EAT SMART, MOVE MORE, GRADES K-2: HEALTH KIDS OUT OF SCHOOL, GRADES 3-5: CHOOSE HEALTH: FUN, FOOD <(>&<)> FITNESS, GRADES 6- 8: ILLINOIS JUNIOR CHEF, GRADES 9-12: TEEN CUISINE, AROUND THE TABLE. PROGRAM IMPACT  BACKGROUND DURING THE PANDEMIC, WE STARTED TO FOCUS ON STAFF TRAINING THAT WOULD ASSIST THE PEER EDUCATORS IN RECOGNIZING FAMILY NEED AND BEING ABLE TO EMPOWER FAMILIES TO MAKE DECISIONS FOR RESOURCES AND CHANGES THAT WOULD HAVE A POSITIVE IMPACT. OUTCOMES / IMPACTS OVER THE COURSE OF THE PAST YEAR, ALL STAFF IN EFNEP HAVE TAKEN THE FAMILY DEVELOPMENT COURSE. THE RESULTS HAVE BEEN NOTICEABLE WHERE THE PEER EDUCATORS HAVE A MUCH BROADER UNDERSTANDING OF THE COMMUNITY WHERE THEY WORK AND HOW TO EMPOWER FAMILIES TO ADVOCATE FOR THEMSELVES AND THE RESOURCES THEY NEED. THE STAFF HAVE LEARNED TO LISTEN TO THEMSELVES, EACH OTHER, AND THE PARTICIPANTS. THIS LISTENING HAS TAKEN OUR ABILITY TO CONNECT WITH FAMILIES TO A NEW LEVEL.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY  TENNESSEES TWO LAND-GRANT INSTITUTIONS COMPRISE THE TENNESSEE AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH AND EXTENSION SYSTEM. THEY WORK INDEPENDENTLY AND COLLABORATIVELY TO CONDUCT RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS IN ALL 95 COUNTIES AND TO SERVE THE STATES 6.9 MILLION PEOPLE. THE UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE IS BASED IN KNOXVILLE AND SERVES AS THE STATES 1862 INSTITUTION. IT INCLUDES THE UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE EXTENSION (UT EXTENSION) AND THE TENNESSEE AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION (UT AGRESEARCH). BASED IN NASHVILLE, TENNESSEE STATE UNIVERSITY (TSU) IS THE STATES 1890 INSTITUTION; IT INCLUDES THE TSU COOPERATIVE EXTENSION PROGRAM AND THE TSU INSTITUTE FOR FOOD, AGRICULTURE AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESEARCH. THIS PLAN OF WORK REPRESENTS THE COMBINED EFFORTS OF UT EXTENSION, UT AGRESEARCH, TSU COOPERATIVE EXTENSION PROGRAM, AND THE TSU INSTITUTE FOR FOOD, AGRICULTURE AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESEARCH.  AGRICULTURE IS INTEGRAL TO TENNESSEES ECONOMY AND CULTURE. ALMOST ONE OF EVERY EIGHT TO NINE DOLLARS GENERATED IN THE STATE IS ASSOCIATED WITH AGRICULTURE OR AN INDUSTRY THAT GENERATES PRODUCTS FROM A NATURAL RESOURCE - MORE THAN $79.3 BILLION ANNUALLY. THE STATES AGRICULTURAL AND RELATED EXPORTS TOTALED $2.2 BILLION IN 2021, UP $325 MILLION OR 17% WHEN COMPARED TO 2020. TENNESSEE EXPERIENCED INCREASES IN ALL MAJOR COMMODITY CATEGORIES IN 2021. FARM RECEIPTS TOTALED $3.6 BILLION, WITH APPROXIMATELY 65.5% OF THIS VALUE COMING FROM CROPS AND 34.5% FROM ANIMALS AND ANIMAL PRODUCTS. IN ADDITION TO THE ECONOMIC SUCCESSES OF TENNESSEE AGRICULTURE, 339,400 TENNESSEANS ARE DIRECTLY EMPLOYED BY AGRICULTURAL OR NATURAL RESOURCE INDUSTRIES, MAKING EFFECTIVE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS CRITICAL. TENNESSEES LAND-GRANT INSTITUTIONS CONDUCT RESEARCH AND PROVIDE EXTENSION OUTREACH IN FIVE KEY AREAS TO ADDRESS CRITICAL ISSUES AFFECTING THE STATE: SUPPORTING FOOD, FIBER, AND ENERGY SYSTEMS; ENHANCING BIODIVERSITY AND ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; ENRICHING OUR ECONOMY; DEVELOPING OUR WORKFORCE; ANDSTRENGTHENING OUR HEALTH. RESEARCH PROJECTS PROVIDE NEW KNOWLEDGE TO HELP STAKEHOLDERS ADDRESS ISSUES THAT AFFECT THEM. EXTENSION ACTIVITIES SHARE THAT KNOWLEDGE WITH STAKEHOLDERS ULTIMATELY TO RESULT IN A CHANGE IN ACTION OR CONDITION.  EXTENSION WILL CONTINUE TO PROVIDE PROGRAMS TO ADDRESS THE ONGOING NEEDS CITIZENS AND AGRICULTURE PRODUCERS ACROSS THE STATE. HEALTH ISSUES CONTINUE TO BE TOP CONCERNS FOR RESIDENTS. EXTENSION WILL STRENGTHEN HEALTH PROGRAMMING BY OFFERING THE HEALTH AND NUTRITION PROGRAMS AND PROVIDE RESOURCES FOR IMPROVING DIETARY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY FOR LIMITED-RESOURCE TENNESSEANS. EXTENSION LIVESTOCK AND FORAGE PROGRAMS STRENGTHEN OUR EXTENSION AND RESEARCH FOR THE STATES LIVESTOCK PRODUCERS, RESEARCHERS AND EXTENSION PERSONNEL WILL JOINTLY IMPLEMENT RESEARCH AND OUTREACH IN HAY SCHOOLS, LATE GESTATION NUTRITION, MARKETING, FORAGE TESTING, AND STOCKPILED FORAGES. TENNESSEE EXTENSION HAS DEVELOPED PROGRAMS TO STRENGTHEN AND PROVIDE VALUE-ADDED OPPORTUNITIES FORPRODUCERS.THE UT CENTER FOR FARM MANAGEMENT WAS ESTABLISHED IN THE DEPT. OF AGRICULTURE AND RESOURCE ECONOMICS IN 2022. THE CENTER FACILITATES EXTENSION, TEACHING, AND RESEARCH PROGRAMS ON FARM FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT. THE CENTER WILL FOCUS ON MEETING THE NEEDS OF TENNESSEE PRODUCERS AND ENHANCING LONG-TERM PROFITABILITY AND SUSTAINABILITY OF AGRICULTURE ENTERPRISES. THROUGH THE CROPS PRODUCTION SYSTEMS EXTENSIONS PROVIDE DEMONSTRATION AND TRANSLATIONAL RESEARCH PROJECTS THAT BENEFITS PRODUCERS. THE CROP VARIETY TRIALS FOR CORN GRAIN, SILAGE, AND SOYBEANS AS WELL AS PRODUCER EDUCATION PROGRAMS FOR CORN, SOYBEANS, COTTON, WHEAT, AND TOBACCO PRODUCTION ARE KEY AREAS. THE CONSUMER ECONOMICS PROGRAM HELPS FAMILIES INCREASE SAVINGS, DECREASE DEBT, AND FINANCIALLY PLAN. THE ON MY OWN  AND 4-H WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMS ARE DESIGNED FOR YOUTH AND ADULTS THAT PROVIDE NEEDED SKILLS, TRAININGS, AND EXPERIENCES TO PARTICIPANTS. WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMS WILL CONTINUE TO BE OF TOP PRIORITYFOR EXTENSION.  EXTENSION CONTINUES DEVELOP PROGRAMS TO ENCOURAGE AND PROVIDE YOUTH DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES. THE NEXT CHAPTER PROGRAM IS A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN THE OFFICE OF ADMISSIONS AND TENNESSEE 4-H. IN CREATING THIS PROGRAM, WE WANT TO CREATE AN EARLY DISCUSSION AROUND WHAT SKILLS ARE NECESSARY FOR STUDENTS TO BE SUCCESSFUL IN BOTH THEIR SECONDARY AND POSTSECONDARY PLANS. 4-H CONTINUES PROGRAMING ON HONING STEM AND CITIZENSHIP/LEADERSHIP SKILLS.  UT AGRESEARCH CONDUCTS RESEARCH WITHIN ITS EIGHT ACADEMIC DEPARTMENTS AND SEVEN PHYSICAL CENTERS, AND AT TEN AGRESEARCH AND EDUCATION CENTERS (REC) LOCATED THROUGHOUT THE STATE. THESE UNITS HELP DRIVE PLANNED RESEARCH PROGRAMS AND FACILITATE FACULTY RESEARCH PROJECTS. IN ADDITION TO A DECADE OF EXCELLENCE: TEN-YEAR STRATEGIC PLAN FOR UTIA, 2018-2028 , AGRESEARCH OPERATES UNDER THE GUIDANCE OF ITS 2021-2024 AGRESEARCH STRATEGIC ACTION PLAN WITH THE OBJECTIVES TO BALANCE A PORTFOLIO OF INTEGRATED, INTER-DISCIPLINARY PROGRAMS,CULTISION LIVESTOCK FARMING (PLF). THE PROGRAM INCORPORATES BOTH PLANT AND ANIMAL MANAGEMENT PROJECTS THAT ULTIMATELY WILL CONTRIBUTE INFORMATION TO REFINE STRATEGIES THAT OFFER CARBON REDUCTIONS OVER TODAY’S AGRICULTURE SYSTEMS. AGRESEARCH IS REALIGNING THE CAPABILITIES AT TWO OF ITS TEN REC TO FACILITATE PLF INITIATIVE. THE LITTLE RIVER ANIMAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL UNIT PLANS TO HAVE MILKING ROBOTS IN OPERATION BY LATE FALL 2022, AND THE MIDDLE TENNESSEE REC IS RETOOLING TO SUPPORT PRECISION BEEF AND POULTRY PRODUCTION RESEARCH. ALSO, EXPANDED ACTIVITY IN CONTROLLED ENVIRONMENT AGRICULTURE WILL RESPOND TO CONCERNS OF FOOD SECURITY AND NUTRITION.  THE TRANSFORMATIONAL AGRICULTURAL GENOMICS AND SYNTHETIC BIOLOGY PROGRAM WILL ADVANCE ANIMAL AND PLANT-BASED PRODUCTIVITY. ALTHOUGH EARLY IN ITS DEVELOPMENT, THE INITIATIVE ALREADY ENGAGES FACULTY TO ADVANCE STATE-OF-THE-ART SCIENCE TO DESIGN CROPS THAT ARE RESILIENT TO CLIMATE CHANGE. FINALLY, THE BIOECONOMY ADVANCEMENT INITIATIVE IS AN ESTABLISHED INTERDISCIPLINARY PROGRAM FOCUSED ON SUSTAINABLE FUELS, CHEMICALS, AND MATERIALS. ADDITIONAL INVESTMENT IS EXPANDING RESEARCH CAPABILITIES IN SUSTAINABLE AVIATION FUELS TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE AGGRESSIVE GRAND CHALLENGE GOALS ANNOUNCED BY THE WHITE HOUSE.  MERIT AND SCIENTIFIC PEER REVIEW PROCESSES  TENNESSEE EXTENSION PROGRAMS FUNDED BY SMITH-LEVER OR NARETPA SECTION 1444 AND 1445 REQUIRE A MERIT REVIEW PROCESS. A PANEL OF EXTENSION ADMINISTRATORS, PROGRAM LEADERS AND SCHOLARS FROM FOUR STATES REVIEWED AND APPROVED THE TENNESSEE EXTENSION MERIT REVIEW CRITERIA. CRITERIA INCLUDES ASSESSING NEEDS, DELIVERY METHODS, IMPLEMENTATION STEPS, EVALUATION, ENSURING DIVERSITY AND DEFINED OUTCOMES. UT AND TSU COORDINATE MERIT REVIEW PROCESSES. STATE EXTENSION SPECIALISTS PROPOSE PLANNED PROGRAMS. ALL PROPOSED PROGRAMS ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY A REVIEW TEAM OF UT EXTENSION ADMINISTRATORS AND SPECIALISTS.  UT AGRESEARCH WILL UTILIZE THE PROCESS THAT HAS BEEN IN PLACE SINCE IT HAS PROVEN TO BE BOTH EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE. HATCH REGULAR AND HATCH/MULTI-STATE RESEARCH PROJECTS UNDERGO A REVIEW PROCESS FOR MERIT AND SCIENTIFIC SOUNDNESS, AND TO ENSURE ALIGNMENT WITH ESTABLISHED RESEARCH PRIORITIES. THE REVIEW PROCESS FOR HATCH REGULAR RESEARCH PROJECTS BEGINS INFORMALLY WITH DISCUSSIONS BETWEEN THE PROJECT DIRECTOR, COLLEAGUES, THE DEPARTMENT HEAD, AND, IF APPLICABLE, AGRESEARCH AND EDUCATION CENTER ADMINISTRATORS (IF FIELD WORK IS REQUIRED FOR THE PROJECT). A REVIEW PANEL OF THREE SCIENTISTS THEN EVALUATES THE PROPOSAL FOR CLARITY, TECHNICAL RELEVANCE, AND SCIENTIFIC MERIT. THE PROJECT DIRECTOR MAKES ANY NECESSARY REVISIONS AND SUBMITS THE PROPOSAL TO THE DEPARTMENT HEAD FOR REVIEW. IF APPROVED, THE DEAN/DIRECTOR OF AGRESEARCH THEN CONDUCTS A FINAL EVALUATION AND ENDORSES THE PROPOSAL FOR SUBMISSION TO NIFA.  HATCH/MULTI-STATE PROJECTS GO THROUGH A COMPARATIVELY MORE EXTENSIVE REVIEW AT THE REGIONAL LEVEL, SO THE INTERNAL REVIEW PROCESS IS ABBREVIATED. THE FACULTY MEMBER OFFICIALLY JOINS A MULTI- STATE PROJECT AFTER CONSULTING WITH COLLEAGUES AND, IF APPLICABLE, THE AGRESEARCH AND EDUCATION CENTER ADMINISTRATORS. THE PROJECT DIRECTOR THEN SUBMITS A PROPOSAL REFLECTING THE UT COMPONENT DIRECTLY TO THE ASSOCIATE DEAN/ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR OF AGRESEARCH FOR REVIEW AND COMMENT. ONCE THE REVIEW IS COMPLETE AND ANY NECESSARY CHANGES ARE MADE, THE RESEARCHER SUBMITS THE PROJECT TO NIFA.  STAKEHOLDER INPUT  UT EXTENSION PURSUED MULTIPLE DATA COLLECTIONS FOR THIS PLAN OF WORK. ALL 95 COUNTIES HAVE LOCAL EXTENSION ADVISORY GROUPS THAT PROVIDE ONGOING STAKEHOLDER INPUT. THE UT-TSU EXTENSION STATE ADVISORY COUNCIL REVIEWS AND UPDATES PLANS BI-ANNUALLY. EXTENSIVE STRATEGIC PLAN ACTIVITIES ALSO INFORMED THIS PLAN. EMPLOYEES, COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND STATE AGENCY LEADERS PARTICIPATED IN SURVEYS, LISTENING SESSIONS AND FOCUS GROUPS TO IDENTIFY CRITICAL ISSUES AFFECTING THEIR COMMUNITIES AND HOW EXTENSION COULD ADDRESS THESE CONCERNS. BASED ON THIS INPUT, THE STATE EXTENSION ADVISORY COUNCIL IDENTIFIED PLAN PRIORITIES. NEW STATE ACTION AGENDAS WERE CREATED TO ADDRESS PRIORITIES. PLANS ARE REVIEWED ANNUALLY TO DETERMINE PROGRESS AND MAKE CHANGES.  UT AGRESEARCH CONTINUES TO SEEK STAKEHOLDER FEEDBACK THROUGH SEVERAL MEANS. THE UT COMMISSION ON AGRICULTURE HOLDS PUBLIC MEETINGS TWICE PER YEAR TO PROVIDE FEEDBACK TO UT LEADERSHIP. THREE UTIA REGIONAL ADVISORY COUNCILS MEET TWICE PER YEAR TO DISCUSS AGRICULTURAL AND NATURAL RESOURCES ISSUES, UTIA PROGRAM PRIORITIES, AND HOW UTIA, INCLUDING UT AGRESEARCH AND UT EXTENSION, MAY RESPOND TO THESE ISSUES. SUCCESSFUL PARTNERSHIPS WITH COMMODITY AND INDUSTRY GROUPS, THE TENNESSEE FARM BUREAU, AND SEVERAL DEPARTMENTS WITHIN THE  TENNESSEE STATE GOVERNMENT ARE BENEFICIAL TO THE ADVANCEMENT OF COMMON RESEARCH INTERESTS. ADVOCACY/ADVISORY GROUPS SERVE THE UT AGRESEARCH ACADEMIC DEPARTMENTS AND THE TEN AGRESEARCH AND EDUCATION CENTERS AT THE INVITATION OF THE DEPARTMENT HEAD AND CENTER DIRECTOR, RESPECTIVELY, TO PROVIDE STAKEHOLDER FEEDBACK AND TO GUIDE FUTURE RESEARCH PRIORITIES. FACULTY HELP DRIVE THE UT AGRESEARCH AGENDA BY REMAINING ABREAST OF EMERGING RESEARCH AND ACTIVELY ENGAGING WITH THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY, PROGRAM LEADERS WITH STATE AND FEDERAL FUNDING AGENCIES, THE PUBLIC, AND AGRICULTURAL AND NATURAL RESOURCES COMMODITY AND INDUSTRY GROUPS.  ADDITIONALLY, THE UT SYSTEM IS COMPLETING A SURVEY THAT WENT STATEWIDE REGARDING PUBLIC INPUT INTO THE GRAND CHALLENGES FACING TENNESSEE. THIS WAS A UT SYSTEM EFFORT, BUT UT EXTENSION AND UT AGRESEARCH ASSISTED IN SHARING THE SURVEY ACROSS TENNESSEE AND THE RESULTS WILL CERTAINLY ADD TO THE INFORMATION WE USE TO DETERMINE DIRECTIONS FOR OUR WORK.  UT AND TSU EXTENSION WILL EMPLOY THEIR EXTENSIVE, STATEWIDE NETWORK OF ADVISORY GROUPS FOR STAKEHOLDER INPUT. THE STATE EXTENSION ADVISORY COUNCIL PROVIDES INPUT AND DIRECTION FOR STATEWIDE INITIATIVES. TENNESSEE EXTENSION AGENTS WILL CONTINUE TO PLACE SPECIAL EMPHASIS ON INVOLVING YOUTH AND OTHER UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS IN NEEDS ASSESSMENT ACTIVITIES. ALL OF TENNESSEE'S 95 COUNTIES HAVE A COUNTY AGRICULTURAL COMMITTEE OF SEVEN LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS, NOMINATED BY THE COUNTY MAYOR AND APPROVED BY MAJORITY VOTE OF THE COUNTY COMMISSION. EVERY COUNTY AGRICULTURE COMMITTEE MEETS FOUR TIMES ANNUALLY, AND THEIR DUTIES INCLUDE INPUT INTO HIRING DECISIONS, LOCAL FUNDING, AND LOCAL PROGRAMMING.  UT AGRESEARCH IMPLEMENTS SEVERAL METHODS TO IDENTIFY STAKEHOLDERS FOR INPUT. THE UT COMMISSION ON AGRICULTURE INCLUDES REPRESENTATIVES FROM COMMODITY AND INDUSTRY GROUPS, THE STATE GOVERNMENT, AND THE COMMUNITY. IT HOLDS PUBLIC MEETINGS TWICE PER YEAR TO PROVIDE FEEDBACK TO UT LEADERSHIP ON RESEARCH, EXTENSION, AND EDUCATION ISSUES. THREE UTIA REGIONAL ADVISORY COUNCILS ARE COMPRISED OF THE UT SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT FOR AGRICULTURE AND DEANS, REPRESENTATIVES FROM TENNESSEE AGRICULTURAL AND NATURAL RESOURCES COMMODITY GROUPS, AND CLIENTELE SERVED BY UTIA PROGRAMS. UTIA PERSONNEL NOMINATE THE COMMODITY GROUP AND CLIENTELE MEMBERS. EACH OF THE THREE REGIONAL ADVISORY GROUPS ELECTS A CHAIR TO GUIDE MEETINGS. IN ADDITION, UT AGRESEARCH ADMINISTRATORS AND FACULTY ARE ACTIVELY ENGAGED WITH AGRICULTURAL AND NATURAL RESOURCES COMMODITY AND INDUSTRY GROUPS. AS NEW PRIORITIES ARISE, THESE GROUPS SEEK OUT ONE ANOTHER TO DISCUSS COMMON RESEARCH NEEDS AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR PARTNERSHIP. ADVOCACY/ADVISORY GROUPS FOR THE UT AGRESEARCH ACADEMIC DEPARTMENTS AND THE AGRESEARCH AND EDUCATION CENTERS IDENTIFY ADDITIONAL STAKEHOLDERS BASED ON THE INDIVIDUALS’ AND GROUPS’ RELEVANT BACKGROUND, EXPERTISE, AND COMMUNITY CONNECTIONS. UT AGRESEARCH FACULTY REGULARLY INTERACT WITH THEIR PEERS AT PROFESSIONAL MEETINGS AND THROUGH JOINT PROJECT VENTURES. UT AGRESEARCH ADMINISTRATORS ENCOURAGE FACULTY TO MEET WITH PROGRAM LEADERS AT STATE AND NATIONAL FUNDING AGENCIES TO DISCUSS RESEARCH PRIORITIES. ADDITIONALLY, FACULTY HAVE OPPORTUNITIES TO MEET WITH THE PUBLIC DURING AGRESEARCH AND EDUCATION CENTER FIELD DAY EVENTS.  TENNESSEE EXTENSION (UT/TSU) AGENTS AND SPECIALISTS ARE TRAINED IN NEEDS ASSESSMENT STRATEGIES AND HOW TO SELECT INDIVIDUALS FOR ADVISORY COMMITTEES. COMMUNITY LEADERS SELECTED FOR ADVISORY COMMITTEES ARE CHOSEN TO REPRESENT THE DIVERSITIES (I.E., GENDER, AGE, RACIAL/ETHNIC, SOCIO-ECONOMIC, POLITICAL, EDUCATIONAL, ETC.) OF THE COUNTY OR AREA SERVED. THE UT COMMISSION ON AGRICULTURE CONDUCTS PUBLIC MEETINGS TWICE PER YEAR (SPECIFIC TO UT EXTENSION). EXTENSION  AGENTS RECRUIT INDIVIDUALS WHO HAVE PARTICIPATED IN PAST AND CURRENT EXTENSION PROGRAMS; AND THEY RECRUIT INDIVIDUALS WHO HAVE NOT USED EXTENSION TO SERVE ON LOCAL ADVISORY COMMITTEES AND PARTICIPATE IN OPEN LISTENING SESSIONS. EXTENSION AGENTS ALSO CONDUCT SURVEYS ON PLANNED PROGRAM AREAS.  UT AGRESEARCH COLLECTS INPUT THROUGH REGULAR CONTACT WITH STAKEHOLDERS. THE UT COMMISSION ON AGRICULTURE AND THE UTIA REGIONAL ADVISORY COUNCILS MEET TWICE PER YEAR. THE UT SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT FOR AGRICULTURE RESPONDS TO ANY ISSUES RAISED, AND, AS APPROPRIATE, MAY DELEGATE ACTION TO THE DEANS/DIRECTORS OF UT AGRESEARCH AND UT EXTENSION. UT AGRESEARCH ADMINISTRATORS MEET WITH EXTERNAL STAKEHOLDERS THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. THEY HAVE FACE-TO-FACE MEETINGS WITH THE ACADEMIC DEPARTMENT HEADS AND VIRTUAL MEETINGS WITH THE AGRESEARCH AND EDUCATION CENTER DIRECTORS MONTHLY; COLLECTIVELY THEY MEET ONCE PER YEAR. THE ACADEMIC DEPARTMENTS AND AGRESEARCH AND EDUCATION CENTERS MEET WITH THEIR ADVOCACY/ADVISORY GROUPS ANNUALLY AND SHARE STAKEHOLDER FEEDBACK WITH AGRESEARCH ADMINISTRATORS AND FACULTY AS APPROPRIATE. FACULTY ATTEND PROFESSIONAL MEETINGS AND READ SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS AND POPULAR PRESS ARTICLES THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. DEPARTMENTS HOLD MONTHLY FACULTY MEETINGS WHERE INDIVIDUALS CAN SHARE THEIR INSIGHTS WITH PEERS AND THEIR DEPARTMENT HEAD.  STAKEHOLDER INPUT AND PERFORMANCE MEASURES AT LOCAL, REGIONAL, AND STATEWIDE LEVEL MONITOR AND ADJUST DEPLOYMENT OF THE STRATEGIC PLAN. AS PART OF THIS PROCESS, THE OPINIONS FROM MANY TENNESSEANS, INCLUDING DECISION-MAKERS, CLIENTELE, PARTNERS, AND VOLUNTEERS WERE CONSIDERED. MORE THAN 120 STAKEHOLDERS AND 490 UT EXTENSION EMPLOYEES PARTICIPATED IN THE REGIONAL AND CAMPUS LISTENING SESSIONS. THE PLANNING EFFORT ALSO INCLUDED AN ONLINE SURVEY COMPONENT. UT EXTENSION WILL ADDRESS THE INCREASING URBANIZATION AND A LOSS OF FARMLAND IN THE STATE ARE CONCERNS FOR RESIDENTS. OUR NURSERY, FRUIT AND VEGETABLE PRODUCTION PROGRAMS WILL PLACE GREATER EMPHASIS ON PLANT, PEST, AND SOIL DIAGNOSTIC SERVICES. THE CENTER FOR PROFITABLE AGRICULTURE WILL CONTINUE TO CONDUCT EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS ON THE STATE'S AGRITOURISM INDUSTRY AND VALUE-ADDED PROGRAMS. HEALTH ISSUES CONTINUE TO BE TOP CONCERNS FOR RESIDENTS. EXTENSION STRENGTHENED HEALTH PROGRAMMING BY OFFERING THE CDC DIABETES PREVENTION PROGRAM. TO STRENGTHEN OUR EXTENSION AND RESEARCH FOR THE STATE'S BEEF CATTLE PRODUCERS, RESEARCHERS AND EXTENSION PERSONNEL WILL JOINTLY IMPLEMENT RESEARCH AND OUTREACH IN HAY SCHOOLS, LATE GESTATION NUTRITION, MARKETING, FORAGE TESTING, AND STOCKPILED FORAGES.  STAKEHOLDER INPUT IS AN ACTIVE PART OF SETTING UT AGRESEARCH BUDGET PRIORITIES AND REDIRECTING ALLOCATIONS AS CRITICAL NEEDS EMERGE, ARE ADDRESSED, AND WANE. STAKEHOLDER INPUT DIRECTLY IMPACTS HIRING PATTERNS, FACULTY EQUIPMENT BUDGETS, SCIENTIFIC COMMUNICATION EFFORTS, FORWARD-LOOKING ACTION PLANS, AND GRANT-WRITING DIRECTIONS.

KENTUCKY IS RANKED 8TH IN THE UNITED STATES IN OBESITY RATES AMONG ADULTS AT ITS HIGHEST AT 36.6%. ACCORDING TO BEHAVIORAL RISK FACTOR SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM, AFRICAN AMERICANS (41.7%) HAVE HIGHER OBESITY RATES (AT 36.8%) THAN THEIR CAUCASIAN COUNTERPARTS. AFRICAN AMERICAN AND HISPANIC (34.1%) OBESITY RATES ARE ALARMINGLY HIGH, CONSIDERING THESES RACES COMBINED ONLY MAKE UP ROUGHLY 12.6% OF KENTUCKY’S POPULATION. NATIONALLY, ON AVERAGE, 40% OF ADULTS REPORTED THAT THEY CONSUME FRUITS LESS THAN 1 TIME A DAY, AND 22% REPORTED CONSUMING VEGETABLES LESS THAN 1 TIME A DAY, BOTH OF WHICH ARE BELOW THE 2020 DIETARY GUIDELINES RECOMMENDATION OF 2 CUPS OF VEGETABLES AND 1.5 CUPS OF FRUITS PER DAY (CDC; DATA, TRENDS AND MAPS, 2015; U.S. DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE AND U.S. DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES, 2020). RESEARCH HAS SHOWN A DIRECT LINK BETWEEN OBESITY RATES AND IMPROPER EATING HABITS. KENTUCKY STATE UNIVERSITY (KYSU) WILL PROVIDE NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAMS IN NO LESS THAN 2 AND NO MORE THAN 3 COUNTIES IN KENTUCKY. WE WILL OFFER OUR PROGRAM TO UNDERSERVED AND LOW-INCOME FAMILIES WITH SCHOOL AGE CHILDREN IN THE HOME AND YOUTH PARTICIPANTS AT COMMUNITY CENTERS AND/OR SCHOOLS THAT MEET THE FREE AND REDUCED LUNCH MANDATE. KYSU WILL UTILIZE APPROVED EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULUM THAT FITS THE NEEDS OF THE GRANTS TARGET DEMOGRAPHIC OF UNDERSERVED AND LOW-INCOME INDIVIDUALS. THE APPROVED CURRICULA ADDRESS THESE CORE OBJECTIVES: DIET QUALITY, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, FOOD SAFETY, FOOD SECURITY, AND FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT. ALL CURRICULA USED WILL INCLUDE HEALTHY RECIPES FOR EDUCATORS TO CONDUCT FOOD DEMONSTRATIONS TO HELP ENGAGE PARTICIPANTS AND AID IN REINFORCEMENT OF HEALTHY FOOD CONCEPTS TAUGHT IN THE LESSONS. CURRENTLY, KYSU COOPERATIVE EXTENSION PROGRAM SUPPORTS VARIOUS SERVICES TO ADDRESS ISSUES AND CONCERNS FOR LOWER INCOME FAMILIES WITH REGARDS TO FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, NUTRITION, AND PUBLIC HEALTH. WE WILL PARTNER WITH CURRENT PROGRAM AREAS AT THE UNIVERSITY AS WELLAS MAINTAIN AND ESTABLISH NEW COMMUNITY PARTNERS YEARLY.

FORT VALLEY STATE UNIVERSITY EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM   FORT VALLEY STATE UNIVERSITY OFFERS THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) THROUGH THE COOPERATIVE EXTENSION PROGRAM. WE HAVE EXTENDED THE REACH OF EDUCATING THE POPULATION OF GEORGIA ON CHANGED BEHAVIORAL TECHNIQUES IN HEALTH AND NUTRITION FOR ENHANCED LIVING. EFNEP ENCOMPASSES FOUR CORE AREAS; DIET QUALITY/PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, FOOD SAFETY AND FOOD SECURITY. THESE GOALS ARE MET THROUGH PEER EDUCATORS DELIVERING NUTRITION EDUCATION CONTENT TO PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS. EDUCATIONAL SESSIONS ARE DELIVERED IN AN INTERACTIVE HANDS-ON SERIES OF LESSONS ON VARIOUS HEALTH/NUTRITION SUBJECTS INCORPORATED WITH FOOD DEMONSTRATIONS ON SPECIFIC HEALTH TOPICS. CURRENT COUNTIES THAT OFFER EFNEP THROUGH FORT VALLEY STATE UNIVERSITY COOPERATIVE EXTENSION ARE CRISP, DOOLY, PEACH, AND MACON COUNTY.

FY 2023 EFNEP CENTRAL STATE UNIVERSITY EXTENSION PROJECT PERFORMANCE SITE CENTRAL STATE UNIVERSITY EXTENSION PROVIDES PROGRAMMING AT VARIOUS THROUGHOUT OHIO. EFNEP PROGRAMMING WILL BE PRIMARILY FOCUSED ON SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES IN THE SOUTHERN OHIO IN THE CSU EXTENSION REGIONS OF SOUTHWEST, SOUTHEAST, AND SOUTHERN.  PROJECT ABSTRACT  THE WELFARE OF ADULTS, YOUTH, AND CHILDREN IN LOW-INCOME, UNDERSERVED, AND DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES IN OHIO IS A CRITICAL PRIORITY FOR CENTRAL STATE UNIVERSITY (CSU) EXTENSION. PARENTS, PREGNANT WOMEN, AND YOUTH IN THESE COMMUNITIES ARE OFTEN AT A GREATER RISK OF POOR NUTRITION AND SUBSEQUENT ILLNESSES WITH LONG TERM CONSEQUENCES. FOR ADULTS THESE INCLUDE CHRONIC DISEASES INCLUDING DIABETES, HYPERTENSION, AND HIGH CHOLESTEROL. FOR YOUTH RISK SUCH AS IMPAIRED OR POOR BRAIN AND PHYSICAL DEVELOPMENT, LEARNING DISABILITIES, DECREASED IMMUNITY, INCREASED INFECTIONS AND OBESITY ARE, AMONG OTHERS.  THE UNITED STATES SPENDS $200 BILLION IN HEALTHCARE RELATED TO OBESITY, AND MORE THAN 81 MILLION AMERICANS ARE COMPLETELY INACTIVE AND LACK PHYSICAL ACTIVITY. OHIO HAS THE 11TH HIGHEST ADULT OBESITY RATE IN THE NATION, AND THE SIXTH HIGHEST OBESITY RATE FOR YOUTH AGES 10 TO 17. OBESITY IN CHILDREN IS A GROWING EPIDEMIC IN THE UNITED STATES, AND THE MINORITY POPULATIONS ARE ESPECIALLY AT RISK FOR OBESITY. HEALTH OF INDIVIDUALS AND OVERALL POPULATIONS ENCOMPASS MANY FACTORS: BEHAVIORAL, ECONOMIC, ENVIRONMENTAL, CULTURAL, EDUCATIONAL, AND GENETIC. DIET AND NUTRITION ARE IMPORTANT TO OVERALL HEALTH. DISEASES RELATED TO OBESITY, SEDENTARY LIFESTYLES, NUTRIENT DEFICIENCIES, AND FOOD INSECURITY, ARE MAJOR DIETARY HEALTH CONCERNS IN THE U.S.  CSU EXTENSION USES RESEARCHED, EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULUMS, AND STRATEGIES TO TEACH PARTICIPANTS IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES HOW TO MI TIGATE THIS CIRCUMSTANCE BY LEARNING FOOD SELECTION, BUDGETING, MEAL PREPARATION, FOOD STORAGE, AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY TO HELP THEY AND THEIR FAMILIES BECOME HEALTHIER.  CSUEFNEP PARTNERS WITH COMMUNITY-BASED AGENCIES, ORGANIZATIONS, AND SCHOOLS TO PROVIDE INTERACTIVE AND DIRECT ENGAGEMENT. ADULT PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS RECEIVE 6-9 IN-PERSON OR VIRTUAL WORKSHOPS SERIES. ADULTS ARE PROVIDED WITH INSTRUCTION IN LEARNING WITH A DIALOGUE APPROACH. ADULT PARTICIPANTS ALSO ENGAGE IN ACTIVITIES TO REINFORCE LESSONS.  CSU PROVIDES YOUTH FROM AGES 6-18 (GRADES PRE-K – 12) PROGRAMS IN AND AFTER-SCHOOL, 4-H CLUBS, DAY CAMPS AND SUMMER CAMPS. EFFNEP YOUTH AUDIENCES LEARN ABOUT HEALTHY LIFESTYLES. YOUTH ARE PROVIDED WITH LESSONS ON HOW TO CHOOSE AND PREPARE HEALTHY FOODS, FOOD SAFETY PRACTICES, INCREASE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND DECREASE SCREEN TIME.  EFNEP PROGRAMMING FOCUSES THE FOLLOWING AREAS OF HEALTH FOR ADULT AND YOUTH PARTICIPANTS:  DIET QUALITY – AN UNDERSTANDING OF NUTRIENTS IN FOOD AND HOW THEY ARE NEEDED BY THE BODY. IDENTIFICATION OF FOODS WITH KEY NUTRIENTS. PHYSICAL ACTIVITY – ILLUSTRATE THE NEED FOR DAILY PHYSICAL ACTIVITY BY THE BODY AS IT RELATES TO THE HEALTH OF A PERSON’S BODY. FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT - HELP ADULTS LEARN PRACTICES AND TECHNIQUES TO SELECT HEALTHY FOODS IN A COST- EFFECTIVE MANNER.  FOOD SAFETY AND SECURITY - TEACH ADULTS FOOD HANDLING, PREPARATION, AND STORAGE PRACTICES TO PREVENT FOOD ILLNESSES. ADDITIONALLY, HELP FAMILIES WITH STRATEGIES AND COMMUNITY RESOURCES TO DECREASE FOOD INSECURITY.  PROGRAM OBJECTIVES AND OUTCOMES  • OBJECTIVE 1: SECURE PARTNERSHIPS WITH COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS O EXPAND OUTREACH TO PARTNER WITH THE FOLLOWING: FOOD PANTRIES, FOOD COOPERATIVE ASSOCIATIONS, LIBRARIES, DAY CARE CENTERS, HEALTH CLINICS, SOCIAL SERVICE ORGANIZATIONS AND ADULT TREATMENT CENTERS AND K-12 SCHOOLS (PUBLIC, CHARTER, AND ALTERNATIVE) O REGIONAL EXTENSION ASSOCIATES WILL ENGAGE COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS TO DEVELOP WORKING PARTNERSHIPS FOR EFNEP CLASSES. O MEET WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS QUARTERLY TO ACCESS NEEDS, SUCCESSES AND STRATEGIZE FUTURE PROGRAMS • EXPECTED OUTCOMES O INCREASE TARGETED DEMOGRAPHICS: MARRIED AND SINGLE PARENTS, PREGNANT WOMEN, TEEN PARENTS, GRANDPARENTS, FOSTER PARENTS, CHILDCARE WORKERS, AND YOUTH  • OBJECTIVE 2: UPDATE CSUE WEBSITE WITH EFNEP CONTENT. O DEVELOP AND LAUNCH ON-LINE AND SOCIAL MEDIA PLATFORM TO PROMOTE EFNEP PROGRAMMING AND PROVIDE TIPS AND RESOURCES IN THE FOUR CORE LEARNING AREAS FOR PARTICIPANTS TO UTILIZE OUTSIDE OF CLASS. O UPDATE CSU EXTENSION WEBSITE FOR ANNOUNCING AND PROMOTING UPCOMING CLASSES AND REGISTRATION. • EXPECTED OUTCOMES: O INCREASE LEARNING RESOURCES FOR EFNEP PARTICIPANTS WITH VIDEOS ON FOODS, FOOD SAFETY, AND FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT O ENSURE CSU EFNEP EXPOSURE THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF OHIO. O PROVIDE VEHICLES FOR PARTICIPANTS TO LEARN MORE ABOUT PROGRAMING, REGISTER FOR CLASSES AND TOOL FOR EDUCATORS TO ENGAGE. O • OBJECTIVE 3: INCREASE RETENTION AND GRADUATION RATES OF EXISTING PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS O PROVIDE TANGIBLE INCENTIVES FOR CLASS ATTENDANCE O PROVIDE GRADUATE INCENTIVES O PROVIDE ON-LINE CONTENT AND/OR LESSON AIDS FOR MISSED CLASSES. EXPECTED OUTCOMES O INCREASED GRADUATION RATES. O SHORT- AND LONG-TERM DIETARY SUCCESS OF PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS O INCREASE POOL OF CLASS VOLUNTEERS

THE PURPOSE OF EFNEP IS TO PROVIDE NUTRITION EDUCATION TO LOW- INCOME POPULATIONS TO REDUCE NUTRITION INSECURITY IN LOW INCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH.  EFNEP OBJECTIVES INCLUDE PROVIDING ASSISTANCE TO LOW-INCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH IN ACQUIRING KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, ATTITUDES, AND CHANGED BEHAVIORS NECESSARY FOR NUTRITIONALLY SOUND DIETS, AND TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE OVERALL IMPROVEMENT OF THE TOTAL FAMILY DIET AND NUTRITIONAL WELL-BEING. THIS IS ACCOMPLISHED BY PROVIDING INFORMAL AND EASILY ACCESSIBLE NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAMS IN THE COMMUNITY. PEER EDUCATORS, WHO TYPICALLY LIVE IN THE COMMUNITIES THEY WORK, DELIVER A SERIES OF INTERACTIVE LESSONS TO PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS IN COMMUNITY SETTINGS. THE LESSONS ARE EVIDENCE-BASED, AND ARE TAILORED TO MEET THE NEEDS OF THE AUDIENCE. THE PROGRAM LESSONS FOCUS ON DEVELOPING KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS RELATED TO NUTRITION, DIET QUALITY, MEAL PREPARATION AND SAFETY, RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY.

PROJECT ABSTRACT: UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS AMHERST   EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM  THE MASSACHUSETTS EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) IS A A NATIONAL AWARD DESIGNED TO IMPROVE THE NUTRITION AND HEALTH OF LOW-INCOME FAMILIES WITH YOUNG CHILDREN. EFNEP HELPS LOW-INCOME FAMILIES (ADULTS AND YOUTH) IMPROVE THEIR NUTRITIONAL HEALTH AND FOOD SECURITY THROUGH HANDS-ON, INTERACTIVE LESSONS WHERE PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS LEARN TO IMPROVE FOOD AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY BEHAVIORS. EFNEP FOCUSES ON WORKING WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS AND SUPPORTS AN IMPROVED NUTRITION AND PHYSICAL ENVIRONMENT FOR LOW-INCOME FAMILIES BY ENGAGING COMMUNITY PARTNERS IN MAKING POLICY, SYSTEM, AND ENVIRONMENTAL (PSE) CHANGES. THESE CHANGES CREATE ENVIRONMENTS THAT "MAKE THE HEALTHY CHOICE THE EASY CHOICE" FOR LOW-INCOME FAMILIES AND OUR ADULT AND YOUTH EFNEP PARTICIPANTS.  IN MASSACHUSETTS ENFEP STAFF ACROSS THE STATE IDENTIFY INDIVIDUALS FROM TARGET COMMUNITIES WHO ARE RECRUITED AND TRAINED TO DELIVER SIX TO NINE NUTRITION EDUCATION LESSONS TO SMALL GROUPS OF FAMILIES OR YOUTH. EDUCATORS TEACH WITH A SPECIAL UNDERSTANDING OF THE LIFESTYLES, FOOD-WAYS, AND CHALLENGES THAT FAMILIES FACE AND IN A LANGUAGE THEY UNDERSTAND. PROJECT STAFF USE A CREATIVE CURRICULUM THAT ENGAGES PARTICIPANTS IN GROUP DISCUSSIONS, COOKING DEMONSTRATIONS, FOOD TASTING, MUSIC, FUN PHYSICAL ACTIVITIES, AND OTHER HANDS-ON LEARNING. STAFF ARE BASED AT UMASS AMHERST AND IN FOUR FIELD OFFICES ACROSS THE STATE (RAYNHAM, LAWRENCE, SPRINGFIELD, AND WORCESTER).

NEVADA'S EFNEP PROGRAM IS CONDUCTED IN CLARK COUNTY, LOCATED IN SOUTHERN NEVADA, WHICH INCLUDES THE UNINCORPORATED AREAS OF CLARK COUNTY, LAS VEGAS, NORTH LAS VEGAS, HENDERSON, AND MESQUITE. OF THE 17 COUNTIES IN NEVADA, 70% OF NEVADA'S POPULATION LIVES IN CLARK COUNTY. CLARK COUNTY CONTAINS NOT ONLY MOST OF THE STATE'S POPULATION BUT ALSO MOST OF THOSE LIVING IN POVERTY.  RECIPIENTS OF THE SUPPLEMENTAL NUTRITION ASSISTANCE PROGRAM (SNAP) ARE AT OR BELOW 130% OF THE POVERTY LEVEL. ALMOST 62% OF SNAP PARTICIPANTS ARE FAMILIES WITH CHILDREN WHICH IS THE TARGET AUDIENCE FOR NEVADA'S ADULT EFNEP PROGRAM. OUR SECOND TARGET AUDIENCE IN NEVADA IS YOUTH/CHILDREN IN 5TH AND 6TH GRADES.  FOR OUR ADULT PARTICIPANTS, NEVADA USES THE HEALTHY EATING AND ACTIVE LIVING CURRICULUM, EATING SMART, BEING ACTIVE. EATING SMART, BEING ACTIVE IS DESIGNED TO TEACH THE MAIN MESSAGE OF THE DIETARY GUIDELINES FOR AMERICANS AND THE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY GUIDELINES FOR AMERICANS WITH THE GOAL OF ASSISTING FAMILIES WITH LIMITED RESOURCES IN ACQUIRING KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, ATTITUDES AND CHANGED-BEHAVIOR NECESSARY FOR NUTRITIONALLY SOUND DIETS. THIS IN TURN CONTRIBUTES TO PERSONAL DEVELOPMENT AND IMPROVEMENT OF THE TOTAL FAMILY DIET AND NUTRITIONAL WELL-BEING. THE CURRICULUM HAS BEEN UPDATED TO COMPLY WITH THE CURRENT 2020-2025 DIETARY GUIDELINES AND THE 2018 PHYSICAL ACTIVITY GUIDELINES.  LESSON CONTENT INCLUDES PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, NUTRITION, HEALTHY LIFESTYLE CHOICES, FOOD PREPARATION (COOKING SKILL DEVELOPMENT), FOOD SAFETY, AND FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT. DEPENDING ON THE AUDIENCE, THE LESSON CONTENT ALSO INCLUDES EATING SMART AND BEING ACTIVE DURING PREGNANCY, FEEDING NEW BABIES AND FEEDING BABIES SOLID FOODS.  USING A PRE- AND POST-PROGRAM 24-HOUR FOOD RECALL AND A QUESTIONNAIRE IN THE WEBNEERS DATABASE, PARTICIPANTS RECEIVE A PRINTOUT OF THEIR OWN DIETARY HABITS BEFORE AND AFTER THE PROGRAM. THEY CAN SEE THE PROGRESS THEY HAVE MADE AND AREAS WHERE THEY CAN IMPROVE. ADDITIONALLY, NEVADA'S DATA SUMMARY ATTESTS TO THE POSITIVE BEHAVIOR CHANGE IN PARTICIPANTS AFTER THE 8- LESSON COURSE.  "CHOOSE HEALTH: FOOD, FUN, AND FITNESS" (CHFFF) IS THE CURRICULUM IMPLEMENTED FOR NEVADA'S YOUTH PARTICIPANTS. CHFFF IS AN AWARD-WINNING, COMPREHENSIVE NUTRITION AND FITNESS CURRICULUM COMPOSED OF SIX HANDS-ON LESSONS FOR 8-12-YEAR-OLDS (3RD-6TH GRADERS). CORNELL UNIVERSITY'S DIVISION OF NUTRITIONAL SCIENCES AND CORNELL COOPERATIVE EXTENSION'S 4-H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM DEVELOPED CHFFF. CHFFF USES EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING TO  TEACH HEALTHY EATING AND ACTIVE PLAY. THIS CURRICULUM TARGETS BEHAVIORS THAT RESEARCH SHOWS TO BE MOST IMPORTANT FOR PREVENTING CHILDHOOD OBESITY AND CHRONIC DISEASE. TOPICS INCLUDE REPLACING SWEETENED DRINKS WITH LOW-FAT MILK AND WATER; EATING MORE VEGETABLES, FRUITS, AND WHOLE GRAINS; EATING FEWER HIGH-FAT AND HIGH-SUGAR FOODS; AND PLAYING ACTIVELY FOR 60 MINUTES A DAY.  EACH LESSON INCLUDES INTERACTIVE NUTRITION ACTIVITIES, FOOD PREPARATION, ACTIVE GAMES, A GOAL SETTING CHALLENGE, AND A FAMILY NEWSLETTER. POSTERS, VISUAL AIDS, SCANNED FOOD PACKAGES, GAME PIECES AND INSTRUCTION CARDS, AND OTHER TEACHING MATERIALS ARE ALL INCLUDED. CHFFF SUPPORTS THE DIETARY GUIDELINES FOR AMERICANS AND USDA'S MYPLATE, AND USES A DIALOGUE APPROACH FOR MORE EFFECTIVE RETENTION AND APPLICATION OF INFORMATION AND SKILLS. PRACTICE-BASED EVIDENCE SUGGESTS THAT CHFFF PROMOTES POSITIVE BEHAVIOR CHANGE, WITH SIGNIFICANT IMPROVEMENTS FROM PRE- TO POST-TESTS IN VEGETABLE AND FRUIT CONSUMPTION, REDUCED SWEETENED BEVERAGES, READING NUTRITION LABELS, AND OTHER FOOD AND ACTIVITY-RELATED BEHAVIORS.

NEW YORK IS THE 4TH LARGEST STATE IN THE UNITED STATES; COVERING 54,556 SQUARE MILES. IT IS COMPRISED OF 62 COUNTIES WITH POPULATIONS RANGING FROM LESS THAN 5,000 TO OVER 2.5 MILLION (1). NYS HAS A DIVERSE POPULATION: 12.3% ASIAN, 24.6% BLACK, 43.7% WHITE, 28.8% HISPANIC (4). POVERTY BY COUNTY RANGES FROM 4.8% - 29.7% (5); BUT EXTREMELY POOR COMMUNITIES HAVE RATES OF UP TO 48% IN KIRYAS JOEL (BRONX), 43% IN ITHACA (TOMPKINS COUNTY), 33% IN BINGHAMTON (BROOME COUNTY), AND 30% IN BUFFALO (ERIE COUNTY)(4). STATEWIDE, 21% OF CHILDREN UNDER THE AGE OF 18 LIVE IN POVERTY - 803,000 CHILDREN (5). IN ADDITION, 47.5% OF CHILDREN RECEIVE FREE OR REDUCED COST LUNCH; (74.9% OF CHILDREN IN NEW YORK CITY AND 31.7% OF CHILDREN IN THE REST OF THE STATE) (6). THIRTY FIVE PERCENT OF CHILDREN LIVE IN SINGLE PARENT HOUSEHOLDS. OVERWEIGHT AND OBESITY RATES FOR ADULTS (60.5%) AND CHILDREN (35.8%) ARE OF GRAVE CONCERN (7), AS THESE CONDITIONS ARE ASSOCIATED WITH SERIOUS CHRONIC HEALTH PROBLEMS, INCLUDING DIABETES, HYPERTENSION, AND HEART DISEASE. PEOPLE LIVING IN POVERTY ARE MORE LIKELY TO SUFFER FROM A VARIETY OF CHRONIC HEALTH PROBLEMS, BOTH PSYCHOLOGICAL AND PHYSICAL. WHILE ONLY ONE COMPONENT OF THE OVERWEIGHT AND OBESITY ISSUE, AND ONE OF A HOST OF CONCERNS FOR PEOPLE IN POVERTY, NUTRITION EDUCATION CAN MITIGATE BOTH. COVID-19 CONTINUED TO IMPACT PROGRAMMING ACROSS NEW YORK STATE IN FFY2022. MORE RURAL AREAS OF NEW YORK BEGAN TO RETURN TO IN-PERSON EDUCATION DURING THE SECOND QUARTER OF 2022, WHILE URBAN PROGRAMS HAVE CONTINUED TO REACH PARTICIPANTS VIRTUALLY. AS 2022 CONTINUES, PROGRAM STAFF ARE WORKING TO STRENGTHEN EXISTING PARTNERSHIPS AND BUILD NEW, AS MANY OF THE AGENCIES WHERE EDUCATION HAS BEEN OFFERED HAVE EXPERIENCED STAFF TURN-OVER AND/OR CHANGE IN OPERATIONAL GUIDELINES THAT HAVE IMPACTED THE SPEED OF A RETURN TO ‘NORMAL’ .  HISTORICALLY, IN NEW YORK, WE HAVE MAINTAINED A COMMITMENT TO A STATEWIDE EFNEP PROGRAM. WE HAVE DEVELOPED AND CONTINUE TO REFINE A COUNTY FUNDING FORMULA THAT INCLUDES ADJUSTMENTS FOR LEVELS OF POVERTY AND POPULATION DENSITY. HOWEVER, CONTINUATION OF LOCAL PROGRAM FUNDING IS CONTINGENT ON SUCCESSFUL ACHIEVEMENT OF PROGRAM OUTPUTS. ADDITIONALLY, COUNTY PROGRAMMING IS DETERMINED BY LOCAL BOARDS OF DIRECTORS. WE WORK IN CONCERT WITH COUNTIES THAT HAVE DETERMINED THAT NUTRITION EDUCATION FOR LOW-INCOME FAMILIES IS A PRIORITY PROGRAM AREA. GIVEN THE STATIC FEDERAL EFNEP ALLOCATION AND INCREASING COST OF PROGRAM OPERATIONS, THE NUMBER OF COUNTIES THAT CAN BE FUNDED HAS BEEN REDUCED SINCE THE LAST 5-YEAR PLAN. EFFORTS TO MAINTAIN AN EFNEP PRESENCE IN THE COUNTIES WITH THE HIGHEST NEED HAS BEEN A PRIORITY. AS A RESULT, 50% OF OUR PROGRAM FUNDS ADDRESS THE NEEDS AND POPULATION IN METROPOLITAN NYC AND LONG ISLAND.  COMMUNICATION WITH STATE LEVEL ORGANIZATIONS AND AGENCIES HAS REMAINED CONSISTENT AND ONGOING AND WILL CONTINUE TO EVOLVE. THE EFNEP COORDINATOR AND SNAP-ED STATE COORDINATOR SCHEDULE PERIODIC CALLS TO COORDINATE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, USE OF NUTRITION EDUCATION MATERIALS AND DISCUSS STRATEGIES FOR POLICY, SYSTEM, AND ENVIRONMENTAL WORK. ACROSS THE STATE, EFNEP REGIONAL COORDINATORS WILL CONTINUE TO NETWORK WITH BOTH PROGRAMS TO ENSURE QUALITY NUTRITION EDUCATION IS PROVIDED TO PROGRAM SPECIFIC AUDIENCES. CAMPUS LEADERSHIP WILL COLLABORATE WITH NYS SNAP LEADERSHIP TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND SUPPORT WITH POLICIES AND PROCEDURES, CONSULTATION ON INITIATIVES AND TRAINING AS NEEDED TO ENSURE QUALITY PROGRAMMING THROUGH LGU SNAP-ED PROGRAMS. SOME AGENCIES IMPLEMENTED STRICT COVID GUIDELINES, LIMITING ACCESS AND MAKING DIRECT CONTACT WITH PARTICIPANTS CHALLENGING. INCONSISTENCIES IN POST-COVID PROTOCOLS HAS HAMPERED BOTH RECRUITMENT AND LESSON DELIVERY.  THE TARGET AUDIENCE FOR EFNEP IN NYS IS LOW-INCOME FAMILIES WITH CHILDREN LIVING AT OR BELOW 185% OF THE FEDERAL POVERTY LEVEL; AND LOW INCOME, 4-H AGED YOUTH. COUNTY STRATEGIES ARE TAILORED TO ADDRESS THE SPECIFIC NEEDS WITHIN THEIR COMMUNITIES TO ENSURE SUCCESSFUL RECRUITMENT, ENROLLMENT, EDUCATION, AND GRADUATION OF PROGRAM ELIGIBLE INDIVIDUALS. COOPERATION WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS, AGENCIES PROVIDING SERVICE TO THE TARGET POPULATIONS, AND COMMUNITY LEADERS WHO CAN PROVIDE INSIGHT AND GUIDANCE REGARDING LOCATIONS WHERE THE TARGET AUDIENCE LIVES AND WORKS, IS A PROVEN STRATEGY. STAFF ARE ENCOURAGED TO FORGE PERSONAL RELATIONSHIPS WITH KEY COMMUNITY LEADERS TO ENSURE THAT OUTREACH IS RELEVANT AND APPROPRIATE. GIVEN THE NATURE OF NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAMMING TO LOW-INCOME AUDIENCES IN NYS, THERE IS LITTLE CONCERN FOR DUPLICATION OF SERVICES. STRATEGIES FOR IMPROVING SOCIAL MEDIA AND ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS ARE UNDER INVESTIGATION BY NATIONAL EFNEP WORKGROUPS IN WHICH NEW YORK STAFF ARE PARTICIPATING AND WILL BE PILOTED IN A VARIETY OF LOCATIONS DURING THE NEXT FIVE YEARS. WE ARE HOPEFUL THAT THESE TECHNOLOGIES CAN EXTEND THE REACH OF THE PROGRAM, BOLSTER ENROLLMENTS AND INCREASE GRADUATION NUMBERS. INVESTIGATION OF ENVIRONMENTAL POLICIES AND SUPPORTS WILL BE UNDERTAKEN TO INSTITUTIONALIZE COLLABORATIONS WITH PARTNER AGENCIES AND COOPERATIVE EXTENSION. THE TRADITIONAL EFNEP ADULT PROGRAM WILL BE EXPANDED TO INCLUDE EDUCATION FOR FOSTER CHILDREN WHO ARE AGEING OUT OF THE FOSTER CARE SYSTEM AND INTO YOUNG ADULTHOOD. THIS AUDIENCE HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED AS A PRIORITY FOR EDUCATION TO PREPARE THEM WITH THE SKILLS TAUGHT THROUGH EFNEP TO MEET THE CHALLENGES OF ADULTHOOD.
