PRAIRIE VIEW A<(>&<)>M UNIVERSITY EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM PROJECT ABSTRACT   POOR HEALTH AND FOOD INSECURITY DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTS LOW-INCOME AND MINORITY FAMILIES AND YOUTH. STATE RESEARCH INDICATES THAT PEOPLE WHO ARE MOST FOOD INSECURE HAVE A GREATER RISK FOR SERIOUS HEALTH ISSUES AND OBESITY THAN THOSE WHO ARE FOOD SECURE. CHILDREN ARE INCREASINGLY AT RISK FOR SERIOUS ILLNESS AS INDICATED BY THE SPIRALING RISE OF ADOLESCENT OBESITY AND TYPE 2 DIABETES. ACCORDING TO THE "THE STATE OF OBESITY: BETTER POLICIES FOR A HEALTHIER AMERICA” REPORT. “IN 2020, 16 STATES HAD ADULT OBESITY RATES AT OR ABOVE 35 PERCENT, UP FROM 12 STATES THE PREVIOUS YEAR AND TEXAS WAS ONE OF THE 16. THESE AND OTHER EMERGING DATA SHOW THAT THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC CHANGED EATING HABITS, WORSENED LEVELS OF FOOD INSECURITY, CREATED OBSTACLES TO PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, AND HEIGHTENED STRESS, ALL EXACERBATING THE DECADES LONG PATTERN OF OBESITY IN AMERICA.” FROM 1990-2019, TEXAS HAS HAD A HIGHER OBESITY RATE COMPARED TO THE U.S. OVERALL. IN 2019, 34.8% OF TEXANS WERE OBESE COMPARED TO 30.9% OF AMERICANS; FURTHERMORE, DURING THE PANDEMIC TEXAS OBESITY RATE INCREASE TO 35.8%. THE PREVALENCE OF OBESITY IN TEXAS IS SIGNIFICANTLY HIGHER AMONG BLACK ADULTS AT 38.8% AND 36.5% FOR LATINOS. AMONG THOSE WITH AN ANNUAL HOUSEHOLD INCOME LESS THAN $15,000 THE OBESITY RATE IS 42.4 % (OBESITY PREVALENCE AMONG ADULTS BY DEMOGRAPHIC CHARACTERISTICS, TEXAS, AND U.S. AND BY HEALTH SERVICE REGION AND COUNTY, TEXAS 2018). HISPANIC OR AFRICAN AMERICAN HOUSEHOLDS HAVE AN INCOME GAP OF TENS OF THOUSANDS OF DOLLARS BETWEEN THEIR MEDIAN INCOMES AND THOSE OF WHITE AND ASIAN TEXANS. THE U.S. CENSUS STATES THAT 13.31% OF TEXANS LIVE IN POVERTY. POOR DIETARY HABITS, PHYSICAL INACTIVITY AND OBESITY ARE LINKED TO SEVERAL CHRONIC DISEASES, INCLUDING CORONARY HEART DISEASE, STROKE, DIABETES, AND SOME CANCERS (NIH CLINICAL GUIDELINES 1998). THE NUMBER OF DIABETES CASES IN THE LAST DECADE AMOUNTED TO 1,962,059 AND IT IS PROJECTED THAT BY 2030, THERE WILL BE ABOUT 2,851,687 DIABETES CASES. DIABETES, HYPERTENSION RATES, HEART DISEASE AND OBESITY-RELATED CANCER CASES ARE SAID TO RISE SIGNIFICANTLY BY 2030. THE HIGHEST OF THESE RATES BEING HEART DISEASE CASES FROM 1,261,654 TO 5,688,482. EFNEP CONTRIBUTES TO THE PERSONAL DEVELOPMENT OF YOUTH AND THE IMPROVEMENT OF THE TOTAL FAMILY DIET AND NUTRITIONAL WELL-BEING. TOPICS INCLUDING REPLACING SWEETENED DRINKS WITH LOW-FAT MILK AND WATER, EATING MORE VEGETABLES, FRUITS, AND WHOLE GRAINS, EATING FEWER HIGH FAT AND HIGH SUGAR FOODS, AND PLAYING ACTIVELY 60 MINUTES A DAY. EFNEP NEA’S EDUCATE THE ADULT PARTICIPANTS USING THE EATING SMART BEING ACTIVE EATING SMART AND BEING ACTIVE CURRICULUM DEVELOPED BY COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY EXTENSION AND UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA DAVIS IS A COMPREHENSIVE NUTRITION EDUCATION CURRICULUM THAT FOCUSES ON THE PARAPROFESSIONAL EDUCATORS AND PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS. IN ADDITION, THE REVISED CURRICULUM PLACES GREATER EMPHASIS ON FOOD PREPARATION AND NOT JUST “TASTE TESTING” DURING DEMONSTRATIONS. THE CURRICULUM WAS DEVELOPED SPECIFICALLY FOR USE IN TEACHING LOW INCOME ADULTS AND FAMILIES WITH YOUNG CHILDREN TO ASSIST THEM IN ADOPTING HEALTHY LIFESTYLE CHOICES. “EATING SMART AND BEING ACTIVE” BASED ON THE PRINCIPLES FOUND IN FROM TELLING TO TEACHING: A DIALOGUE APPROACH TO ADULT LEARNING BY JOYE NORRIS, EDD TAKES A LEARNER CENTERED APPROACH TO EDUCATION THAT FOCUSES ON THREE DIFFERENT LEARNING THEORIES. ADULT LEARNING THEORY, THE SOCIAL LEARNING THEORY, AND THE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING THEORY. USE OF THESE METHODS ALLOWS THE EFNEP NEA’S TO HELP PARTICIPANTS LEARN TO PRACTICE NEW SKILLS, LEARN FROM EACH OTHER, ENJOY SOME DEGREE OF SUCCESS, AND BECOME CONFIDENT IN THE K NOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES DEVELOPED DURING CLASSROOM SESSIONS. FOCUS LESSONS: WELCOME TO EATING SMART BEING ACTIVE (OVERVIEW OF LESSON SERIES; RELATIONSHIP BUILDING BETWEEN EDUCATOR AND PARTICIPANTS), GET MOVING! (PHYSICAL ACTIVITY IS PART OF A HEALTHY LIFESTYLE), PLAN, SHOP, SAVE (HOW TO STRETCH YOUR FOOD DOLLARS), FRUITS <(>&<)> VEGGIES: HALF YOUR PLATE (HOW TO INCREASE AMOUNT AND VARIETY OF FRUITS AND VEGETABLES), MAKE HALF YOUR GRAINS WHOLE (IDENTIFY WHOLE GRAIN FOODS AND WHY WHOLE GRAINS ARE BENEFICIAL), BUILD STRONG BONES (CALCIUM RICH FOODS AND WEIGHT BEARING ACTIVITY HELP BUILD STRONG BONES), GO LEAN WITH PROTEIN (CHOOSING LEAN SOURCES OF PROTEIN AND HOW TO KEEP FOOD SAFE), MAKE A CHANGE (CHOOSING FOODS LOW IN FAT, SUGAR, AND SALT), AND CELEBRATE! EAT SMART AND BE ACTIVE (REVIEW OF KEY CONCEPTS, CELEBRATE WHAT WE’VE LEARNED AND HOW TO INVOLVE FAMILY IN GOOD FOOD CHOICES).  EFNEP’S PREGNANT ADULTS AND TEENS ARE EDUCATED THROUGH EATING SMART BEING ACTIVE DURING PREGNANCY “EATING SMART BEING ACTIVE DURING PREGNANCY” CURRICULUM DEVELOPED BY COLORADO STATE CONTAINS MATERNAL AND INFANT NUTRITION LESSONS AS A SUPPLEMENT TO THE CORE NINE LESSONS. “EATING SMART AND BEING ACTIVE DURING PREGNANCY” LESSONS IS DESIGNED TO BE TAUGHT EARLY IN PREGNANCY AND COVERS TOPICS ABOUT SEEING A HEALTHCARE PROVIDER REGULARLY, EATING HEALTHY AND BEING ACTIVE DURING PREGNANCY, AND COMBATING COMMON PREGNANCY DISCOMFORTS. LESSONS  “FEEDING YOUR NEW BABY” COVERS INFORMATION ABOUT BREASTFEEDING AND FORMULA FEEDING TO AID WOMEN LATE IN THEIR PREGNANCIES IN DECIDING HOW TO FEED THEIR BABIES. LESSONS “FEEDING YOUR BABY SOLID FOODS” IS DESIGNED TO BE TAUGHT TO MOTHERS OF YOUNG INFANTS AND PROVIDES INFORMATION REGARDING INTRODUCING SOLID FOODS INCLUDING WHEN AND HOW TO INTRODUCE NEW FOODS. DUE TO THE PANDEMIC PUSHING EFNEP INTO VIRTUAL EDUCATION, WE RECEIVED PERMISSION, TRAINING, AND POWERPOINT LESSONS FROM COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY WAS USED TO TEMPORARILY EDUCATE OUR PARTICIPANTS VIA ZOOM. EFNEP WORKSHOPS WILL INCLUDE LOW-INCOME HOMEMAKERS/INDIVIDUALS WITH CHILDREN LIVING IN THE HOUSEHOLD IN URBAN AND RURAL AREAS, WHO ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR PLANNING AND PREPARING FAMILY MEALS. PROGRAMMING WILL ALSO BE EXTENDED TO LOW-INCOME YOUTH LIVING IN URBAN AND RURAL AREAS. YOUTH AND ADULTS WILL BE TARGETED VIA CHURCHES, FAITH-BASED ORGANIZATIONS, SCHOOLS, CIVIC AND COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS, TEEN PREGNANCY CENTERS, COLLEGES, BOYS AND GIRLS CLUBS, YMCA'S, HOSTELS, AS WELL AS HOSTING EFNEP SUMMER CAMPS THROUGH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF FACE-TO-FACE OR VIRTUAL NUTRITIONAL CLASSES, ALONG WITH FOOD DEMONSTRATIONS. EFNEP ALSO IMPLEMENTS THE KAHOOT APP INTO OUR MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL CLASSES. KAHOOT IS A MEDIUM IMPACT TECHNOLOGY TOOL THAT IS A GAME-BASED LEARNING PLATFORM AS EDUCATIONAL TECHNOLOGY IN SCHOOLS. IT IS A GAME-BASED CLASSROOM RESPONSE SYSTEM PLAYED BY THE WHOLE CLASS IN REAL TIME. MULTIPLE-CHOICE QUESTIONS ARE PROJECTED ON THE SCREEN. STUDENTS ANSWER THE QUESTIONS WITH THEIR SMARTPHONE, TABLET, OR COMPUTER. THIS WILL BE USED AS A SUPPLEMENT TO ENHANCE STUDENT’S INTEREST AND INTERACTION IN EFNEP CLASSES. PROGRAM DESCRIPTION: THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) IS A NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM FOR FOOD INSECURE LI MITED-RESOURCE YOUTH AND FAMILIES DELIVERED THROUGH THE COOPERATIVE EXTENSION SERVICE IN EVERY STATE AND U.S. TERRITORY. IN MARYLAND, EFNEP IS IMPLEMENTED THROUGH THE UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND EXTENSION AND IS HOUSED IN THE DEPARTMENT OF NUTRITION AND FOOD SCIENCE AT THE UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND. EFNEP IS FUNDED BY THE UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE (USDA)/ NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF FOOD AND A GRICULTURE AND BRINGS TOGETHER FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL RESOURCES TO TEACH LIMITED-INCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH ABOUT HEALTHY EATING AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY.  EFNEP HELPS FAMILIES LEARN SKILLS AND STRATEGIES TO FEED THEIR FAMILY NUTRITIOUS MEALS ON A LIMITED BUDGET, MAKE HEALTHIER FOOD CHOICES AT HOME AND AT THE GROCERY STORE, IMPROVE FOOD SECURITY AND IMPROVE THEIR OVERALL HEALTH. THE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS ACQUIRED ALSO HELP FAMILIES AND YOUTH CHANGE BEHAVIORS THAT PLACE THEM AT LONG-TERM RISK FOR OVERWEIGHT/OBESITY AND CHRONIC DISEASES SUCH AS DIABETES, HEART DISEASE AND CERTAIN CANCERS THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) IN MARYLAND UTILIZES EVIDENCE- BASED STRATEGIES TO ADDRESS DIET AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY BEHAVIORS AND REDUCE RISK FOR FOOD INSECURITY AND CHRONIC DISEASE IN FAMILIES. EFNEP FOCUSES ON DIET QUALITY, NUTRITION, BETTER FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, AND FOOD SAFETY. OUR WORKSHOPS ARE TAUGHT IN A SERIES AND PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS RECEIVE 6 LESSONS, OFTEN OVER SEVERAL WEEKS. THE CLASSES ARE TAUGHT IN SMALL GROUPS OR INDIVIDUALLY AND ARE DELIVERED IN A CULTURALLY SENSITIVE MANNER.  OBJECTIVES: THE PURPOSE OF THE EFNEP PROGRAM IS TO PROMOTE NUTRITIONAL WELL-BEING OF LOW- NCOME FAMILIES. THIS IS ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH A SERIES OF HANDS-ON, INTERACTIVE LESSONS WHEREIN PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS LEARN AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO IMPROVE FOOD AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY BEHAVIORS IN ACCORDANCE WITH USDA/U.S. HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES (HHS) DIETARYGUIDELINES, HHS PHYSICAL ACTIVITY GUIDELINES, USDA’S FOOD GUIDANCE SYSTEM (MYPLATE AND SIMILAR RESOURCES), AND PUBLIC HEALTH PRIORITIES, ESPECIALLY THOSE RELATED TO IMPROVING NUTRITIONAL HEALTH AND FOOD SECURITY. BY DOING SO, EFNEP CONTRIBUTES TO THE REDUCTION OF HEALTH DISPARITIES TYPICALLY ASSOCIATED WITH THOSE WHO HAVE LIMITED FINANCIAL RESOURCES. IT IS ALSO VITAL IN ADDRESSING MAJOR SOCIETAL CHALLENGES, SUCH AS REDUCING CHILDHOOD OBESITY AND HINDERING THE EFFECTS OF CHRONIC DISEASE.  EFNEP FURTHER CONTRIBUTES TO THE HEALTH OF THE NATION BY WORKING WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS AND INFORMING KEY DECISION MAKERS AND STAKEHOLDERS TO SUPPORT AN IMPROVED FOOD AND PHYSICAL ENVIRONMENT FOR LOW-INCOME POPULATIONS. IN WORKING WITH OTHERS, EFNEP’S PRIMARY FOCUS REMAINS ON INCREASING PROGRAMMATIC REACH AND FACILITATING PARTICIPANTS’ ABILITY TO MAKE DESIRED CHANGES AS INDIVIDUALS AND AS FAMILIES.  METHODS: EFNEP USES KNOWLEDGE GAINED FROM SOCIAL, BEHAVIORAL, AND BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES TO CONTINUALLY IMPROVE THE PROGRAM AND TO ADDRESS EMERGING ISSUES. CONTENT AND METHODOLOGY HELP BRIDGE PRACTICAL APPLICATION OF NUTRITION EDUCATION WITH SCIENCE.  EFNEP FOCUSES ON FOOD-RELATED PRACTICES TO HELP PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS ACHIEVE PERSONAL AND FAMILY WELLNESS. PARTICIPANTS LEARN TO: • CHOOSE AND EAT FOODS OF ADEQUATE VARIETY AND APPROPRIATE QUANTITY AND TO BE PHYSICALLY ACTIVE TO IMPROVE HEALTH AND REDUCE THE RISK FOR CHRONIC DISEASE (CORE AREA: DIET QUALITY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY); • IMPROVE FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES SUCH AS PURCHASING, SELECTING, OR OTHERWISE OBTAINING; PREPARING; AND STORING FOODS TO INCREASE THE SUSTAINED AVAILABILITY OF HEALTHY FOODS (CORE AREA: FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT) • PRACTICE SAFE FOOD HANDLING TO REDUCE THE RISK OF FOODBORNE ILLNESS (CORE AREA: FOOD SAFETY) • IDENTIFY AND USE EMERGENCY AND NON-EMERGENCY FOOD ASSISTANCE, AS NEEDED, TO ENSURE HOUSEHOLD FOOD SECURITY (CORE AREA: FOOD SECURITY)  PEER EDUCATORS PROVIDE A SERIES OF LESSONS DIRECTLY OVER TIME IN GROUP OR ONE-ON-ONE SETTINGS. EMPHASIS IS ON PROVIDING SUFFICIENT CONTACT WITH PARTICIPANTS TO TEACH THEM IMPORTANT FOOD- RELATED SKILLS AND TO SHOW MEASURABLE IMPACTS ON THEIR BEHAVIORS. LESSONS ARE LEARNER-CENTERED, WHICH MEANS THAT THE NEEDS AND LEARNING STYLES OF PARTICIPANTS FORM THE BASIS OF PROGRAM CONTENT AND DELIVERY. DRAWING UPON THE STRENGTHS AND PAST EXPERIENCES OF PARTICIPANTS LEADS TO A RICHER LEARNING EXPERIENCE. EFNEP USES INTERACTIVE HANDS-ON LEARNING APPROACHES, WHICH MAY BE REINFORCED BY TECHNOLOGY, INNOVATIVE TEACHING TECHNIQUES, AND ENGAGEMENT WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS.  PROFESSIONAL EFNEP STAFF COORDINATE EFFORTS AND COLLABORATE WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS TO IMPROVE THE FOOD AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY ENVIRONMENT FOR PARTICIPANTS AND INFORM KEY DECISION-MAKERS AND STAKEHOLDERS OF CHANGES THAT CAN POSITIVELY IMPACT THE LIVES OF THE LIMITED-RESOURCE POPULATION. EFNEP ALSO PROVIDES ONGOING PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES FOR PROGRAM STAFF THROUGH IN-SERVICE EDUCATION AND OTHER MEANS, AS APPROPRIATE, WITHIN THE PROGRAM CONTEXT.  EFNEP USES AN INTEGRATED LOCAL, STATE/TERRITORY, AND FEDERAL DATA COLLECTION AND REPORTING SYSTEM, WEBNEERS, TO GUIDE PARTICIPANT ED UCATION, INFORM PROGRAM MANAGEMENT, AND ASSESS PROGRAM IMPACT. GRANT RECIPIENTS SUBMIT A 5-YEAR PROGRAM PLAN, AND ANNUAL UPDATES IN INTERVENING YEARS, TO OUTLINE STATE/TERRITORY AND LOCAL NEEDS/OPPORTUNITIES, PRIORITIES, PLANS, AND ANY OTHER ADJUSTMENTS THEY INTEND TO MAKE TO THEIR PROGRAMMING. THEY ALSO SUBMIT DEMOGRAPHIC AND OUTCOME/IMPACT DATA ANNUALLY AS PART OF THE DATA COLLECTION SYSTEM. THIS INFORMATION IS USED TO MONITOR PROGRAMMING AND TO GUIDE LEADERSHIP DECISIONS AT BOTH THE FEDERAL AND STATE/TERRITORY LEVEL.

TITLE: SOUTHERN UNIVERSITY AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH <(>&<)> EXTENSION CENTER (EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM) FY 2023 EFNEP PROGRAM ABSTRACT  PROGRAM SITUATION IN LOUISIANA, OBESITY AND OVERWEIGHT HAVE REACHED EPIDEMIC PROPORTIONS. OUR STATE IS RANKED 49TH IN THE COUNTRY IN OBESITY. HOWEVER, WE RANKED 50TH IN 2011. (2012 UNITED HEALTH FOUNDATION'S AMERICA'S HEALTH RANKINGS). SIXTY-FOUR PERCENT OF LOUISIANA ADULTS ARE OVERWEIGHT OR OBESE (2009 CDC BRFSS) AND THE LOUISIANA REPORT CARD ON PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND HEALTH FOR CHILDREN AND YOUTH, SPONSORED BY THE PENNINGTON BIOMEDICAL RESEARCH CENTER GRADED OUR STATE A "D". MOREOVER, THE 2012 UNITED HEALTH FOUNDATION REPORT, LOUISIANA RANKS 40TH IN THE PREVALENCE OF OBESE YOUTH. SINCE 1990, THE PREVALENCE OF OBESITY INCREASED BY 135% (2009 UNITED HEALTH FOUNDATION). RESEARCH SHOWS THAT OBESITY <(>&<)> OVERWEIGHT ARE ASSOCIATED WITH INCREASED RISK FOR COSTLY CHRONIC DISEASES, SUCH AS DIABETES, CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASE, OSTEOARTHRITIS, AND SOME CANCERS AND OBESE ADULTS HAVE A 36% HIGHER AVERAGE ANNUAL MEDICAL EXPENDITURE THAN ADULTS AT A NORMAL WEIGHT. FURTHERMORE, THE COST OF CHILD OBESITY-ASSOCIATED ILLNESS INCREASED FROM 35 TO 127 MILLION IN THE PAST 2 DECADES. OVERALL, THE POVERTY RATE IN LOUISIANA IS 19.7%, AND THE PERCENTAGE OF LOW- WAGE JOBS IS 33%, EXTREME POVERTY LEVELS ARE AT 12%. TO ASSIST OUR EFNEP PROGRAM, THE SOUTHERN UNIVERSITY AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH AND EXTENSION CENTER HAS AN OUTREACH CENTER, THE SOUTHWEST CENTER FOR RURAL INITIATIVES, WHICH SERVES 10 PARISHES, INCLUSIVE OF THE PARISHES SERVED BY THE EFNEP PROGRAM. LANDRY, AND LAFAYETTE PARISHES. THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM AIMED AT PROVIDING PRACTICAL HANDS-ON NUTRITION EDUCATION. EFNEP DELIVERS NUTRITION EDUCATION IN FOUR CORE AREAS: DIET QUALITY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, FOOD SAFETY AND FOOD SECURITY. THE PURPOSE OF EFNEP IS TO ASSIST LIMITED-RESOURCE AUDIENCES ( ADULT AND YOUTH) IN ACQUIRING THE KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, ATTITUDES AND CHANGE BEHAVIOR NECESSARY FOR NUTRITIONALLY SOUND DIETS AND TO CONTRIBUTE TO THEIR PERSONAL DEVELOPMENT AND THE IMPROVEMENT OF THE TOTAL FAMILY DIET AND NUTRITIONAL WELLBEING. OVERALL EFNEP OUTCOMES INCLUDES INCREASED KNOWLEDGE OF THE ESSENTIALS OF HUMAN NUTRITION, INCREASED ABILITY TO SELECT AND BUY FOOD THAT SATISFY NUTRITIONAL NEEDS, IMPROVED PRACTICES IN FOOD PRODUCTION, PREPARATION, STORAGE, SAFETY AND SANITATION, IMPROVED ABILITY TO MANAGE FOOD BUDGETS AND FOOD RESOURCES AND INCREASED RATE OF PHYSICAL ACTIVITY.

KANSAS EFNEP WORKS TO PROVIDE NUTRITION EDUCATION FOR LOW-INCOME YOUTH AND FAMILIES WITH YOUNG CHILDREN, IN AREAS ACROSS THE STATE WHERE NEED IS MOST PRONOUNCED. KANSAS EFNEP IS IN THE FOLLOWING COUNTIES ACROSS KANSAS CRAWFORD, FINNEY, HAMILTON, HASKELL, KEARNEY, LABETTE, MONTGOMERY, SEDGWICK, SEWARD, SHAWNEE, WILSON AND WYANDOTTE.  KANSAS EFNEP WORKS TO ESTABLISH AND MAINTAIN RELATIONSHIPS WITH LOCAL, REGIONAL, AND STATE AGENCIES AND GROUPS AND/OR SERVICE PROVIDERS WORKING WITH THE EFNEP AUDIENCE. THESE EFFORTS RESULT IN COLLABORATIVE PROJECTS, PROPOSALS, AND INVITATIONS TO BE AT THE TABLE AS NEEDS ARE IDENTIFIED AND TACKLED. KANSAS EFNEP HAS DEVELOPED RELATIONSHIPS WITH DIFFERENT ORGANIZATIONS THAT INCLUDE THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION, THE SPECIAL SUPPLEMENTAL PROGRAM FOR WOMEN, INFANTS AND CHILDREN, DEPARTMENT OF CHILDREN AND FAMILIES, FOOD POLICY COUNCILS, LOCAL AND STATE BREASTFEEDING COALITIONS, LIVE-WELL COALITIONS, FOOD PANTRIES AND COMMUNITIES THAT HAVE RECEIVED THE BLUE CROSS BLUE SHIELD PATHWAYS GRANTS. AS EFNEP WORKS TO INCREASE AND CAPTURE OUR IMPACT IN THE COMMUNITY WE SEE INCREASED VALUE IN FORMING AND NURTURING RELATIONSHIPS.  THE KANSAS EFNEP AND SNAP-ED PROGRAMS ARE COORDINATED THROUGH KSRE BY THE SAME PERSON, WHICH HAS HELPED TO IMPROVE PROGRAM FOCUS AND ENHANCE OUR REACH RATHER THAN OVERLAP. LOCAL EXTENSION UNIT AGENTS WHO OVERSEE EFNEP ALSO OVERSEE SNAP-ED EFFORTS WHICH HELPS WITH EFFICIENCIES, BETTER POSITIONING PROGRAMMING IN COMMUNITY SITES SERVING THE EFNEP AND SNAP-ED AUDIENCES WITHOUT OVERLAP OR DUPLICATION.  THE KANSAS EFNEP PROGRAM’S AUDIENCE IS LOW-INCOME PARENTS AND OTHER ADULT CAREGIVERS (SUCH AS GRANDPARENTS AND GUARDIANS) WHO HAVE PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY FOR OBTAINING AND PREPARING FOOD FOR THEIR CHILDREN. KANSAS ALSO HAS A SMALL YOUTH PROGRAM, AND WE TARGET GRADES 3-12, BUT HAVE PRIORITIZED YOUTH IN 6TH GRADE AND ABOVE. WE SERVE A HIGH PROPORTION OF HISPANIC FAMILIES WITH EFNEP, AND WE TARGET THIS GROWING AUDIENCE THROUGH STRATEGIC PROGRAMMING WITH SPANISH-SPEAKING EDUCATORS IN AREAS OF HIGH POPULATION AND NEED, THE SOUTHWEST AREA, SEDGWICK COUNTY AND WYANDOTTE COUNTY.  KANSAS EFNEP HAS 6 PROGRAM PRIORITIES TO FOCUS ON OVER THE NEXT 3 YEARS.  1. ADULT IMPROVEMENT IN ONE OR MORE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY BEHAVIORS  2. ADULT IMPROVEMENT IN ONE OR MORE FOOD SAFETY PRACTICES  3. YOUTH (GRADE 3-5) IMPROVEMENT IN ONE OR MORE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY BEHAVIORS  4. YOUTH IMPROVEMENT IN ONE OR MORE FOOD SAFETY PRACTICES  5. IMPROVEMENT IN ADULT GRADUATION RATE  6. INCREASING DISTRIBUTION OF YOUTH PROGRAM IN GRADES 6-8 AND 9-1  KANSAS EFNEP WILL ALSO FOCUS ON WORKING ON CORE COMPETENCIES WITH STAFF, ESPECIALLY TECHNOLOGY AS WE WORK WITH DELIVERY SITES ON THE HYBRID TEACHING METHOD DESCRIBED IN THE TECHNOLOGY PLAN.  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY OVERVIEW K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION (KSRE) IS A STATEWIDE NETWORK OF EDUCATORS SHARING UNBIASED, RESEARCH- BASED INFORMATION AND EXPERTISE ON ISSUES IMPORTANT TO KANSANS. THE KSRE NETWORK INCLUDESOFFICES IN ALL 105 COUNTIES, ALONG WITH FOUR REGIONAL EXTENSION OFFICES, FIVE AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH CENTERS DISTRIBUTED THROUGHOUT THE STATE TO ENCOMPASS VARIABILITY IN CLIMATE AND SOILS, FOUR SATELLITE UNITS, FOUR AGRONOMY EXPERIMENT FIELDS AND FOUR HORTICULTURE CENTERS AND EXPERIMENT FIELDS. IN ADDITION, KSRE FUNDS RESEARCH PROJECTS IN 20 DEPARTMENTS ACROSS FIVE COLLEGES.  A UNIQUE FEATURE WITHIN THE K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION ORGANIZATION IS THE CLOSE ALIGNMENT OF RESEARCH AND EXTENSION. IN 1996, K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION WAS FORMED BY ALIGNING THE KANSAS AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION (KAES) AND THE KANSAS COOPERATIVE EXTENSION SERVICE. THE STRATEGIC INTENT OF THIS ALIGNMENT WAS TO ACHIEVE GREATER EFFICIENCY AND SYNERGY BETWEEN DISCOVERY AND OUTREACH EFFORTS. ONE ANCILLARY BENEFIT OF THIS ALIGNMENT IS THAT BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH WILL LEAD TO RAPID EXTENSION PROGRAMMING AND APPLICATION IN THE FIELD. THIS ALIGNMENT ALSO ALLOWS MORE FLUID COMPLIANCE WITH MULTI-STATE ANDINTEGRATED COMPONENTS OF AREERA.  K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION IS FOCUSING ITS EFFORTS ON FIVE GRAND CHALLENGES (CRITICAL ISSUES) THAT DIRECTLY OR INDIRECTLY AFFECT ALL KANSANS: GLOBAL FOOD SYSTEMS, WATER AND NATURAL RESOURCES, HEALTH, DEVELOPING TOMORROW'S LEADERS, AND COMMUNITY VITALITY. THESE GRAND CHALLENGES WERE DETERMINED THROUGH A SERIES OF MEETINGS WITH STAKEHOLDERS AND DEFINE AREAS OF EMPHASIS FOR AGENTS, SPECIALISTS, AND RESEARCHERS.  EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS AT THE LOCAL, REGIONAL AND STATE LEVEL WORK TO DEVELOP REGIONAL AND STATEWIDE SIGNATURE PROGRAMS ALONG WITH PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES FOR ITS MEMBERS THROUGH 11 PROGRAM FOCUS TEAMS – ADULT DEVELOPMENT AND AGING; COMMUNITY VITALITY; CROP PRODUCTION; FAMILY AND CHILD DEVELOPMENT; FAMILY RESOURCE MANAGEMENT; FARM MANAGEMENT; HORTICULTURE; LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION; NATURAL RESOURCES; NUTRITION, FOOD SAFETY AND HEALTH; AND YOUTH DEVELOPMENT. IN ADDITION, TWO TRANSDISCIPLINARY TEAMS WERE CREATED TO ADDRESS COMPLEX ISSUES TO KANSANS - LOCAL FOOD SYSTEMS AND STRESS AND RESILIENCY. THE WORK OF THESE TEAMS FALLS WITHIN THE OVERALL UMBRELLA OF THE FIVE GRAND CHALLENGES.  K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION CANNOT SOLVE THESE CHALLENGES ALONE. KSRE'S STATEWIDE PRESENCE LENDS ITSELF TO COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS WITH ORGANIZATIONS, PRIVATE BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY, LOCAL GROUPS, STATE AND FEDERAL ORGANIZATIONS, AND COLLEAGUES IN OTHER STATES. QUALITY FACULTY DRAW BUSINESSES AND FUNDING TO K- STATE AND TO KANSAS INCLUDING: - K-STATE IS THE ONLY UNIVERSITY IN THE WORLD WITH ACCESS TO A FULL CONTINUUM OF BIOSECURITY LABORATORIES LOCATED ON OR ADJACENT TO CAMPUS. THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE WILL PROVIDE PLANT DISEASE DIAGNOSTICS, RESEARCH, SURVEILLANCE, AND TRAINING IN DISEASE VECTOR BIOLOGY. THE LABORATORIES WILL OFFER EMERGENCY RAPID TESTING AND MANUFACTURING TO PROTECT THE NATION'S ANIMAL HEALTH AND FOOD SUPPLY DURING A CRISIS. - KANSAS PRIDE IS DEDICATED TO SERVING COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE STATE TO ENCOURAGE AND ASSISTLOCAL GOVERNMENT AND VOLUNTEERS IN MAKING THEIR COMMUNITY A BETTER PLACE TO LIVE AND WORK. THE KANSAS PRIDE PROGRAM IS A PARTNERSHIP OF K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION, THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE, KANSAS MASONS AND KANSAS PRIDE, INC. THROUGH THIS PROGRAM, LOCAL COMMUNITIES IDENTIFY WHAT THEY WOULD LIKE TO PRESERVE, CREATE, OR IMPROVE FOR THEIR FUTURE. THEN, WORKING WITH THE RESOURCES OF K-STATE RESEARCH <(>&<)> EXTENSION AND THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE, COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERS PULL TOGETHER TO CREATE THEIR IDEAL COMMUNITY FUTURE. - EXTENSION’S RESEARCH CENTERS, EXPERIMENT FIELDS AND HIGHLY SKILLED SCIENTISTS AND STAFF, COMBINED WITH THE CLIMATE AND SOIL VARIABILITY ACROSS THE STATE, PROVIDE UNIQUE OPPORTUNITIES FOR AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH  AND CORPORATE AND PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS. - FAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCES IS A PARTNER OF THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT FOR AGING AND DISABILITY SERVICES TO PROVIDE HEALTH INSURANCE EDUCATION TO MEDICARE ELIGIBLE KANSANS. APPROXIMATELY 1/3 OF THE CONTACTS OF THOSE SERVED ARE VULNERABLE BENEFICIARIES WITH INCOMES BELOW 150% OF THE POVERTY LEVEL. - KANSAS 4-H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT WAS AWARDED A CONTRACT BY THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION FOR $4.2 MILLION OVER THE NEXT THREE SUMMERS TO PROVIDE HANDS-ON, PROJECT-BASED 4-H SUMMER PROGRAMMING OPPORTUNITIES TO ADDRESS COVID-19 -RELATED LEARNING LOSS IN COUNTIES ACROSS THE STATE. BUILDING UPON THE LONG RECORD OF SUCCESSFUL PARTNERSHIP WITH LOCAL SCHOOL DISTRICTS AND LEVERAGING THE STATE'S LARGEST YOUTH DEVELOPMENT NETWORK REACHING ALL 105 COUNTIES, KANSAS 4-H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT WILL USE SUMMER ENRICHMENT PROGRAMS TO ADDRESS THE ACADEMIC, SOCIAL, EMOTIONAL AND MENTAL HEALTH NEEDS OF YOUTH AS A PART OF THE AMERICAN RESCUE PLAN — ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY SCHOOL EMERGENCY RELIEF PLAN. - K-STATE - IN PARTNERSHIP WITH FOUR OTHER UNIVERSITIES AND SEVERAL INDUSTRY PARTNERS HAVE JOINED EFFORTS TO CREATE THE IRRIGATION I NNOVATION CONSORTIUM, A COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH EFFORT TO ACCELERATE THE DEVELOPMENTAND ADOPTION OF EFFICIENT IRRIGATION TECHNOLOGIES AND PRACTICES. - K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION WILL ADDRESS THE HEALTH OF KANSANS THROUGH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE NATIONAL COOPERATIVE EXTENSION’S FRAMEWORK FOR HEALTH EQUITY AND WELL-BEING WHICH INCLUDES A FOCUS ON HEALTH EQUITY, SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH AND COALITIONS AND COMMUNITY HEALTH ASSETS.  THE DEMOGRAPHICS OF KANSAS CONTINUE TO CHANGE. KSRE IS REACHING OUT TO BOTH UNDERSERVED AND TRADITIONAL AUDIENCES THROUGH NEW VENUES. TO INCREASE MULTICULTURAL COMPETENCY AND SENSITIVITY AMONG OUR WORKFORCE, K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION AND THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE/KSRE DIVERSITY PROGRAMS OFFICE PROVIDES REGULAR NAVIGATING DIFFERENCE TRAINING FOR NEW EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS. THE GOAL OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO BRING SYSTEMIC CHANGE AND DIVERSITY TO THE KSRE TEAM AND PROVIDE CULTURAL COMPETENCY AWARENESS AND SKILLS THAT THEY CAN PRACTICALLY APPLY IN THEIR DAY-TO-DAY WORK. OTHER EFFORTS INCLUDE: - THE MULTICULTURAL UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE SUMMER RESEARCH FELLOWSHIP PROGRAM TARGETS UNDER- REPRESENTED POPULATIONS OF STUDENTS WITH THE GOAL TO ESTABLISH NETWORKING RELATIONSHIPS BACK TO THEIR RESPECTIVE HOME INSTITUTIONS, AS WELL AS K-STATE FACULTY. THIS PROGRAM HAS A SPECIFIC GOAL OF GROWING THE MINORITY POPULATIONS OF STUDENTS WITHIN GRADUATE PROGRAMS IN THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE AND ACROSS OTHER PARTNER COLLEGES REPRESENTED WITHIN K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION. - LOCAL UNIT EXTENSION COUNCIL MEMBERS REVIEW PARITY STATISTICS ANNUALLY AND SPEND TIME DETERMINING STRATEGIC EFFORTS NECESSARY TO REACH UNDERSERVED AND AT-RISK AUDIENCES. - K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION IS IN THE PROCESS OF DEVELOPING A LANGUAGE ACCESS PLAN AND SECURING SERVICES THROUGH LANGUAGE LINE SERVICES TO BRING GREATER ACCESS TO LIMITED ENGLISH PROFICIENT AUDIENCES. - THIS FALL, A NEW COMMUNITY LIAISON WILL BE ON STAFF TO HELP LINK KSRE’S RESOURCES TO THE TRIBAL COMMUNITIES IN NORTHEAST KANSAS.  GLOBAL FOOD SYSTEMS AS THE STATE'S LARGEST EMPLOYER,AGRICULTURE DRIVES THE KANSAS ECONOMY. IN 2020, THE AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRY CONTRIBUTED $70.3 BILLION TO THE KANSAS ECONOMY. AGRICULTURE IS THE LARGEST EMPLOYER IN THE STATE, WITH 250,058 PEOPLE ACCOUNTING FOR 13 PERCENT OF THE ENTIRE WORKFORCE. WE ARE IMPROVING FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS TO FEED THE WORLD'S GROWING POPULATION, WHICH WILL ECONOMICALLY BENEFIT KANSAS.  TO FEED AND SUSTAIN A GROWING POPULATION, K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION IS FOCUSED ON DEVELOPING INNOVATIVE PRACTICES TO HELP FARMERS, RANCHERS, AND AGRIBUSINESSES IMPROVE PROFITABILITY, EFFICIENCY AND SUSTAINABILITY FOR KANSAS, OUR NATION, AND THE WORLD THROUGH CUTTING-EDGE RESEARCH IN AREAS SUCH AS GENETICS, DISEASE PREVENTION, FOOD SECURITY AND FARM BILL EDUCATION.  PROJECTS AND PROGRAMS WOULD INCLUDE:  • DEVELOPING AND TESTING NEW CROP, VEGETABLE, AND TREE VARIETIES SUITED TO THE KANSAS CLIMATE. • IMPROVING THE EFFICIENCY OF FEED AND WATER USE, REPRODUCTION AND ANIMAL HEALTH. • REDUCING FOOD WASTE CAUSED BY INSECTS, POOR STORAGE, AND PROCESSING TECHNIQUES. • CREATING SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS THAT INTENSIFY PRODUCTIVITY. • IDENTIFYING WAYS TO MAINTAIN CATTLE RANGELAND THREATENED BY VARIATIONS IN CLIMATE. • LEADING NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL TEAMS TO SOLVE GLOBAL FOOD ISSUES. • HELPING FAMILIES STRETCH THEIR FOOD DOLLARS.  WATER AND NATURAL RESOURCES WATER QUALITY IN CENTRAL AND EASTERN KANSAS AND WATER QUANTITY IN WESTERN KANSAS ARE IMPORTANT ISSUES. CURRENT IRRIGATION TRENDS COULD DEPLETE 69 PERCENT OF THE GROUNDWATER IN THE OGALLALA AQUIFER WITHIN 50 YEARS, DRASTICALLY AFFECTING THE KANSAS ECONOMY. SEDIMENT AND SILT ARE WASHING INTO LARGE RESERVOIRS THAT SUPPLY DRINKING WATER AND RECREATION TO MANY KANSANS.  TO ENSURE FUTURE GENERATIONS HAVE A RELIABLE SOURCE OF CLEAN WATER, OUR FOCUS WILL BE TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT PROGRAMS TO HELP KANSANS MAINTAIN AND IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY. THESE INCLUDE PIONEERING NEW PRACTICES AND TECHNIQUES; RESEARCHING HIGH-PRIORITY WATER ISSUES; FACILITATING MEETINGS AMONG LOCAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL OFFICIALS AND EFFECTIVELY COMMUNICATING RESEARCH RESULTS.  PROJECTS AND PROGRAMS WOULD INCLUDE: • BREEDING NEW DROUGHT-TOLERANT CROP VARIETIES THAT CAN BE USED FOR HUMAN AND PET FOOD, LIVESTOCK FEED, AND FUEL. • IDENTIFYING BEST-ADAPTED TURF SPECIES AND CULTIVARS FOR KANSAS. • DEVELOPING MORE EFFICIENT IRRIGATION AND WATER MONITORING SYSTEMS FOR HOME AND FARM USE. • REDUCING RUNOFF AND SEDIMENTATION INTO RESERVOIRS. • IMPROVING LIVESTOCK GENETICS TO INCREASE FEEDING EFFICIENCY, WHICH REDUCES FEED AND WATER NEEDS. • WORKING WITH THE STATE OF KANSAS AND PARTNERING WITH STAKEHOLDERS TO IMPLEMENT STRATEGIES IDENTIFIED IN THE 50- YEAR VISION FOR THE FUTURE OF WATER PLAN. • BALANCING THE USE AND PROTECTION OF THE STATE’S NATURAL AND RECREATIONAL RESOURCES THAT LEAD TO SIGNIFICANT ECOLOGICAL, MEDICAL, E CONOMIC AND CULTURAL BENEFITS.  HEALTH THIRTY-FIVE PERCENT OF KANSAS ADULTS ARE OBESE, AND 16.7 PERCENT OF KANSAS CHILDREN LIVE IN POVERTY. TARGETING THE DIVERSITY OF KANSANS, OUR PROGRAMS ADDRESS QUALITY OF LIFE, HEALTHY DEVELOPMENT, AND HEALTHY BEHAVIORS ACROSS LIFE STAGES FOR ALL SOCIOECONOMIC GROUPS.  PROJECTS AND PROGRAMS WOULD INCLUDE: • IDENTIFYING AND IMPLEMENTING PRACTICES TO HELP PREVENT ADULT AND CHILDHOOD OBESITY • PROVIDING OPTIONS TO HELP FAMILIES AND PRACTITIONERS UNDERSTAND HEALTH-CARE CHOICES FOR ELDERLY KANSANS. • EDUCATING CONSUMERS ON SAFE FOOD HANDLING WITH FOOD PREPARATION, FOOD PRESERVATION, FOOD SERVICE AND MORE.  COMMUNITY VITALITY RURAL, SUBURBAN, AND URBAN COMMUNITIES THROUGH KANSAS FACE MANY CHALLENGES. WHEN CITIZENS ARE ENCOURAGED TO COMBINE THEIR EXPERIENCES AND SKILLS TO WORK TOGETHER, EVERYONE IN THE COMMUNITY BENEFITS.  PROJECTS AND PROGRAMS WOULD INCLUDE: • HELPING COMMUNITIES OF ALL SIZES MAINTAIN NECESSARY SERVICES, SUCH AS GROCERY STORES, THAT HIRE LOCALLY AND GENERATE LOCAL SALES TAX. • WORKING DIRECTLY WITH FARMERS, RANCHERS, AND FAMILIES TO DEVELOP BETTER FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. • ENGAGING COMMUNITY GROUPS AND LOCAL BUSINESSES BY PROVIDING LEADERSHIP, RESEARCH-BASED EXPERTISE AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO MAKE COMMUNITIES BETTER PLACES TO LIVE AND WORK. • ADVANCING THE HEALTH AND WELFARE OF COMPANION ANIMALS • ASSISTING COMMUNITIES, ALONG WITH NEW AND EXISTING BUSINESS, BY COORDINATING SUPPORT AND TRAINING EFFORTS, CREATING SUPPORT NETWORKS AND INCREASING ACCESS TO UNIVERSITY RESOURCES.  DEVELOPING TOMORROW'S LEADERS THE COMPLEX GLOBAL SOCIETY OF THE FUTURE WILL REQUIRE LEADERS WITH EFFECTIVE TEAMWORK AND COMMUNICATION SKILLS. WE NEED TO PREPARE LEADERS OF ALL AGES, SO THEY MAY CONTRIBUTE TO A VIBRANT KANSAS ECONOMY FOR YEARS TO COME.  PROJECTS AND PROGRAMS WOULD INCLUDE: • BUILDING OUTSTANDING LEADERS WITH MARKETABLE SKILLS TO SUCCEED IN TODAY’S GLOBAL SOCIETY AND WORKPLACE. 4-H MEMBERS ARE TWICE AS LIKELY TO ATTEND COLLEGE AND PURSUE CAREERS IN SCIENCE, ENGINEERING AND COMPUTER TECHNOLOGY. • MEETING THE NEEDS OF MILITARY YOUTH AND THEIR FAMILIES AT KANSAS MILITARY INSTALLATIONS AND FAMILIES OF DEPLOYED MEMBERS OF THE NATIONAL GUARD AND ARMY RESERVE • TRAINING KANSANS OF ALL AGES TO BE BETTER CITIZENS AND LEADERS.

PROGRAM PURPOSE  EFNEP IN IOWA SERVES CAREGIVERS AND CHILDREN WHO MEET INCOME GUIDELINES AND YOUTH IN BEFORE, AFTER, AND SUMMER SCHOOL SETTINGS IN PARTNERSHIP WITH QUALIFYING SITES. TO SERVE THE MOST FAMILIES AND YOUTH POSSIBLE, IOWA EFNEP FOCUSES PROGRAMMING IN AREAS WITH HIGH CONCENTRATIONS OF ELIGIBLE FAMILIES. THIS INCLUDES THE URBAN COUNTIES OF BLACK HAWK, LINN, POLK, SCOTT, AND WOODBURY. PROGRAMMING FOR YOUTH IS PROVIDED IN POLK, BLACK HAWK AND CERRO GORDO COUNTIES. NUTRITION EDUCATION AND HEALTHY FOOD ACCESS PROGRAMMING ARE PROVIDED TO ADDITIONAL ELIGIBLE FAMILIES IN IOWA THROUGH THE SNAP-ED PROGRAM.  AUDIENCE AND OUTREACH  IOWANS EXPERIENCING POVERTY OFTEN EAT FEWER FRUITS, VEGETABLES, AND LOW-FAT DAIRY THAN IS RECOMMENDED. IN ADDITION, MANY COULD IMPROVE HEALTH THROUGH INCREASED PHYSICAL ACTIVITY. FAMILIES WHO ARE FOOD INSECURE FACE MORE BARRIERS TO ACHIEVING THESE GOALS. THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION BEHAVIORAL RISK FACTOR SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM (BRFSS) DATA FROM 2017 INDICATE THAT 44% OF IOWANS IN THE LOWEST INCOME CATEGORY EAT LESS THAN ONE FRUIT PER DAY AND 27% EAT LESS THAN ONE VEGETABLE PER DAY. IOWANS IN HIGHER INCOME CATEGORIES REPORTED GREATER FRUIT AND VEGETABLE CONSUMPTION. THE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY GUIDELINES FOR AMERICANS RECOMMEND 150 MINUTES PER WEEK OF MODERATE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY OR 75 MINUTES PER WEEK OF VIGOROUS PHYSICAL ACTIVITY. BRFSS DATA FROM 2017 SHOWS THAT JUST 12% OF IOWANS WHO EARN LESS THAN $15,000 PER YEAR MEET THIS RECOMMENDATION. OVERWEIGHT AND OBESITY ARE SERIOUS HEALTH PROBLEMS IN IOWA. ACCORDING TO 2018 BRFSS DATA, 69% OF IOWANS ARE OVERWEIGHT OR OBESE AND 63% OF IOWANS EARNING LESS THAN $15,000 PER YEAR ARE OVERWEIGHT OR OBESE.  ACS 2018 DATA ESTIMATE THAT 8.8% OF IOWANS SPEAK A LANGUAGE OTHER THAN ENGLISH AT HOME, AND FOR HALF OF THOSE SPANISH WAS THEIR FIRST LANGUAGE. IOWA EFNEP AIMS TO PROVIDE A BILINGUAL EDUCATOR WHO SPEAKS SPANISH IN COUNTIES WITH SIGNIFICANT DEMAND FOR THAT SERVICE. A RECENT IOWA SNAP-ED NEEDS ASSESSMENT SHOWED THAT PEOPLE WHO IDENTIFY AS AFRICAN AMERICAN HAVE THE HIGHEST NEED FOR NUTRITION RELATED INTERVENTIONS. THEREFORE, EFNEP AND OTHER NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAMS IN IOWA ARE COMMITTED TO IDENTIFYING METHODS OF INCREASING SERVICE TO THIS AUDIENCE.  WITH THE PANDEMIC, SOCIAL DISTANCING HAS BECOME THE NEW NORMAL IN THE STATE OF IOWA. EFNEP NUTRITION EDUCATORS PROVED QUICK AND ADAPTABLE IN THIS SITUATION. ALL ADULT STAFF ARE TEACHING VIRTUAL EFNEP LESSONS INCLUDING KEY NUTRITION INFORMATION, ENGAGING DISCUSSIONS, AND SKILL BUILDING IN THE AREAS OF RECIPE PREPARATION AND MEAL PLANNING. THUS, IOWA EFNEP AIMS TO IMPROVE AND CONTINUE VIRTUAL EDUCATION IN ORDER TO MEET THE NEEDS OF IOWANS. IOWA EFNEP IS COMMITTED TO PROVIDING HIGH QUALITY NUTRITION EDUCATION WHILE CONTINUING TO GROW AND ADAPT TO MEET THE NEEDS OF THE PEOPLE OF IOWA.  THE ADULT PRIORITY AUDIENCE IS CAREGIVERS WITH CHILDREN WHO HAVE A HOUSEHOLD INCOME LESS THAN 185% OF THE FEDERAL POVERTY LEVEL. OTHER PARTICIPANTS INCLUDE ELEMENTARY AGE YOUTH AND YOUNG ADULTS WITH ANTICIPATED CAREGIVING/PARENTING NEEDS. STAFF USE A WIDE VARIETY OF RECRUITMENT TECHNIQUES INCLUDING REFERRALS FROM ENROLLED FAMILIES AND AGENCIES, PRE-FORMED GROUPS,  DEMONSTRATIONS, AND THE LIST OF FAMILIES PARTICIPATING IN SNAP. REFERRALS ARE A COMMON AND EFFECTIVE METHOD OF RECRUITING NEW PARTIC IPANTS. REFERRALS MAY BE MADE FROM OTHER EXTENSION PROGRAMS OR BY OTHER AGENCIES SERVING A SIMILAR AUDIENCE. CURRENT AND GRADUATED EFNEP PARTICIPANTS PROVIDE THE BEST REFERRALS, SO EDUCATORS ARE ENCOURAGED TO REGULARLY ASK PARTICIPANTS TO REFER FRIENDS AND FAMILY. PRE-FORMED GROUPS ARE THOSE THAT ALREADY MEET FOR A PURPOSE OTHER THAN EFNEP BUT SERVE A HIGH PERCENTAGE OF EFNEP-ELIGIBLE CLIENTS. THESE GROUPS MAY INCLUDE HEAD START, PARENT PREPARATION CLASSES, COMMUNITY OR NEIGHBORHOOD CENTERS, TEENAGE PARENT PROGRAMS, AND OTHERS. DEMONSTRATIONS BASED ON THE EFNEP CURRICULUM CAN CAPTURE THE ATTENTION OF POTENTIAL AUDIENCES. POTENTIAL SITES FOR DEMONSTRATIONS INCLUDE WIC, HEAD START, MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH CLINICS, COMMUNITY OR NEIGHBORHOOD CENTERS, COMMODITY FOOD SITES, SCHOOL EVENTS AND FOOD PANTRIES. IOWA'S YOUTH EFNEP PROGRAM HAS STRONG DEMAND IN COMMUNITIES WHERE IT OPERATES. IT HINGES ON PARTNER SUPPORT AS IT IS DELIVERED AT LOCATIONS PROVIDING AFTER SCHOOL AND SUMMER CARE TO YOUTH FROM LOW-INCOME FAMILIES. MOST PARTNER AGENCIES ARE SCHOOLS AND COMMUNITY CENTERS (I.E., YMCA, SALVATION ARMY).  PROGRAM ACTIVITIES  EFNEP PROGRAMMING FOR ADULTS USES THE EATING SMART - BEING ACTIVE CURRICULUM FROM COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY. THE SERIES IS DELIVERED BY EDUCATORS WHO ARE TYPICALLY PARAPROFESSIONALS HIRED FROM THE COMMUNITIES WHICH THEY AIM TO SERVE. THE SERIES INCLUDES EIGHT LESSONS WHICH FOCUS ON NUTRITION PRACTICES, FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, FOOD SAFETY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY. EATING SMART - BEING ACTIVE LESSON PLANS ARE DETAILED AND APPROPRIATE FOR USE BY PARAPROFESSIONAL EDUCATORS. EACH LESSON IS DESIGNED TO BE TAUGHT IN 60 TO 90 MINUTES. THE INFORMATION INCLUDED IS BASED ON THE LATEST RESEARCH IN HEALTH AND NUT RITION FROM THE DIETARY GUIDELINES FOR AMERICANS 2020 AND MYPLATE (WILL BE UPDATED WITH NEW GUIDELINES). EACH LESSON ALSO INCLUDES A REFERENCE SECTION CALLED “FOR YOUR INFORMATION” TO ASSIST WITH STAFF BACKGROUND UNDERSTANDING AND TRAINING. ALL PARTICIPANT MATERIALS ARE AVAILABLE IN ENGLISH AND SPANISH. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE FACILITATED DISCUSSION (DIALOGUE-BASED LEARNING) AND HANDS-ON ACTIVITIES SUCH AS MENU PLANNING, WHILE INFORMATION SHARING SECTIONS ARE SHORT. THE CORE LESSONS INCLUDE THE LATEST, RESEARCH-BASED INFORMATION FROM THE DIETARY GUIDELINES FOR AMERICANS AND COVER TOPICS ABOUT PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, NUTRITION AND HEALTHY LIFESTYLE CHOICES, FOOD PREPARATION (COOKING), AND FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT (SAVING MONEY AT THE GROCERY STORE), EATING A VARIETY OF HEALTHY FOODS FROM ALL OF THE FOOD GROUPS, FOOD SAFETY, REDUCING FAT, SUGAR AND SALT, AND FEEDING CHILDREN. SEVERAL EVALUATION STUDIES HAVE BEEN CONDUCTED TO ASSESS THE EFFECTIVENESS OF EATING SMART - BEING ACTIVE. SPECIFICALLY, CURRICULUM DEVELOPERS UTILIZED EXPERTS IN ADULT EDUCATION, NUTRITION AND THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) AND SUPPLEMENTAL NUTRITION ASSISTANCE PROGRAM EDUCATION (SNAP-ED) FROM MULTIPLE STATES TO REVIEW THE CURRICULUM DURING ITS DEVELOPMENT. REVIEWERS ASSESSED THE CURRICULUM AND CONFIRMED IT ADHERED TO AND EFFECTIVELY APPLIED THE TENETS AND PRINCIPLES OF SOCIAL COGNITIVE THEORY AND ADULT LEARNING AND THE CONTENT WAS BASED ON THE 2005 DIETARY GUIDELINES (EATING SMART • BEING ACTIVE HAS NOW BEEN UPDATED TO REFLECT THE 2015 DIETARY GUIDELINES WITH UPDATES FOR 2020 GUIDELINES COMING SOON). IOWA EFNEP HAS CONSISTENTLY SHOWN STRONG BEHAVIOR CHANGE, OFTEN EXCEEDING TIER AND NATIONAL AVERAGES USING EATING SMART - BEING ACTIVE.  KIDS IN THE KITCHEN WAS CREATED AT THE UNIVERSITY OF MISSOURI AND IS ALIGNED WITH CURRENT DIETARY GUIDELINES FOR AMERICANS. EVIDENCE OF EFFECTIVENESS IS CURRENTLY PRACTICE BASED. MISSOURI IS  PRIORITIZING ADDITIONAL EVALUATION TO EARN THE EVIDENCE-BASED DESIGNATION. SEVEN LESSONS ADDRESS THE VALUE OF PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, FOOD SAFETY, MYPLATE AND EACH FOOD GROUP WITH CHILD FRIENDLY ACTIVITIES AND COOKING OPPORTUNITIES. LESSONS ADDRESS THE EFNEP CORE AREAS OF DIET QUALITY, FOOD SAFETY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY USING LANGUAGE AND HANDS-ON ACTIVITIES THAT ARE RELEVANT FOR THE AGE GROUP. KIDS IN THE KITCHEN HAS DEMONSTRATED EVIDENCE OF EFFECTIVENESS WHEN EVALUATED USING THE YOUTH EFNEP EVALUATION TOOLS. GIVEN THE AGE OF THE PARTICIPANTS, KNOWLEDGE IS MEASURED WITH THE YOUNGEST CHILDREN AND SOME BEHAVIORAL CHOICES WITH THE OLDER CHILDREN. IOWA HAS ADAPTED THE CURRICULUM TO REFLECT RECIPES FROM OUR OWN STATE'S COLLECTION AND THE ADDITION OF PARENT MATERIALS THAT CONNECT FAMILIES TO IOWA'S SPEND SMART. EAT SMART. ONLINE PRESENCE. WE FELT IT WAS IMPORTANT TO HAVE A PARENT COMPONENT TO COMPLEMENT THE LESSONS FOR CHILDREN IN ORDER TO ENCOURAGE FAMILIES TO LEARN TOGETHER, PRACTICE NEW SKILLS AND ADOPT NEW HABITS.  KIDS IN THE KITCHEN ADDRESSES DIET QUALITY, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND FOOD SAFETY IN A CHILD-FRIENDLY WAY FOR CHILDREN IN GRADES K-5. GIVEN THE YOUNG AGE OF CHILDREN SERVED WITH THIS CURRICULUM, IT DOES NOT ADDRESS FOOD SECURITY OR FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT. YOUTH EDUCATORS TEACH IN A WAY THAT IS INFORMED BY THE REALITY THAT MANY OF THE CHILDREN PARTICIPATING COME FROM HOMES WHERE FOOD SECURITY IS A REAL CHALLENGE. THEY ACKNOWLEDGE THIS BY USING INCLUSIVE TERMS WHEN TALKING ABOUT FOOD BEHAVIORS; SUCH AS, MENTIONING THE FOOD PANTRY AS WELL AS THE GROCERY STORE WHEN DISCUSSING SHOPPING FOR FOOD.  DELIVERABLES AND OUTCOMES  GOALS FOR 2023 INCLUDE:  • 66% OF ADULT EFNEP PARTICIPANTS WHO COMPLETE AT LEAST 6 LESSONS WILL INCREASE THEIR FREQUENCY OF DAILY PHYSICAL ACTIVITY TOTALING 30 MINUTES OR MORE PER DAY. • ADULT EFNEP PARTICIPANTS WHO COMPLETE AT LEAST 6 LESSONS WILL INCREASE THEIR INTAKE OF FRUITS AND VEGETABLES BY A COMBINED 0.8 CUPS. • 54% OF ADULT EFNEP PARTICIPANTS WHO COMPLETE AT LEAST 6 LESSONS WILL INCREASE THEIR FREQUENCY OF PLANNING MEALS BEFORE SHOPPING. • 36% OF 3-5 GRADE YOUTH EFNEP PARTICIPANTS WILL INCREASE THEIR FREQUENCY OF VEGETABLE CONSUMPTION AFTER 5 OR MORE LESSONS. • 41% OF 3-5 GRADE YOUTH EFNEP PARTICIPANTS WILL INCREASE THEIR PHYSICAL ACTIVITY FREQUENCY AFTER 5 OR MORE LESSONS.

THE GOAL OF MISSOURI’S EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) IS TO ASSIST MISSOURIANS WITH LIMITED RESOURCES IN ACHIEVING LIFELONG HEALTH AND FITNESS. OUR PRIMARY TARGET AUDIENCE IS WOMEN OR PRIMARY FOOD PREPARER IN HOMES WITH CHILDREN. IN ADDITION, WE WORK WITH MISSOURI’S 4-H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMS TO OFFER NUTRITION EDUCATION TO GROUPS OF YOUTH. ALL PARTICIPANTS RECEIVE A MINIMUM OF SIX LESSONS. MISSOURI’S EFNEP PROGRAM PROVIDES EDUCATION TO ADULTS IN URBAN AND METROPOLITAN COMMUNITIES, IN TEN COUNTIES AND CITY OF ST. LOUIS, SO WE CAN OFFER EDUCATION IN MORE CENTRALIZED SITES AND REACH NEW ADULT AUDIENCES EACH YEAR. AS A RESULT OF THE PANDEMIC, MISSOURI SAW AN INCREASE IN SNAP ENROLLMENT OF OVER 80,000 INDIVIDUALS AND MANY OF THEM WERE FROM THE URBAN/METROPOLITAN AREAS, SO THIS GREATLY INCREASED OUR POTENTIAL EFNEP ADULT AUDIENCE. YOUTH RECEIVE NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAMS THAT INCLUDES A HEALTH ADVOCACY COMPONENT THROUGHOUT THE STATE WITH EMPHASIS ON 70 RURAL COUNTIES OF THE STATE. THIS WILL ENABLE US TO DEVELOP YOUTH AS HEALTH ADVOCATES WHO CAN ALSO EDUCATE ADULTS IN THEIR COMMUNITIES. THE OVERALL GOALS OF OUR PROGRAM INCLUDE: • ADULT EFNEP PARTICIPANTS WILL IMPROVE OR MAINTAIN THEIR OVERALL HEALTH LONG TERM. BY SEPTEMBER 30, 2024, WE ANTICIPATE THAT EIGHTY PERCENT (80%) OF ADULT PROGRAM GRADUATES WILL IMPROVE ONE OR MORE DIET QUALITY BEHAVIORS AS DEMONSTRATED ON THE ADULT QUESTIONNAIRE/BEHAVIOR CHECKLIST. • LONG TERM, OUR GOAL IS THAT ADULT EFNEP GRADUATES WILL BE MODERATELY PHYSICALLY ACTIVE FOR 30 MINUTES OR MORE MOST DAYS OF THE WEEK. BY SEPTEMBER 30, 2024, FIFTY-FIVE PERCENT (55%) OF ADULT EFNEP GRADUATES WILL REPORT THAT THEY PARTICIPATE IN 30 MINUTES OR MORE OF MODERATE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY MOST DAYS OF THE WEEK. • LONG TERM, OUR GOAL IS THAT YOUTH EFNEP PARTICIPANTS WILL IMPROVE OR MAINTAIN THEIR OVERALL HEALTH LONG TERM. BY SEPTEMBER 30, 2025, WE ANTICIPATE THAT EIGHTY PERCENT (80%) OF YOUTH PROGRAM GRADUATES WILL IMPROVE ONE OR MORE DIET QUALITY BEHAVIORS AS DEMONSTRATED ON THE BEHAVIOR CHECKLIST. WE WILL ALSO EVALUATE THE IMPACT OF THE USE OF THE SNAC PROGRAM TO ENHANCE THE ENVIRONMENTS AND SYSTEMS IN WHICH YOUTH INTERACT. • LONG TERM, OUR GOAL IS TO KNOW THAT THERE IS A SAFE, ADEQUATE, HEALTHY FOOD SUPPLY AVAILABLE TO ALL COMMUNITY MEMBERS. BY SEPTEMBER 30, 2025, AS A RESULT OF OUR NUTRITION EDUCATION, WE WILL DECREASE THE FOOD INSECURITY STATUS OF PARTICIPANTS BY 50% AS THEY LEARN HOW TO STRETCH THEIR FOOD RESOURCE DOLLARS AND GROW THEIR FOOD IN COLLABORATION WITH PARTNERS.

PURPOSE THE UNIVERSITY OF RHODE ISLAND EXPANDED FOOD <(>&<)> NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) USES AN EVIDENCE-BASED NUTRITION EDUCATION APPROACH BASED ON FOUR CORE MESSAGES: DIET QUALITY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, FOOD SAFETY, AND FOOD SECURITY TO IMPROVE THE HABITS OF LOW-INCOME PARENTS/CHILD CAREGIVERS AND YOUTH (AGES 5-18). A CENTRAL EMPHASIS OF THESE PROGRAMS IS HANDS-ON COOKING OPPORTUNITIES FOR PARTICIPANTS TO BUILD SELF-CONFIDENCE IN PREPARING HEALTHY MEALS AND SNACKS AT HOME.  ACTIVITIES DIRECT EDUCATION PROGRAMS ARE DELIVERED BY PARAPROFESSIONALS IN VARIOUS COMMUNITY SETTINGS ACROSS RI CORE CITIES IN PROVIDENCE COUNTY AND KENT COUNTY WHERE POVERTY IS MOST CONCENTRATED. FAMILY NEWSLETTERS TRANSMIT THIS INFORMATION TO THE HOME ENVIRONMENT. · OLDER YOUTH (GRADES 6-12): MIDDLE SCHOOL AND HIGH SCHOOL-AGED CHILDREN RECEIVE THE SIX-WEEK TEEN CUISINE CURRICULUM. MISSISSIPPI (MS) IS A RURAL STATE WHERE 51% OF RESIDENTS LIVE IN RURAL AREAS MAKING MS THE FOURTH LARGEST RURAL POPULATION IN THE U.S. (HTTPS://WORLDPOPULATIONREVIEW.COM/STATES/MISSISSIPPI-POPULATION/). THE STATE IS CHARACTERIZED BY SLOW POPULATION GROWTH (0.30% COMPARED TO THE U.S. AVERAGE OF 0.59%) AND A HIGH LEVEL OF POVERTY (19.7% COMPARED TO THE U.S. AVERAGE OF 11.8%) (HTTPS://WWW.CENSUS. GOV/QUICKFACTS/FACT/TABLE/MS,US/PST045219). MS HAS THE HIGHEST PERCENTAGE OF ADULTS AGE 30 AND OVER RAISING GRANDCHILDREN (2.9%), WHILE THE NATIONAL AVERAGE IS 1.4% (HTTPS://WWW.CENSUS.GOV/LIBRARY/STORI ES/2019/04/OPIOID-CRISIS-GRANDPARENTS-RAISING-GRANDCHILDREN.HTML). MISSISSIPPI’S EFNEP FOCUSES ON LIMITED-RESOURCE FAMILIES AND YOUTH. AN EMPHASIS IS PLACED ON PARENTS AND OTHER ADULT CAREGIVERS (I.E., GRANDPARENTS) WHO HAVE PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY FOR FEEDING YOUNG CHILDREN, PREGNANT TEENS, YOUTH, AND SCHOOL-AGED CHILDREN (KINDERGARTEN AND ABOVE), AS WELL AS PREGNANT WOMEN AND EMANCIPATED TEEN PARENTS OR TEENS WITH CHILDCARE RESPONSIBILITIES. WE CONTINUE OUR EFFORTS TO REACH ADULT PARTICIPANTS IN COMMUNITIES WHERE THEY LIVE AND COLLABORATE WITH OTHER AGENCIES SERVING LIMITED-RESOURCE FAMILIES. ADULTS WILL BE REACHED THROUGH HOUSING AUTHORITIES, CHURCHES, COUNTY HEALTH OFFICES, DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN SERVICES OFFICES, FOOD PANTRIES, PARENT MEETINGS AT PUBLIC SCHOOLS OR HEAD START, COMMUNITY ACTION CENTERS, AND LIBRARIES. YOUTH PARTICIPANTS WILL BE REACHED THROUGH PUBLIC SCHOOLS (83% OF MS STUDENTS QUALIFY FOR FREE AND/OR REDUCED LUNCH), GIRLS AND BOYS CLUBS, AFTERSCHOOL PROGRAMS, SUMMER PROGRAMS, LIMITED RESOURCE 4-H CLUBS AND SCOUT TROOPS, SUMMER FEEDING SITES, HOUSING AUTHORITIES, PARK AND RECREATION SETTINGS, AND CHURCHES. SELECTION OF COUNTIES FOR EFNEP PROGRAMMING IS BASED ON POVERTY LEVEL, PERCENTAGE OF CHILDREN LIVING IN POVERTY, AND OPPORTUNITIES WITHIN THE COUNTY TO CONDUCT PROGRAMS. THE FOLLOWING COUNTIES ARE PROPOSED FOR CONDUCTING EFNEP: ATTALA, CHICKASAW, CLAIBORNE, GRENADA, HINDS, HOLMES, JEFFERSON DAVIS, JONES, KEMPER, LAFAYETTE, LEE, LEFLORE, MARION, MONTGOMERY, NEWTON, QUITMAN, SIMPSON, TATE, WASHINGTON, WAYNE. TEACHING SKILLS THAT HELP LIMITED RESOURCE YOUTH AND ADULTS EAT SMART, INCREASE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, AND ACHIEVE A HEALTHY WEIGHT MAY CONTRIBUTE TO REVERSING MS TRENDS. THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) CONSTITUTES THE EMPLOYMENT AND TRAINING OF PROFESSIONAL AND PARAPROFESSIONAL (PEER EDUCATOR) STAFF TO ENGAGE IN DIRECT NUTRITION EDUCATION AND OTHER APPROPRIATE NUTRITION EDUCATION EFFORTS, SUCH AS SUPPORTING TECHNOLOGY, WITH LOW-INCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH. PEER EDUCATORS HIRED ARE FROM OR REPRESENT THE INDIGENOUS TARGET POPULATION.  EFNEP SERVES TWO PRIMARY LOW-INCOME AUDIENCES: 1) FAMILIES WITH YOUNG CHILDREN (PARENTS AND OTHER CAREGIVERS WITH PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY FOR FEEDING YOUNG CHILDREN); AND 2) YOUTH/CHILDREN (GRADE RANGE - KINDERGARTEN THROUGH 12TH GRADE). THE PURPOSE OF THIS FUNDING IS TO INCREASE THE IMPACT OF NUTRITION EDUCATION DISSEMINATED TO LOW-INCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH IN THE 50 STATES, THE U.S. TERRITORIES, AND THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA.  THE PRIORITIES OF EFNEP ARE TO ASSIST LOW-INCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH IN ACQUIRING KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, ATTITUDES, AND CHANGED BEHAVIORS NECESSARY FOR NUTRITIONALLY SOUND DIETS AND TO CONTRIBUTE TO THEIR PERSONAL DEVELOPMENT AND IMPROVEMENT OF THE TOTAL FAMILY DIET AND NUTRITIONAL WELL-BEING. PARTICIPATION IN EFNEP SHOULD RESULT IN IMPROVED DIET QUALITY, FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, FOOD SAFETY, AND FOOD SECURITY THROUGH DIRECT EDUCATION AND COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT.

THE UNIVERSITY OF KENTUCKY EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (KY EFNEP) PROVIDES NUTRITION EDUCATION AND RESOURCES TO REDUCE NUTRITION INSECURITY OF LOWINCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH. NUTRITION INSECURITY IS CHARACTERIZED BY POOR NUTRITION, LIMITED PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, AND UNSAFE FOOD PRACTICES AND KENTUCKY EFNEP HAS IDENTIFIED THE LOCATIONS OF GREATEST POVERTY, MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES, AND FEMALEHEADED HOUSEHOLDS TO ENSURE KY EFNEP TARGETS EFFORTS MORE EFFECTIVELY.  KENTUCKY CONSISTENTLY RANKS AMONG THE TOP TEN STATES IN THE UNITED STATES FOR POVERTY WHEN UTILIZING THE POVERTY RATE BY HOUSEHOLD INCOME, WITH THE MOST CURRENT STATISTICS REPORTING 18.3%1 (823,443 OF 4,499,690) OF KENTUCKIANS LIVING IN POVERTY. THE GREATEST PERCENTAGES OF KENTUCKYS POPULATION LIVING IN POVERTY ARE LOCATED IN THE EAST AND SOUTHEAST AREAS OF THE STATE, BUT 49% (59) OF KENTUCKY COUNTIES HAVE POVERTY LEVELS HIGHER THAN 18.3%. WHILE PERCENTAGES OF POVERTY ARE LOWER IN URBAN AREAS, THE NUMBERS OF KENTUCKIANS LIVING IN POVERTY ARE GREATER IN THESE AREAS.  THE FOOD RESEARCH AND ACTION CENTER REPORTS A POSITIVE CORRELATION BETWEEN POVERTY AND OBESITY2, AND KENTUCKY DEMONSTRATES THIS CORRELATION. KENTUCKYS SELFREPORTED PREVALENCE OF OBESITY AMONG ADULTS IS 36.6%3 (1,113,120 OF 3,041,313), AMONG THE HIGHEST IN THE UNITED STATES. IN 2018, 13.1%4 (ABOUT 398,412) OF KENTUCKYS ADULT POPULATION WAS KNOWN TO BE DIABETIC. ACCORDING TO THE 2020 KIDS COUNT DATA CENTER, 23% OF KENTUCKYS CHILDREN (ABOUT 269,602) LIVED AT 100% POVERTY, AND 40% (ABOUT 468,874) LIVED IN AREAS OF CONCENTRATED POVERTY, 2013 20178. STATEWIDE, 61%9 (ABOUT 715,000) OF KENTUCKYS STUDENTS QUALIFIED FOR FREE OR REDUCED PRICE MEALS THROUGH THE NATIONAL SCHOOL LUNCH PROGRAM, DURING THE 20182019 SCHOOL YEAR (PRE PANDEMIC DATA).  TO MEET THE NEEDS OF ELIGIBLE HISPANIC FAMILIES, KY EFNEP HAS DEVELOPED EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS, PUBLICATIONS, AND TEACHING AIDS WRITTEN IN SPANISH AND USES TRANSLATORS WHEN NEEDED. TO REACH REFUGEE POPULATIONS, THERE ARE PUBLICATIONS AVAILABLE IN FRENCH AND SWAHILI. IN ADDITION TO LIMITED ENGLISH PROFICIENCY AUDIENCES WHO DO NOT SPEAK ENGLISH AS THEIR FIRST LANGUAGE, EFNEP IN KENTUCKY DESIGNS RESOURCES TO MEET THE NEEDS OF KENTUCKIANS WHO HAVE LOW LITERACY LEVELS. EFNEP REACHES OUT TO AUDIENCES WHO ARE VISUALLY IMPAIRED USING CURRICULUM TRANSLATED INTO BRAILLE AND MODIFICATIONS TO CURRICULUM TO MEET PHYSICAL AND INTELLECTUAL DISABILITIES. EFNEP WILL ALSO TARGET THE LARGE NUMBER OF MILITARY FAMILIES WITH CHILDREN WHO RESIDE IN KENTUCKY AND ARE MEMBERS OF THE LIMITED RESOURCE COMMUNITY. TO REACH SPECIFIC ADULT POPULATIONS, THE ADULT CURRICULUM IS CURRENTLY BEING MODIFIED TO ADDRESS THE SPECIFIC NEEDS OF AUDIENCES IN SUBSTANCE USE RECOVERY; AS WELL, AN ADDITIONAL MODIFICATION FOR PREGNANT WOMEN. LIMITED RESOURCE YOUTH ARE REACHED THROUGH VARIOUS VENUES, INCLUDING SCHOOL PROGRAMS, SUMMER YOUTH CAMPS, FAMILY RESOURCE YOUTH SERVICE CENTERS AND LOCATIONS OFFERING THE SUMMER FEEDING PROGRAM. UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF COUNTY FAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCE AGENTS AND AREA NUTRITION AGENTS, AND WITH THE SUPPORT OF STATE AND COUNTY EXTENSION RESOURCES, PARAPROFESSIONALS BUILD A NETWORK WITH PARTNER AGENCIES THAT PROVIDE REFERRALS, PROGRAM VOLUNTEERS, AND MEETING LOCATIONS. PARAPROFESSIONALS IMPLEMENT THE PROGRAM THROUGH GROUP TEACHING METHODS.  KY EFNEP IS COORDINATING ACTIVITIES WITH OUR 1890 PARTNER INSTITUTION, KY STATE UNIVERSITY, IN THEIR EFNEP AND SNAPED EFFORTS. STRATEGIC PLANNING AND COORDINATION BROADEN THE REACH TO THE TARGET AUDIENCE WHILE ENSURING NONDUPLICATION OF EFFORTS. KENTUCKY EFNEP MEASURES INCREASED FRUIT AND VEGETABLE CONSUMPTION, FOOD SAFETY AND FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT. THE CDC REPORTS KENTUCKY ADULTS RANK IN THE 10 HIGHEST FOR POOR CONSUMPTION OF FRUITS AND VEGETABLES IN THE US. THE GOAL IS TO HAVE EFNEP GRADUATES DEMONSTRATE AN INCREASE IN CONSUMPTION OF FRUITS AND VEGETABLES BY 1/3 CUP EACH YEAR FOR THE NEXT FIVE YEARS, TOTALING 1 2/3 CUP AT THE END OF THE FIVEYEAR PLAN. IMPROVEMENT WILL BE MEASURED BY USING THE DATA FROM THE WEBNEERS PRE/POST 24HOUR DIETARY RECALL TO MEASURE FRUIT AND VEGETABLE CONSUMPTION OUTCOMES.  ONE IN SIX AMERICANS GET SICK FROM FOOD POISONING EACH YEAR. FOOD POISONING SENDS MORE THAN 100,000 AMERICANS TO THE HOSPITAL AND 3,000 DIE EACH YEAR. KY EFNEP FOCUSES ON THE FOLLOWING METRICS FOR FOOD SAFETY IN POST EVALUATION RESULTS: DO PARTICIPANTS CLEAN HANDS AND SURFACES OFTEN, SEPARATE FOODS TO AVOID CROSS CONTAMINATION, COOK FOODS TO THE RIGHT TEMPERATURE AND CHILL FOODS PROMPTLY AND PROPERLY.  KENTUCKY EFNEP GRADUATES ARE CURRENTLY AT 67.5% IN INCORPORATING FOOD MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. THE GOAL IS TO INCREASE THE FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES BY 4.2% EACH YEAR FOR THE NEXT FIVE YEARS IN ORDER TO MEET THE 84% GOAL RATE SET BY NATIONAL EFNEP. IMPROVEMENT WILL BE MEASURED BY USING THE DATA FROM THE WEBNEERS PRE AND POST CHECKLIST SUMMARY. IN ADDITION, PAIRING EFFECTIVE REINFORCEMENT ITEMS WITH LESSONS

THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) EMPOWERS INDIVIDUALS, FAMILIES, AND YOUTH WITH LIMITED RESOURCES TO ACQUIRE KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, ATTITUDES AND BEHAVIOR CHANGES NECESSARY TO MAINTAIN NUTRITIONALLY SOUND DIETS AND INCREASE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY. ARKANSAS EFNEP USES A HOLISTIC NUTRITION EDUCATION APPROACH. PARTICIPANTS WILL EXPERIENCE IMPROVEMENTS IN FOUR CORE AREAS: DIET QUALITY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, FOOD SAFETY, AND FOOD SECURITY. PEOPLE WHO ARE ELIGIBLE TO PARTICIPATE IN EFNEP INCLUDE INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES WHO ARE ELIGIBLE FOR ASSISTANCE BY PROGRAMS SUCH AS SUPPLEMENTAL NUTRITION ASSISTANCE PROGRAM (SNAP), SPECIAL SUPPLEMENTAL NUTRITION PROGRAM FOR WOMEN, INFANTS AND CHILDREN (WIC), HEAD START OR THEIR CHILDREN WHO PARTICIPATE IN THE SCHOOL BREAKFAST/LUNCH PROGRAMS. ADULT EFNEP PARTICIPANTS ARE TAUGHT IN SMALL GROUPS OR INDIVIDUALLY BY TRAINED EFNEP EDUCATORS. THE EFNEP YOUTH PROGRAM FOCUSES ON PROVIDING FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION TO CONTRIBUTE TO PERSONAL DEVELOPMENT. FOR YOUTH PROGRAMMING, ARKANSAS EFNEP USES THE KIDS IN THE KITCHEN (KIK) CURRICULUM DEVELOPED BY MISSOURI COOPERATIVE EXTENSION AND BASED ON USDA'S MYPLATE, AND TEEN CUISINE, A CURRICULUM DEVELOPED BY VIRGINIA COOPERATIVE EXTENSION. THE KIK CURRICULUM IS A SERIES OF SIX LESSONS IN THREE AGE LEVELS. LEVEL A (AGES 6-9); LEVEL B (AGES 10-12); AND LEVEL C (AGES 13-15). FOR THE YOUTH PHYSICAL ACTIVITY COMPONENT, ARKANSAS EFNEP USES THE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY COMPONENT OF KIK. TEEN CUISINE IS AVAILABLE FOR USE WITH YOUTH IN GRADES 6-12. THIS CURRICULUM WAS ADOPTED BASED ON REQUESTS FROM EFNEP EDUCATORS AND SCHOOL PARTNERS WHO ASKED FOR ANOTHER OPTION TO USE WITH THIS AGE/GRADE RANGE. TEEN CUISINE CONSISTS OF 6 LESSONS WITH EACH LESSON OFFERING A VARIETY OF ACTIVITIES COVERING NUTRITION, FOOD SAFETY, FOOD PREPARATION, AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY. THE GOALS OF THE CURRICULUM ARE TO APPLY MYPLATE GUIDANCE, LEARN HOW TO IDENTIFY NUTRIENT DENSE FOODS AND BEVERAGES, READAND FOLLOW A RECIPE, PREPARE FOOD SAFELY, USE FOOD LABELS TO CHOOSE HEALTHIER FOODS AND SNACKS, AND UNDERSTAND THE IMPORTANCE OF PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND INCLUDE IT IN EVERYDAY LIFE. WITH ADULT PARTICIPANTS, ARKANSAS EFNEP UTILIZES THE EATING SMART BEING ACTIVE (ESBA) CURRICULUM DEVELOPED BY COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY. ESBA IS AN EVIDENCED-BASED, HEALTHY EATING AND ACTIVE LIVING CURRICULUM. IT IS DESIGNED FOR PARAPROFESSIONAL EDUCATORS TO USE WHEN TEACHING FAMILIES WITH YOUNG CHILDREN TO LEARN HEALTHY LIFESTYLE CHOICES. THE CURRICULUM CONSISTS OF A SERIES OF NINE CORE LESSONS, EACH 60- 90 MINUTES LONG, DESIGNED TO BE TAUGHT IN SEQUENTIAL ORDER AND IS BASED ON THE LATEST RESEARCH FINDINGS FROM THE U.S. DIETARY GUIDELINES FOR AMERICANS. THE CURRICULUM ADDRESSES ALL THE CORE FOCUS AREAS INCLUDING PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, DIET QUALITY, FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, FOOD SECURITY, AND FOOD SAFETY. THE CURRICULUM IS AVAILABLE IN BOTH ENGLISH AND SPANISH AND IS DELIVERED IN BOTH LANGUAGES IN ARKANSAS. THEADULT PHYSICAL ACTIVITY COMPONENT UTILIZES THE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY PYRAMID BUILT INTO THE ESBA CURRICULUM.

ARIZONA COOPERATIVE EXTENSION IS A DIVERSE ORGANIZATION WITH A BROAD MISSION DIRECTED AT SERVING THE NEEDS OF ARIZONA. WHILE PERHAPS BEST KNOWN FOR WORK IN SUPPORT OF CROP AND ANIMAL PRODUCTION AND ASSOCIATED RURAL DEVELOPMENT, EXTENSION’S WORK AND INFLUENCE ARE FELT CONSIDERABLY MORE BROADLY. ARIZONA COOPERATIVE EXTENSION HAS EVOLVED TO EMBRACE AN EXPANSIVE MISSION, SEEKING TO ADVANCE NOT ONLY IMPROVEMENTS IN SPECIFIC SECTORS OF THE ECONOMY BUT ALSO TO PROVIDE KNOWLEDGE TO EMPOWER SOCIETAL, FAMILY, AND INDIVIDUAL CAPACITY TO THRIVE IN THE ECONOMIC AND SOCIO-CULTURAL FABRIC OF ARIZONA.  THE WORK OF ARIZONA COOPERATIVE EXTENSION CAN BE SEGMENTED ACROSS FIVE THEMATIC FOCUS AREAS: 1. AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION – COMPRISING EXTENSION WORK FOCUSED ON ENHANCING AND SUSTAINING ARIZONA’S COMMERCIAL CROP AND LIVESTOCK P RODUCTION. 2. NATURAL RESOURCES AND ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP – COMPRISING EXTENSION WORK TO HELP ASSURE RESILIENCY AND SUSTAINABILITY IN LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCES ASSETS THAT SUSTAIN ARIZONA’S ECONOMY AND QUALITY OF LIFE. 3. 4-H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT AND EDUCATION – COMPRISING EXTENSION WORKING TO BRING RESEARCH-BASED, KNOWLEDGE AND PROGRAMMING TO YOUTH THAT ENHANCES EDUCATIONAL AND PERSONAL DEVELOPMENT OUTCOMES, PERSONAL PRODUCTIVITY, EMPLOYABILITY, FINANCIAL SECURITY, AND QUALITY OF LIFE. 4. FAMILY, CONSUMER, AND HEALTH SCIENCES – WHERE EXTENSION WORKS TO EMPOWER INDIVIDUALS WITH THE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS REGARDING THEIR HEALTH AND NUTRITION, FOOD PREPARATION AND FOOD SAFETY, FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT/LITERACY, FAMILY DEVELOPMENT, CHILD DEVELOPMENT, AND PARENTING. 5. COMMUNITY AND BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT – WHEREBY EXTENSION WORKS TO PROVIDE KNOWLEDGE AND PROGRAMS THAT ASSIST BOTH RURAL AND URBAN C OMMUNITIES IN THEIR ONGOING DEVELOPMENT. EACH OF THESE PRIMARY AREAS OF ACTIVITY CONTAIN MULTIPLE PROGRAMS AND INITIATIVES THAT BUILD AND SUSTAIN ARIZONA’S ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL WELL-BEING. SERVICES AND PROGRAMS UNDER THESE AZ EXTENSION THEMES REACH ACROSS ALL 15 ARIZONA COUNTIES AND TRIBAL LANDS. THEY ARE MADE AVAILABLE BY AZ EXTENSION TO ARIZONANS YOUNG AND OLD, IN RURAL AND URBAN ENVIRONMENTS, AND AT HOME AND IN THE WORKPLACE. THE PRINCIPAL FUNCTIONS AND ASSOCIATED IMPACT BENEFITS OF EACH OF THE THEMES ARE ILLUSTRATED IN FIGURE ES-2 AND ARE DISCUSSED IN DETAIL IN THE REPORT THAT FOLLOWS.

ALASKA IS A SPARSELY POPULATED STATE WITH THREE-QUARTERS OF THE POPULATION CENTERED IN THREE URBAN AREAS WITH THE REST OF THE POPULATION WIDELY SCATTERED THROUGHOUT THE STATE. ALASKA HAS A TOTAL POPULATION OF 735,554 ACCORDING TO THE 2019 ESTIMATES BY THE CENSUS BUREAU, A 3.7% INCREASE SINCE 2010. MORE THAN HALF OF THE STATE’S POPULATION (53%) RESIDE IN THE SOUTH-CENTRAL REGION THAT IS COMPRISED OF THE ANCHORAGE AND MATANUSKA SUSITNA (MAT-SU) BOROUGH. FOURTEEN PERCENT OF THE POPULATION RESIDES IN THE FAIRBANKS AREA, 8% IN THE KENAI PENINSULA, 4% IN JUNEAU. THE REMAINDER OF THE POPULATION IS SCATTERED IN SMALL RURAL COMMUNITIES, WITH 1.2 PERSONS PER SQUARE MILE. ALASKA IS A FRONTIER STATE. THE POPULATION IS PREDOMINANTLY WHITE BUT HAS REPRESENTATION OF ALL RACIAL GROUPS. IN 2017, 81.1% OF ALASKANS WERE AT OR ABOVE THE POVERTY RATE BASED 125% OF THE FEDERAL POVERTY THRESHOLD, WHICH IS BELOW THE 90% GOAL FOR HEALTHY ALASKANS 2020. FOR ALASKA NATIVE PEOPLE, 68.2% WERE AT OR ABOVE THE 125% POVERTY RATE. ALASKA NATIVE PEOPLE HAVE LOWER RATES OF EXCEEDING THE 125% POVERTY THRESHOLD THAN DO ALASKANS IN GENERAL OVER TIME, ACCORDING TO THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND SOCIAL SERVICES. THE POVERTY RATE IN 2019 IN ANCHORAGE IS 9.2%, IN MATSU IT IS 9.1%, IN FAIRBANKS IT IS 8.9%, IN JUNEAU IT IS 7.9%, IN KENAI AREA IT IS 12.4%, AND IN THE SOUTHEAST FAIRBANKS REGION IT IS 13.4%. (INDEX MUNDI) IN EACH OF THESE DISTRICTS THE PERCENTAGE OF ALASKA NATIVES LIVING THERE IS HIGH, AND THEY ARE THE HARDEST HIT ECONOMICALLY. WE WILL BE TARGETING THE ALASKA NATIVE POPULATION OVER THE NEXT YEAR. OBESITY IS A PROBLEM IN ALASKA. ACCORDING TO THE ALASKA HEALTH AND SOCIAL SERVICES DEPARTMENT IN 2019 TWO OUT OF EVERY THREE ADULTS IN ALASKA IS OVERWEIGHT OR OBESE. THEY FURTHER STATED THAT 31% OF HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, 53% OF MIDDLE SCHOOLERS AND GRADE SCHOOLERS, AND 36% OF TODDLERS UNDER THE AGE OF THREE ARE OVERWEIGHT. ALASKA NOW HAS THE 15TH HIGHEST ADULT OBESITY RATE IN THE NATION, ( BIENER,ADAM, ET AL, 2019) ALASKA'S ADULT OBESITY RATE IN 2019 IS 29.5% (AMERICA’S HEALTH RANKINGS) WHERE A THE RATE WERE AT 23.5 PERCENT IN 2004 AND FROM 15.7 PERCENT IN 1995. IN 2007, THIRTY PERCENT OF ALASKA NATIVE CLINIC PATIENTS BETWEEN THE AGES OF TWO AND FIVE WERE REPORTED AS OBESE (FENAUGHTY, FINK, PECK, <(>&<)> UTERMOHLE, 2009). WE OFTEN THINK OF CONSUMPTION OF SUGAR SWEETENED SOFT DRINKS IN RELATION TO YOUTH, ADOLESCENTS, AND ADULTS, BUT A 2006 FOOD RECALL STUDY REVEALED A STRIKING STATISTIC OF 29% OF TODDLERS STATEWIDE AND 58% IN THE NORTHERN AND SOUTHWEST AREAS OF ALASKA CONSUMED AT LEAST SOME IN THE PREVIOUS DAY (FENAUGHTY, FINK, PECK, WELLS , UTERMOHLE, <(>&<)> PETERSON, 2009). 50% OF ALASKA HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, AND 23% OF ADULTS DRINK ONE OF MORE SODA OR SUGARY DRINK EACH DAY (2018 ALASKA CHILDHOOD UNDERSTANDING BEHAVIORS SURVEY). OUR PARAPROFESSIONALS WORK WITH MANY DIFFERENT ORGANIZATIONS. WE ARE CONSTANTLY NETWORKING AND WORKING TOWARDS EXPANDING OUR PARTNERSHIPS WITH NEW ORGANIZATIONS. SOME OF THE PROGRAMS THAT WE WILL APPROACH ARE WOMEN'S SHELTERS, SCHOOL DISTRICTS, FOOD BANKS, AND MANY OTHER ORGANIZATIONS. THE OTHER APPROACH THAT WE WILL TAKE IS TO VERIFY WE HAVE CONTACTS IN OTHER COMMUNITIES THAT WE CAN UTILIZE AS AN "IN" TO REACH THE ORGANIZATIONS. FOR EXAMPLE, IF WE ARE PROVIDING SERVICES FOR PUBLIC ASSISTANCE IN ONE COMMUNITY, WE CAN THEN PROVIDE THAT INFORMATION TO PUBLIC ASSISTANCE IN ANOTHER COMMUNITY, LETTING THEM KNOW THAT OUR PROGRAM REALLY WORKS, THAT IT IS RELEVANT AND THAT IT IS IN DEMAND. WE ALSO PLAN ON WORKING CLOSELY WITH FOOD BANKS TO ENCOURAGE PEOPLE TO PICK HEALTHIER OPTIONS WHEN THEY ARE CHOOSING THE FOODS, THEY TAKE IN THEIR BOXES THEY PICK. ANCHORAGE, MATSU, FAIRBANKS, JUNEAU, KENAI, JUNEAU, AND THE SOUTHEAST FAIRBANKS BOROUGHS HAVE THE HIGHEST POPULATIONS, BUT ALSO THE HIGHEST POVERTY LEVELS IN THE STATE OF ALASKA. ACCORDING TO THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND SOCIAL SERVICES (2019) THE FOLLOWING PERCENTAGE OF THE POPULATIONRECEIVED SNAP BENEFITS: 8.4% IN ANCHORAGE, 11.6% IN FAIRBANKS, 13.8% IN KENAI, 7.3% IN JUNEAU, AND 8.8% IN THE SOUTHEAST FAIRBANKS BOROUGH. OF THE TOTAL AMOUNT RECEIVING SNAP BENEFIT 57% OF THOSE WERE  HOUSEHOLDS WITH CHILDREN. WE HAVE SELECTED THESE COMMUNITIES, BECAUSE THEY HAVE THE HIGHEST POPULATIONS WITH THE GREATEST AMOUNT OF NEED. WE ARE TARGETING AUDIENCES THAT ARE BELOW THE POVERTY LINES, INCLUDING YOUTH, AND PARENTS AND GUARDIANS OF CHILDREN, ESPECIALLY ALASKAN NATIVES. ALASKA NATIVES ARE SOME OF THE HIGHEST POVERTY GROUPS IN ALASKA. WE WILL ALSO BE TARGETING OTHER LOW-INCOME MINORITY GROUPS, ESPECIALLY IN ANCHORAGE AND FAIRBANKS. THE POVERTY RATES ARE ESPECIALLY HIGH OUT IN THE RURAL AREAS OF ALASKA. WE ARE TARGETING CLIENTELE THROUGH THE PARTNERSHIPS AND ORGANIZATIONS, AND WE ARE TEACHING AT TITLE I SCHOOLS. WE TEACH 6 – 8 LESSONS TO OUR TARGET AUDIENCE USING EVIDENCED BASED CURRICULUM WITH TEACHES THE BASICS OF NUTRITION, FOOD SAFETY, FOOD PLANNING AND BUDGETING, FOOD SECURITY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY. WE ENGAGE THE PARTICIPANTS IN HANDS-ON ACTIVITIES AND CURRENT INFORMATION FOLLOWING THE USDA GUIDELINES AND MYPLATE. WE ALSO DEMONSTRATE HOW TO COOK NUTRITIOUS AND TASTY MEALS WHILE COOKING ON A BUDGET. THE CLIENTELE LEARNS KNIFE SAFETY SKILLS, PROPER HANDLING OF FOOD, AND THE RECOMMENDED GUIDELINES FOR COOKING MEATS AND STORING THEM. CLIENTELE ENGAGE IN FUN PHYSICAL ACTIVITY DURING EACH LESSON WHICH IS DESIGNED TO ENCOURAGE THEM TO PARTICIPATE IN THEIR OWN ACTIVITIES OUTSIDE OF CLASS. ALASKA HAS THREE MAIN GOALS: • INCREASE THE AMOUNT OF TIME PER WEEK THE MIDDLE SCHOOLERS (GRADES 6 – 8) ARE ACTIVE PER WEEK. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH BRINGING MORE “FUN” INTO OUR PHYSICAL ACTIVITY LESSONS. THE GOAL IS TO SHOW YOUTH THAT PHYSICAL ACTIVITY IS ENJOYABLE AND SOMETHING THAT THEY ARE WILLING TO PARTICIPATE IN. • ENCOURAGE ADULTS TO EAT MORE VEGETABLES. WE WILL DO THIS THROUGH LESSONS REGARDING THE BENEFITS OF EATING MORE VEGETABLES DAILY. WE WILL ALSO INTRODUCE THEM TO DIFFERENT TYPES OF VEGETABLES THROUGH OUR COOKING DEMONSTRATIONS. • ENCOURAGE ADULTS TO COMPARE PRICES WHEN SHOPPING FOR FOOD. WITH THE RECENT INCREASE IN FOOD PRICES THIS IS A SKILL THAT IS MORE IMPORTANT THAN EVER. OUR EDUCATORS WILL TEACH OUR ADULT CLIENTELE HOW TO COMPARE PRICES THROUGH COMPARING PRICING LABELS, USING COUPONS TO GET BETTER PRICES, AND TO SHOP FOR FRUITS AND VEGETABLES IN SEASON. ALASKA SUFFERS FROM INCREASING FOOD PRICES AND A DECREASE IN FOOD SUPPLIES AVAILABLE IN GROCERY STORES. IT IS NOW MORE IMPORTANT THAN EVER TO EDUCATE THOSE MOST IN NEED OF THE VALUE OF NUTRIENT DENSE FOODS, PROVIDING THEM WITH THE ABILITY TO MAKE THE MOST OF THEIR DOLLARS IN THE GROCERY STORES AND THE IMPORTANCE OF PHYSICAL ACTIVITY. ALL THESE ACTIVITIES CONTRIBUTE TO PREVENTING OBESITY WHICH IS A PROBLEM IN ALASKA. ALASKA EFNEP IS PREPARED TO WORK TOWARDS ACHIEVING THOSE GOALS.

ACCESS TO QUALITY FOOD IS A MUCH LARGER PROBLEM IN NEIGHBORHOODS WHERE THE RESIDENTS ARE PREDOMINANTLY THOSE WITH LOWER INCOMES AND/OR RACIAL/ ETHNIC MINORITIES. THE NATIONAL POVERTY RATE WAS 12.8% IN 2021, BUT WAS SIGNIFICANTLY DIFFERENT FOR THE NATIONS YOUNGEST POPULATIONS, ACCORDING TO THE NEW RELEASED CENSUS BUREAU REPORT. THE CHILD POVERTY RATE FOR UNDER AGE 18 AGE GROUP WAS 16.9% IN 2021, 4.2 PERCENTAGE POINTS HIGHER THAN THE NATIONAL RATE. THE STATE OF ALABAMAS CHILD POVERTY RATE IS OVER 22 PERCENT. GIVEN THE BREADTH AND SEVERITY OF THE IMPACTS OF DIET RELATED DISEASES AND CORRESPONDING DISPARITIES, THIS HAS BECOME, FUNDAMENTALLY, A PROBLEM. WITHOUT QUESTION, PROMOTING FOOD AND NUTRITION SECURITY IS CRITICAL TO RECOVERING FROM THE COVID 19 PANDEMIC, IMPROVING HEALTH OUTCOMES, AND ADDRESSING HEALTH DISPARITIES TO HELP GIVE ALL ALABAMIANS A CHANCE FOR A HEALTHY FUTURE. NUTRITION SECURITY MATTERS BECAUSE POOR NUTRITION LEADS TO DIET RELATED DISEASES SUCH AS OBESITY, DIABETES AND HEART DISEASES. WHERE WE IMPLEMENT OUR PROGRAMS ARE PREDOMINANTLY BLACK OR MINORITY POPULATIONS, WHOSE HOUSEHOLDS EXPERIENCE FOOD INSECURITY AT MORE THAN TRIPLE THE RATE OF WHITE HOUSEHOLDS. PARAPROFESSIONALS AS PEER EDUCATORS FROM THE INDIGENOUS TARGET POPULATION PLAY AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN SUPPORTING ADULTS HEALTHY EATING BEHAVIORS, AND WILL RECRUIT PARTICIPANTS FROM TWO PRIMARY LOW INCOME AUDIENCES: 1) FAMILIES WITH YOUNG CHILDREN (PARENTS AND OTHER CAREGIVERS WITH PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY FOR FEEDING YOUNG CHILDREN); AND 2) YOUTH/CHILDREN (GRADE RANGE KINDERGARTEN THROUGH 12TH GRADE). YOUNG ADULTS WITH LIMITED FINANCIAL RESOURCES WOULD ALSO BE APPROPRIATE FOR TU EFNEP, AS THEY MAY BECOME PARENTS IN THE NEAR FUTURE. THEY WILL TEACH EIGHT TO TEN LESSONS FROM SCIENCE BASED CURRICULA THAT REFLECT FOUR CORE AREAS TO ACHIEVE THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES: A) DIET QUALITY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY TO IMPROVE DIETS AND NUTRITIONAL AND PHYSICAL WELL BEING THROUGH THE ADOPTION OF FEDERAL FOOD ANDPHYSICAL ACTIVITY RECOMMENDATIONS. B) FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT TO INCREASE ABILITY TO BUY, GROW, OR OTHERWISE APPROPRIATELY OBTAIN, PREPARE, AND STORE FOOD THAT MEETS NUTRITIONAL NEEDS. C) FOOD SAFETY TO IMPROVE HOUSEHOLD FOOD SAFETY AND SANITATION PRACTICES. D) FOOD SECURITY TO INCREASE ABILITY TO GET FOOD DIRECTLY AND FROM FOOD ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS WHERE NECESSARY TO ENSURE HAVING ENOUGH HEALTHY FOOD TO EAT.  ADULT AND YOUTH PARTICIPANTS FILL OUT PRE AND POST TEST QUESTIONNAIRES, AND 24HOUR FOOD RECALL BEFORE DIRECT NUTRITION EDUCATION TEACHING AND FOOD PREPARATION DEMONSTRATION. QUESTIONNAIRES DATA INPUT INTO WEBNEERS FOR ANALYSIS AND EVALUATION, IS CONSIDERED BY PROFESSIONALS FOR DISCUSSION FOR IMPROVEMENT. A FACT SHEET IS PREPARED TO SHARE WITH STAKEHOLDERS. TU EFNEP INVOLVEMENT WITH ALABAMA COMMUNITIES SHOULD RESULT IN FAMILIES ACCESS TO THE SAFE, HEALTHY, AFFORDABLE FOOD ESSENTIAL TO OPTIMAL HEALTH AND WELL BEING. THE ULTIMATE EXPECTED OUTCOME OF TU EFNEP IS TO INCREASE THE IMPACT OF NUTRITION EDUCATION DISSEMINATED TO LOW INCOME FAMILIES WITH CHILDREN AND YOUTH IN THE COUNTIES SERVED IN ALABAMA. OUTCOMES EXPECTED ARE INCREASED REFERRALS ACROSS PROGRAMS, ORGANIZATIONS, AND COMMUNITY GROUPS TO ADDRESS PARTICIPANTS NEEDS AND TO STRENGTHEN UNIVERSITIES CAPACITY, AND INCREASED COORDINATION, COOPERATION, AND COLLABORATION BETWEEN AND AMONG ALABAMA STATE LAND GRANT UNIVERSITIES AND COMMUNITIES TO ACCOMPLISH PRIORITIES ASSOCIATED WITH EFNEPS FOUR CORE AREAS.

THE COLLEGE OF TROPICAL AGRICULTURE AND HUMAN RESOURCES (CTAHR) AT THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAIʻI AT MANOA (UHM) OVERSEES A STATEWIDE NETWORK OF 22 RESEARCH AND EXTENSION STATIONS ON FIVE HAWAIIAN ISLANDS. CTAHR, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH STAKEHOLDERS ACROSS THE STATE, IS ACTIVELY SEARCHING FOR OPPORTUNITIES TO INCREASE LOCAL FOOD PRODUCTION IN A SUSTAINABLE WAY WHILE ALSO MAKING IT MORE PROFITABLE. WHILE THERE ARE OPPORTUNITIES, THERE ARE ALSO SUBSTANTIAL CONSTRAINTS. THE COSTS OF LAND, LABOR, AND ENERGY EXCEED THOSE FOUND IN MOST OTHER STATES. AGROCHEMICALS AND ANIMAL FEED ARE MOSTLY IMPORTED AND EXPORTING PRODUCTS TO DISTANT MARKETS REDUCES THE FARMERS’ COMPETITIVE ABILITY. THE HIGH COSTS OF ENERGY, LACK OF SKILLED LABOR, AND REDUCED INTEREST IN FARMING ARE MAJOR CHALLENGES. CTAHR UNDERSTANDS THESE CHALLENGES AND ENGAGES IN A BROAD SPECTRUM OF RESEARCH AND EXTENSION ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING: MANAGEMENT OF INVASIVE SPECIES THAT CONSTANTLY THREATEN THE "GATEWAY" STATE OF HAWAI’I; IMPROVED CULTIVATION AND PROCESSING OF SPECIALTY CROPS; AGRICULTURAL ADVANCED TECHNOLOGY; DEVELOPMENT OF VALUE-ADDED PRODUCTS; INCREASING FOREST PRODUCTIVITY; PROTECTION OF FORESTS, WATERSHEDS AND COASTAL R ESOURCES; PLANT AND ANIMAL BREEDING AND GENETIC IMPROVEMENT; BIOFUEL DEVELOPMENT TO ADDRESS SOARING ENERGY COSTS AND FOSSIL FUEL DEPLETION; PLANT STRESSES RELATED TO DROUGHT AND CLIMATE CHANGE; FOOD SAFETY AND SECURITY; THE HEALTH (MENTAL, PHYSICAL, AND FINANCIAL) OF HAWAI'I'S CITIZENS AND COMMUNITIES; AND HUMAN NUTRITION PROGRAMS. CTAHR WORKS WITHIN THE FRAMEWORK OF FIVE CRITICAL ISSUES: BIOENGINEERING FOR AGRICULTURE/NATURAL RESOURCES/HEALTH; BIOSECURITY OF AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES; DIVERSIFIED TROPICAL AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS; PROTECT AND MANAGE NATURAL RESOURCES AND THE ENVIRONMENT; AND YOUTH/FAMILY/COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT AND HEALTH.

FY2023 EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP)  PROJECT SUMMARY THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) SHOULD CONSTITUTE THE EMPLOYMENT AND TRAINING OF PROFESSIONAL AND PARAPROF ESSIONAL (PEER EDUCATOR) STAFF TO ENGAGE IN DIRECT NUTRITION EDUCATION AND OTHER APPROPRIATE NUTRITION EDUCATION EFFORTS, SUCH AS SUPPORTING TECHNOLOGY, WITH LOW‐ INCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH. TO THE MAXIMUM EXTENT PRACTICABLE, PEER EDUCATORS SHALL BE HIRED FROM THE “INDIGENOUS TARGET POPULATION1 .” EFNEP SERVES TWO PRIMARY LOW‐INCOME AUDIENCES: 1) FAMILIES WITH YOUNG CHILDREN (PARENTS AND OTHER CAREGIVERS WITH PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY FOR FEEDING YOUNG CHILDREN); AND 2) YOUTH/CHILDREN (GRADE RANGE ‐ KINDERGARTEN THROUGH 12TH GRADE). YOUNG ADULTS WITH LIMITED FINANCIAL RESOURCES WOULD ALSO BE APPROPRIATE FOR EFNEP, AS THEY MAY BECOME PARENTS IN THE NEAR FUTURE.  THE PRIORITIES OF EFNEP ARE TO ASSIST LOW‐INCOME FAMILIES AND YOUTH IN ACQUIRING KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, ATTITUDES, AND CHANGED BEHAVIORS NECESSARY FOR NUTRITIONALLY SOUND DIETS AND TO CONTRIBUTE TO THEIR PERSONAL DEVELOPMENT AND IMPROVEMENT OF THE TOTAL FAMILY DIET AND NUTRITIONAL WELL‐BEING. PARTICIPATION IN EFNEP SHOULD RESULT IN IMPROVED DIETS AND NUTRITIONAL WELL‐BEING OF THE TOTAL FAMILY.  1. INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES SHOULD EXPERIENCE IMPROVEMENTS IN FOUR CORE AREAS: A. DIET QUALITY AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY—IMPROVED DIETS AND NUTRITIONAL AND PHYSICAL WELL‐BEING THROUGH THE ADOPTION OF FEDERAL FOOD AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY RECOMMENDATIONS. B. FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT—INCREASED ABILITY TO BUY, GROW, OR OTHERWISE APPROPRIATELY OBTAIN, PREPARE, AND STORE FOOD THAT MEETS NUTRITIONAL NEEDS. C. FOOD SAFETY—IMPROVED HOUSEHOLD FOOD SAFETY AND SANITATION PRACTICES. D. FOOD SECURITY—INCREASED ABILITY TO GET FOOD DIRECTLY—AND FROM FOOD ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS WHERE NECESSARY—TO ENSURE HAVING ENOUGH HEALTHY FOOD TO EAT.  2. COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT WITH EFNEP SHOULD RESULT IN: A. INCREASED REFERRALS ACROSS PROGRAMS, ORGANIZATIONS, AND COMMUNITY GROUPS TO ADDRESS PARTICIPANTS’ NEEDS AND TO STRENGTHEN UNIVERSITIES’ CAPACITY WITH RESPECT TO EFNEP’S FOUR CORE AREAS. B. INCREASED COORDINATION, COOPERATION, AND COLLABORATION BETWEEN UNIVERSITIES AND COMMUNITIES TO ACCOMPLISH LOCAL AND STATE IDENTIFIED PRIORITIES ASSOCIATED WITH EFNEP’S FOUR CORE AREAS.  THE [EFNEP] IS ALIGNED WITH THE FOLLOWING: STRATEGIC GOAL 4: MAKE SAFE, NUTRITIOUS FOOD AVAILABLE TO ALL AMERICANS; OBJECTIVE 4.1 INCREASE FOOD SECURITY THROUGH ASSISTANCE AND ACCESS TO NUTRITIOUS AND AFFORDABLE FOOD

EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM

THE CLEMSON UNIVERSITY YOUTH LEARNING INSTITUTE (YLI) WILL MAINTAIN, CONTINUOUSLY IMPROVE AND FURTHER DEVELOP THE WEB-BASED LOW-INCOME NUTRITION EDUCATION EVALUATION AND REPORTING SYSTEM (WEBNEERS). THE FUNDING WILL ALSO COVER ALL COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH HOSTING, SECURING AND BACKING UP THE WEBNEERS SYSTEM. WITH THE REQUESTED FUNDS, YLI WILL PROVIDE A TEAM OF SOFTWARE DEVELOPERS WHO WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH NIFA'S EFNEP LEADERSHIP AS WELL AS WITH A TEAM OF PROGRAM EXPERTS COMPRISED OF INDIVIDUALS FROM EFNEP IMPLEMENTING AGENCIES TO IDENTIFY NECESSARY CHANGES TO THE SYSTEMS FUNCTIONALITY IN ORDER TO KEEP DATA COLLECTION EFFORTS RELEVANT TO THE CHANGING NEEDS OF THE EFNEP PROGRAM.
